DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), on behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, made a statement placing before the House concerns his Committee had in relation to summonses issued on a person involved with the Committee's inquiry into the Australian banking industry.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have examined the documents presented by the honourable member. In my view the issues involved, as well as being of great importance to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in this particular inquiry, have important implications for the House's committee system.

Although the documents served on the person do not refer specifically to his involvement with the Committee, they do seek to place restraints upon him in general terms in so far as his ability to disclose and use certain information is concerned.

My understanding of the law is that, even if granted as requested, the orders sought could not expose the person to prosecution on account of what he may say in giving evidence to the Committee. Nevertheless, after seeking advice, I have concluded that the issues are sufficiently important to have counsel seek leave to appear on my behalf before the court when this matter is called on later today to make submissions on the matter of parliamentary privilege. I have accordingly asked that the necessary instructions be issued.

The honourable member also referred to the issue of contempt in so far as the witness had complained of what he saw as an attempt to intimidate him. I share the honourable member's concerns that witnesses must be protected. If evidence is forthcoming to support the claim of intimidation, I would naturally give it immediate consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a statement.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I have some concern that the appearance of a Queen's Counsel to argue a case for the Parliament submits the Parliament's rights to the judgment of the court. The Bill of Rights is absolutely clear. The courts cannot under any circumstances prevent the Parliament from conducting its duties, including the examination of public issues, and that is what is at issue here. Whether the Parliament itself makes decisions on how that should be conducted is a matter for the Parliament and the House of Parliament concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I place that on the record because I believe that there have over a number of years been attempts to reduce the rights of Parliament to examine issues and attempts to expand the sub judice rule. I am aware that Westpac Bank itself has said that it may challenge the sub judice rule on the basis that it should not apply where Westpac or other persons feel that it is against their privilege between themselves and their solicitors.

I am concerned that this matter may be used as an attempt to deny the Parliament its proper rights in a matter which could well involve very serious allegations which go to the administration and responsibilities of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member raises a very legitimate point for discussion in terms of submission to jurisdiction.
—Would the honourable member for Kooyong let me respond and then put forward his comments?
—Yes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the fears that the honourable member for Corio may have are groundless in this case. I am very much aware of the rights that the Parliament has and I will go to the barrier to insist that those rights are upheld. The reason that I am seeking leave to intervene in this case today is to specifically put the case before the court about what I feel on behalf of the House about the rights of people who appear before parliamentary committees as witnesses or who may be considering being witnesses.

INTERJECT.PARA: The court ruling cannot have any jurisdiction over what this House or its committees do, and I am sure that the judge who will be hearing this matter will understand that. I think it is sufficiently important, however, in this matter that we should publicly say that-that the reason we are seeking leave to intervene is only for the purpose of our publicly making that point on behalf of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, from what you have just said, I now curtail my remarks to agreeing with you. The mere act of having counsel appear before the court ought not, of itself, connote submission to the jurisdiction. I endorse your remarks.

—I would respectfully invite the honourable Speaker to reconsider his decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -The object of the Social Security Bill 1990 is to replace the current mishmash and complexities of the Social Security Act 1947 and the more than 100 amending Acts with a new plain English version.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to bring the size of the amended Act to the attention of the Parliament. Comparing it with the explanations which are in these volumes, on a weight for weight basis, one finds that the explanations are greater than the legislation itself. In that regard one wonders whether there is not a further complexity in the Social Security Acts in the explanations that go with them. I am almost reminded of a rewrite of the Bible, but even the Bible did not have the explanatory notes attached to it that this particular legislation has. I am relying on advice from my colleague in the other House that the matter has been explained in clear English-a plainer English version.

The rewrite of the Act does not involve any major policy initiatives, so we are told, and it does not have any financial impact. It is intended to reflect existing policy, and to make the Act easier to change in the future. It is hoped that it will pave the way for other large pieces of Federal legislation to be written or rewritten in a similar clear English style and format, so that they are more understandable and easier to interpret.

The first thing that must spring to the attention of honourable members of this House when we talk about rewriting other Federal legislation must be the Income Tax Assessment Act and the associated amendments that are attached to it. If the rewriting of the social security legislation proves a success, I recommend that the rewriting of the Federal Income Tax Assessment Act be the next task to be tackled.

The Bill is the culmination of a very interesting experiment to popularise the proposal. An exposure draft was released for public comment in February 1990. Public seminars have been held in each capital city. A legislative working party of the Social Security Advisory Council, led by Professor Terry Carney, has worked closely with the Department of Social Security (DSS) and the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel. The end result to date has been welcomed by all the major players. No public or private concern has been expressed by interest groups or media commentators-especially not to the Opposition. However, I suggest that it would take more than a day, a week or a month to digest properly all the pages that comprise the rewrite and the explanatory memorandum.

The Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) is said to be satisfied with the Bill, indicating that it is uncontroversial and that it contains, at worst, only minor drafting errors. In fact, ACOSS actually supports the Bill. The Welfare Rights Unit, which has particular expertise in reviewing social security legislation, has so far conducted only a cursory examination of the Bill but is persuaded at this stage that it contains no significant policy changes. In fact, that unit has recently established an eight-member working party to conduct a more thorough review.

The Bill comprises 600 pages; the explanatory memorandum is just over 2,000 pages. Any amendments that arise will be brought forward in time for debate in the Senate. The unit has undertaken to forward any proposed changes to the Opposition as soon as they are made available. The Opposition intends in the Senate to refer the legislation to the appropriate committee to allow further time for review. This will also allow any necessary amendments to be caught up with.

I understand that the Bill does not contain reference to a recent bilateral agreement with the Netherlands or to the December changes dealing with deeming. I want to deal now with the matter of deeming. Much as the Bill tries to clarify various things, there is still confusion and fear amongst pensioners about the deeming provisions and a lack of simplicity in relation to the implementation and interpretation of the Bill as it stands now.

On 18 December the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, gave the Senate an unequivocal assurance that he would not set a 10 per cent deeming rate on cash and low interest bank accounts held by pensioners and beneficiaries if the rate were not available to people around the country. This clearly meant that the 10 per cent at call, irrespective of the amount, would need to be available from all major commercial banks. Judging from the Minister's statement of 6 February this year, it was evident that none of the major commercial banks had come to the party.

Because the market was not paying 10 per cent interest on accounts at call, financial institutions were forced to make up contrived accounts to meet the new 10 per cent requirements of the Department of Social Security. None of the so-called special pensioner accounts with the major banks will pay interest on balances less than $2,000. Basically, when this is considered in terms of the relationship between the customer and the bank, it can be seen that it is a flagrant denial of any investor's right to a reasonable rate of return on his funds. Moreover, the ANZ and Westpac banks will not pay interest on the first $2,000, irrespective of the amount invested. On this basis, $3,000 would return a pensioner the grand total in interest of $100 a year. If a pensioner simply kept that sum in Westpac's Advantage Saver cheque account he or she would receive an interest rate of 6.5 per cent, or $195 in interest in a full year.

I mention also the risk that goes with the marketing of these accounts. In view of the confusion that is rife amongst pensioners at the moment, a pensioner might be persuaded to divide his investment and enter into one of these special arrangements with both ANZ and Westpac, thus denying himself the advantage of having those funds and having $4,000 instead of $2,000 invested without interest being paid and with the deeming provisions then applying.

The Minister's disgraceful strong-arm tactics will result in any pensioner who moves money across to the ANZ or Westpac prescribed funds losing about $95 a year. Of course, that amount is doubled if a pensioner has an account in both banks. Yet on AM on 23 August 1990 the Minister, when discussing his scheme to force pensioners to maximise their incomes, said:
But the truth is, every single person affected by this deeming provision actually finishes better off, more money in their pockets to spend.

As a result of what has happened in this regard, it is no wonder that pensioners have lost all faith in the Government and these particular deeming provisions. Pensioners are confused and concerned and this results in probably more representations to my office than I receive on any other social security issue. It is interesting to note that on, I think, Monday of this week there was a meeting of concerned pensioners in Melbourne which was addressed by Daryl Dixon. The meeting agreed more or less unanimously that the deeming provisions were not working, that they were not clear and that there was room for some rectification.

Another area of concern regarding the deeming provisions relates to loans to charitable organisations on which the organisations pay low rates of interest. This has been of particular concern to me as the shadow spokesman for aged care. Entry contributions to hostels were to be exempt from the deeming provisions but ongoing contributions and gifts were not. Many organisations involved in providing hostel accommodation for the aged rely on an ongoing flow of cash by way of loan or by gifting in order just to survive. The resources of these organisations are strictly limited. The importance of interest free or low interest loans being made available on an unrestricted basis is extremely critical to their survival-and these loans are approved under various Acts of this Parliament.

Since the announcement of the Budget intentions, the Opposition, the Voluntary Care Association of New South Wales and Australian Capital Territory, other voluntary care associations around the country-such as the Lutheran Homes in South Australia-and numerous other charitable organisations have urged the Government not to deny the use of pensioner loans at little or no interest to pensioners needing ongoing care. I said in my speech to Parliament in November last year that we must not, and cannot, afford to restrict support of aged care organisations to the fees of pensioner patients and Government grants. I am pleased to say that following this pressure from the Opposition and from the voluntary and charitable organisations around the country, the Minister has agreed to exempt from the deeming provisions loans and deposits with church or charitable funds if those loans or deposits are utilised for the purpose of capital expenditure. This announcement has been welcomed by all the aged care organisations.

However, I do understand that the Australian Democrats, who are ever keen to grab some type of publicity and who use special interest and minority groups in this quest, are pressing some aged care organisations to support an amendment which would allow ongoing loans and gifts to be used for recurrent funding of hostels. They are urging these organisations to set out the issues and are pointing out that these organisations will have to close or limit services unless the Government amends its legislation.

This is really a fairly desperate bid to gain public attention, it is irresponsible, and shows a lack of appreciation and understanding on the part of a political party of the existing conditions that apply to the funding in the aged care industry which, if there is a need for money for recurrent expenditure, can be gained through the entry contribution by diminution over the first few years and by using the interest on those funds. There is also a provision that if a person can pay more of his or her weekly accommodation and rental at a hostel the amount of the funding from the Commonwealth diminishes. As I have said, the Democrats display an abysmal lack of appreciation and understanding of the provisions that already exist.

Anyone with just a little knowledge of the cost of aged care and the increasing costs facing the country in the future knows that it makes sense for user contributions to be used, in this case to fund capital expenditure-that is, original capital expenditure for the accommodation, renovations or replacement-and for the Government to fund operating costs. It would be a retrograde step for aged care if the Democrats were to get what they want. In any event, if a hostel proprietor wishes to use the interest on ingoing contributions to supplement recurrent expenditure, as I said before, he or she is perfectly free to do so.

The Democrats tried to score further political points with their amendment to exempt the family farm from the assets test for family allowance supplement. The decision by the Government to impose an assets test for the family allowance supplement was a Budget initiative which the coalition parties did not oppose. In a letter sent to editors of rural newspapers the Democrats used this particular point in a rather crude attempt to claim all the credit for the coalition's decision to block the introduction of an assets test on family allowance.

The coalition's decision was based on the needs of people who live in poverty-prone rural Australia, a matter that Senator Richardson, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and this Government have not concerned themselves with. Nor have they concerned themselves in a large measure with the rural recession that the Government itself engineered. I need only remind the House of the quote of the Treasurer: `It is a recession Australia had to have'.

What the Democrats did not make clear was their fundamentally anti-rural bias. If they are really concerned with the survival of the rural sector, why do they still propose to reintroduce death duties for properties worth more than $300,000; introduce a Federal land tax; continue and strengthen the capital gains tax; abolish the live sheep export trade; reduce and ultimately ban intensive animal production; place stricter bureaucratic controls on all areas of agriculture, including land use; repeal the plant variety rights legislation; prevent the privatisation of most government enterprises; reduce the public funding of private schools; and remove individual choice in the education system?

In that last respect I point out the disaster facing some families in rural Australia, particularly as a result of the wool crisis. I have heard from honourable members on my own side that some families will not be able to educate their children; they will not have the choice of a private or a public school. That should be a matter of great concern to the Government and the Democrats. It is certainly of concern to us.

This is no centre of the road, keep the bastards honest-as Don Chipp put it-party; this is an outfit determined to fill the vacuum on the left of Australian politics which it believes to have been vacated by the Australian Labor Party. The latest example is its total opposition to Australia's involvement in the Gulf conflict. Unfortunately, this Party will continue to pander to the fears, ignorance and prejudices of those confused and embittered by the Government's massive failure to revive the economy.

On another social security matter, I would like to bring to the attention of the Minister the advice which continually seems to be given to applicants for the Jobsearch allowance and the unemployment benefit-that they are not allowed to do voluntary work while receiving the unemployment benefit or the Jobsearch allowance. A constituent of mine has recently written to me concerning her daughter. Her position as a shop assistant for a local grocery store was terminated. When she finished work, she applied for and received permission from the local branch of the National Parks and Wildlife Service to do voluntary work, with the aim in mind of proving her ability and working voluntarily until a position became vacant. I want to read a particular passage from this letter that really conveyed to me the fact that this is a person who desperately wants to work, is prepared to play her part in being an Australian and has the incentive to get out and earn. When her position was terminated-and I am not sure what the reasons were; it probably would have been the recession-her employer said:
If I had three workers with her willingness to work and in fact do the work as well, I wouldn't need any more staff.

This relates to one of our young people who works and works well. In this voluntary job with the National Parks and Wildlife Service she worked eight hours a day, five days a week doing jobs such as mowing, weeding, cleaning toilets and planting trees-very much demonstrating the community caring aspect. She was contented and happy within herself and looked forward to the day when she could apply for permanent work, starting as a labourer and hoping to work her way up the ladder within the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Her mother wrote:

During the period she did voluntary work, her bus fares to and from Airlie Beach cost $59, so we, as parents, advised her to apply for Job Search Allowance when her holiday pay finished in order that she would at least have her fares paid.

However, she was told by Commonwealth Employment Service, in my presence, that she was forbidden to do any voluntary work whilst receiving the allowance, and that she had to apply for two, and only two jobs per fortnight. I was shocked, to say the least, and pointed out that my daughter had shown some initiative by doing voluntary work and that in her opinion she was paying back the government for the pittance she would receive after we, her parents, were means tested.

The CES worker informed me that she would be unable to apply for her two jobs if doing other work, and if she was found to be doing same her allowance would be terminated immediately. How ridiculous! How long does it take one to apply for a position-40 hours (8 hrs x 5 days)?

I think we have to conclude that the whole situation is ridiculous. I believe that provided the person remains uncommitted to the business operators applying the voluntary work, provided the unemployed person is using the opportunity for training and continues to look for jobs elsewhere, there should be no reason why Jobsearch allowance or unemployment benefits should be jeopardised or why the current restrictions are imposed by Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). I find the suggestion that a person should be limited to only two applications for positions in any fortnight patently ridiculous; it restricts incentive, which was shown by this young lass and which is necessary to help Australia out of the current economic recession. I have today written to the manager of the CES at the point of contact in my electorate, but I would also appreciate the Minister's comment on this situation.

I mention this because it highlights one of the other deficiencies of the social security system. We are addressing a massive social security Bill and its rewording to bring simplicity and clear up a lot of the English expression; hopefully, we will then be able to work with it a lot better. In the two examples I have given-the deeming provisions and Jobsearch allowance-there is no similar simplicity in the administration and delivery of these services. What is needed is a more commonsense application. I have mentioned only two of the programs; I am sure that my colleagues could mention many more programs for income security which are muddled and, in some cases, stupid. The Minister should now address himself to this further simplicity and commonsense approach to the delivery of those services.

As I said, in the Senate the coalition will refer this Bill to an appropriate committee to get further clarification and understanding of it. Hopefully, by the time it passes through the Senate with whatever amendments are necessary, we will have a document from which we can work. I bring those other matters to the attention of the Minister for his attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to support the Social Security Bill, as I personally believe it is a cornerstone in the history of our country's social security system. Any legislation which seeks to keep pace with the changing needs of our society and adjust to those needs should be recommended.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the overall reform of our social security system, the Bill before us marks the first time ever that an Act has been almost completely rewritten to enable the more efficient running of the social security system. The 1947 Social Security Act allowed for the consolidation of five welfare related Acts which existed at the time. They were the Invalid and Old-age Pensions Act 1908-1946, the Child Endowment Act 1941-1945, the Widows' Pension Act 1942-1946, the Maternity Allowance Act 1912-1944 and the Unemployment and Sickness Benefits Act 1944. This is why the structure of the current Act is somewhat hard to follow. More than 100 amending pieces of legislation have been enacted since 1947 to enable governments and their policies to keep up with social changes. This has led to an Act containing a number of different styles and terms, which have at times been very confusing.

It was this Labor Government which consequently decided in March of 1988 to review the legislation encompassing the 1947 Act. Following the establishment of the legislation working party, assisted by a small team from the legal branch of the Department of Social Security, the structure and form of the Act was examined and reviewed and the rewriting of the Act into clear English was accomplished. The language contained in this Bill should therefore make the meaning of the legislation apparent and unclouded to the reader. It was obviously not an easy task to rewrite that 1947 Act. In doing so, the drafter has had to attempt to restate the rules in a simpler but equally accurate and precise way.

Where conflict arose between precision and simplicity, the drafter apparently has ensured that precision prevailed. Consequently some parts of the Act may still be a little confusing at first glance, but the reader aids now provided in the Act should help sort out any readability problems.

A few examples of clear English in this Bill are as follows: instead of `ascertained in accordance with the formula' the clear English version is `worked out using the formula'; instead of `commence', `start' or `begin' are used; and `pursuant to' or `in pursuance of' is replaced with `because of'. I believe that the rewriting of this Act in clear and understandable English marks yet another step in the much needed reform of Australia's social security system by our Hawke Labor Government.

When our Government came into power in 1983, the number of social security pensioners and beneficiaries was at a record level, mainly because of the recession which had begun in 1982 under the previous Liberal-National coalition Government. The Hawke Government then set about to amend the situation and to restructure the social security system to make it more accountable and effective.

Since 1983 the value of almost all pension and benefits payments has increased in real terms. Pensions are now more than 25.8 per cent of average weekly earnings, the highest proportion since 1949. Families needing income support are receiving greater real levels of payment than ever before. All of this has been achieved while simultaneously cutting social security expenditure as a proportion of the gross domestic product from 7.1 per cent to 5.7 per cent.

The Hawke Labor Government's overall strategy has been to achieve equity in the distribution of economic resources; equity of civil, legal and industrial rights; fair and equal access to essential services, such as housing, health and education; and the opportunity for participation by all in personal development, community life and decision making.

This Labor Government has endeavoured to maintain and improve real levels of support to ensure the adequacy of social security payments. It has encouraged entry into education, training and employment, and it has attempted to provide major assistance to low income families with children in order to tackle the problem of child poverty. It has taken the Hawke Labor Government to target social security programs to ensure that they assist those most in need and to introduce administrative reforms for greater effectiveness, efficiency and integrity.

Basically, this Government has had to find an acceptable balance between care and accountability under its social security portfolio, and I commend our present Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) for the work that he has done in achieving these goals. Through the expert management and restructuring of social security policy and administration begun under the former Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), we have achieved many of our objectives.

Australia now has one of the most efficient welfare systems in the world. Unlike systems in the United States and Europe, which are insurance based, the Australian social security system is means tested, targeted to those most in need and funded from general revenue. Achievements of the Hawke Labor Government in social justice policy have included real increases in the value of social security payments and the removal of significant poverty traps.

Another policy achievement since 1983 has been the closer integration of the social security, education and labour market system to provide better opportunities for people to move from dependence on social security provisions into employment.

The Department of Social Security has also endeavoured to become more efficient in its administration through the better use of technology and through increased support for staff serving the community. This has led to a number of changes and reforms being made to departmental administration and to social security programs. To aid these reforms, a social security review was established at the end of 1985 to target assistance where it was most needed; ensure greater adequacy of incomes; encourage and assist clients to enter or return to the work force or to provide for their own income security; and develop support for families, particularly those on low incomes.

A number of issue papers have resulted from the social security review, and action on five of those papers has already been taken. The major reforms as a consequence of these papers have been made basically in relation to families, the unemployed, sole parents and the aged. According to the booklet Reform of Social Security Policies and Administration 1983-1990, put out by the former Minister for Social Security following the 1989-90 Budget, `achievements within the social security portfolio over the last few years have been substantial and noteworthy'.

These achievements have included `significant increases in the rates of payment of pensions, benefits and allowances and increases in the free areas (to encourage self-help and financial independence among clients)'; `extensions of, and substantial increases in, rent assistance'; `increased coverage of the needs of particular client groups-for example, increased assistance to sole parents and the introduction of the Child Support Scheme and the Jobs, Education and Training program'; `significantly increased assistance to families-Family Allowance Supplement'-the supplement is being paid at much higher rates to many more people than was the old family income supplement; `increased rates of additional pension and benefits, in line with the FAS rates'; `rationalisation of outmoded provisions'; `an increase in the proportion of the labour force who are independent of the social security system'; and `indexation of family payments, rent assistance and the income tax free area'.

I must re-emphasise that all of these achievements have been accomplished at the same time as substantial restraint in social security expenditure has been achieved. Of particular interest to me and the constituents I represent have been the changes and the reforms to family assistance and child support programs. More people from my electorate claim family allowance and family allowance supplement-related benefits than do constituents of any one other electorate in Australia. Claims for these benefits outweigh claims for any other social security benefits by people in my electorate.

I am pleased to say that the Prospect electorate has the Fairfield social security regional office and shares part of the Merrylands and Cabramatta regional offices of social security. The Fairfield Social Security office alone had some 15,828 clients claiming family payments as of 14 September 1990. Consequently, the Government's achievements in the family assistance area are of great importance to my electorate. These achievements include the introduction of benchmarks of adequacy for child payments, brought in in 1989. These benchmarks increased family income support and are, I believe, a key part of the Government's initiatives on child poverty. The combined family allowance and family allowance supplement rates have consequently been set at 15 per cent of the married pension rate for children under 13 years of age and 20 per cent of the married pension rate for 13- to 15-year-old children. Family allowance rates were also increased substantially in July 1989, and all child payments were indexed from January 1990.

Nationally, some 3.8 million children in almost two million families around Australia benefit from family allowance. When one considers that statistic, it is an enormous assistance going out to those families by this Hawke Labor Government. More than one million children who come from low income families receive extra assistance from either the family allowance supplement or additional pension or benefit payments. Both payments are not taxed. Children of separated parents now benefit from more adequate and regular financial support from non-custodial parents as a result of the introduction of the child support scheme. This scheme helps ensure that the support of children is shared by the non-custodial parent.

Another important reform which has had a positive effect on low income families has been the significant increases in the rate of rent assistance to help those families since 1983. More than 640,000 pensioners, beneficiaries and low income earners benefit from this rent assistance. As from March of this year, rent assistance will also be indexed twice a year in line with the consumer price index.

It is reforms like these to our social security system which have really been of benefit to the Australian people. At last, through the efforts and the initiatives of the Hawke Labor Government we have seen rates of payment rise in real terms; incentives and opportunities for self-help enhanced; social security programs more fairly targeted; and administration tightened and improved.
According to the booklet Reform of Social Security Policies and Administration, the challenge now is to maintain the gains of reform. It states:

The integrity of and public support for the social security system must be protected, while measures aimed at providing greater effectiveness and administrative efficiency, including improved client service, continue to be pursued vigorously.

In the limited time I have left, I would like to commend the staff of the Department of Social Security employed in those three offices I mentioned: the Fairfield, Cabramatta and Merrylands social security offices. The statistics I have supplied to the House during this debate highlight the enormous pressure those staff face through the number of people seeking assistance. Like the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), I too have had a number of complaints in this regard, but at the same time I wish to congratulate publicly those staff on a job well done in such extenuating circumstances.

I believe that, at times, reform, assistance and help can be given to those staff members to help them put up with the pressure and provide them with the ability to go with the tide as those people come in. The electorate I represent is of such complexity with people from so many nations from all over the world that it certainly provides a challenge to those people working in the social security offices. I believe the reform in the Bill will go a long way towards assisting people to understand and appreciate the social security system itself.

I agree with the honourable member for Dawson that the Bill consists of 600-odd pages and over 2,000 pages of explanatory notes. I found it interesting reading. I also recollect that when I was in another place and another government that was trying to rewrite a separate Act of local government we faced trying times in attempting to bring plain English to fruition. I believe that this Bill is a benchmark in legislation. It is something that governments all over Australia must adopt. We cannot have the people we represent and the people who administer our legislation unable to understand and appreciate what Bills are about and what they mean. Too often we have had misinterpretation because of the language structure of a particular piece of legislation.

This is 1991 and we can no longer face the twenty-first century as a government unless we are prepared to restructure our legislation to enable people throughout Australia to understand it, and therefore appreciate it and know where we are heading. I commend the Bill to the House. I again commend not only our Minister on the implementation and the finalisation of this social security reform but also all the other people and committees that were involved in a long, intensive and very precise presentation of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was rather surprised to hear the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), in the context of this particular legislation, the Social Security Bill, go on at some length to trumpet the achievements of the Hawke Government in the area of social security. I would have thought that in talking about the achievements of the Hawke Government perhaps the only thing it will go down in history as having been remembered for is overloading the social security system to an enormous extent. This Government-induced recession that we are experiencing is forcing many thousands of Australians to turn-for the first time in their lives on many occasions-to welfare assistance. The honourable member talks about the Fairfield social security office. I imagine the queues there must be extending out the door and down the street to the extent that they will need to call the police soon to control the crowds.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the issue at hand, we are talking about a Bill which deals with some important matters. The Social Security Bill is extremely commendable as far as the Opposition is concerned in that it seeks to replace the current complexities of the original 1947 Act and the more than 100 subsequent amendments with a new layman's English version. We would expect-I think the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) has indicated-that this will pave the way for other pieces of legislation to be rewritten in a clear English style and format.

This Bill was released for public comment in February last year. That has made it a very interesting and successful experiment to popularise legislation, to bring it down to earth as it were and to make it meaningful and relevant to the average person. The Bill has the support of the Opposition in that it reasonably fulfils its objectives of making each individual provision as simple and easy to read as possible and arranging the provisions in a logical and easy to follow format.

However, although the objectives were not to change the existing legislation, I nevertheless believe that the Government has missed an excellent opportunity to update some other aspects of the 1947 Act. Recently a constituent contacted me regarding the fact that she was on the invalid pension and her husband was unable to receive a spouse's pension. In the case of a male invalid pensioner, his wife is automatically entitled to a spouse's pension. In this case, however, despite the fact that she was the main breadwinner for the family before her illness, her husband could only get a carer's pension. The carer's pension requires a report from the doctor giving details of the type of personal care being given to the pensioner by the carer.

The implication of the comment here on the respective roles of men and women, vis-a-vis who is actually caring for the other, is out of step with society today. My constituent, quite rightly I believe, finds it demeaning to have to go to her doctor to furnish a report regularly when male invalid pensioners are not subject to the same treatment. I find it incredible that in this day and age, when governments across the country have implemented laws to prevent sexual discrimination in the workplace, such a situation can continue to exist within the Social Security Act.

I wrote to the Minister for Social Security to bring this particular anomaly to his attention and to ask him to seek to remedy the situation expeditiously. I received a reply from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), in which he said:
I do understand your constituent's concerns that a ``spouses pension'' is not payable to her husband.

It is true that a number of the provisions of the Social Security Act involve different treatment of men and women. This situation is a reflection of the different community expectations about the role of women in society and the workforce which prevailed when the particular forms of assistance were introduced.
With the growing participation of women in the workforce, these provisions may seem as inconsistent with the aim of promoting equality between the sexes.
In fact, the Parliamentary Secretary goes on to say:
. . . the Government has already introduced a number of changes in recent years to restructure the social security system so that it meets the needs of the 1990's.

As a result of changes introduced on 1 July 1987 widows Class B pension is gradually being phased out and widows pension and sole parents pension are no longer available to women once their children turn 16. In addition, discrimination has been removed from income support arrangements for sole parents. On 1 March 1989, widows pension and supporting parents pension were merged into a new pension called sole parents pension. This new pension gives the same assistance to both male and female sole parents.
A new Widowed Persons Allowance which does not discriminate on the basis of age or sex has already been introduced. The Widowed Persons Allowance may be paid for 12 weeks to eligible men and women--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has not got to the question yet.
—He has not got to the question yet; in fact, he has complicated the question to such an extent that nobody would understand what he is actually trying to say. Anyway, I will finish what he does say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Widowed Persons Allowance may be paid for 12 weeks to eligible men and women who are newly widowed and who do not have a child which would qualify them for a sole parents pension.
Finally he makes this very perceptive comment:

There is clearly a need to keep the Social Security Act under review and the issue of a ``spouses pension'' will be considered in the context of options for broader redevelopment of income support programs.

One would need to read that letter with a dictionary on hand and would need to have a fairly detailed understanding of what it is all about, because the answer is extremely confusing. It did not turn out to be terribly helpful at all. We wonder why people are confused. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), in his remarks, was pointing to the complexities of the system. Obviously the problems of the system go way beyond semantics.

The Bill before us deals with semantics. We recognise the importance of having clear and understandable legislation, but the sort of problems that we daily encounter in our electorate offices are not so much matters of semantics as matters of practice and principle. This particular instance that I brought to the attention of the House today involving a constituent of mine points out a matter of fairly fundamental sexual discrimination and it really goes very much to the core of the system.

The honourable member for Dawson alluded to some of the changes that have been made to the system. As if the system was not already complex enough, with the changes being introduced and implemented on top of changes, which has gone on and on, it has grown like Topsy to the point where we almost need a university course to understand the social security system. Of course, with the deeming provisions that the Government has inflicted on the community, particularly pensioners, it has delivered almost the coup de grace. Those provisions have totally confused everybody and upset people-to a large extent, unnecessarily.

The Minister has been shown that the announced changes are flawed in a number of important respects. I will bring them to the attention of the House, and there are a number of them. The $2,000 threshold is too low to provide pensioners with an adequate level of emergency funds; the flat threshold implies that two can live as cheaply as one, yet the rest of the social security system is totally inconsistent with that because it proceeds on exactly the opposite basis; and the flat rate of 10 per cent is too high and could force pensioners into risky non-bank investments about which they know very little.

In response to my correspondence and other members' correspondence, the Minister has provided a list of banks which will offer 10 per cent per annum interest. I passed on some of that information to pensioners who had requested it and they found out that there were some ridiculous stipulations. For instance, most of the banks require a minimum transaction of $500. Assuming a pensioner has to pay out a $50 account, he or she would have to then effectively circumvent the law in some way by withdrawing a bigger amount and then re-banking the balance. In other words, that person would have to go to a whole lot of trouble to engage in what should have been a very simple operation. None of the major banks presently offers 10 per cent at call on amounts just over $2,000. Further, there is no announced intention to allow the Minister to vary the interest rate.

We have heard that interest rates are coming down and we have been told they are coming down fairly quickly, yet the Minister has made no mention about reducing the deeming rate of 10 per cent. He indicated that he would keep the matter under consideration, but so far he has not done so. There are a number of important unanswered questions about the deeming provisions, particularly technical questions relating to interest rates. Is the interest rate to be a nominal or an effective rate? What if bank account balances fluctuate around the $2,000 mark? How many forms will pensioners have to fill in? We really do put pensioners to an enormous amount of trouble.

A case was recently brought to my attention where a pensioner went into her bank to adjust her affairs to comply with the Government's requirements. Even though she had been a customer of the particular bank for many years, for one reason or another she needed to open a new account. She was an elderly lady and she was told that she had to provide all sorts of information in order to score the necessary points to be able to open a new account. It was actually this lady's son who rang me. He said, `My mother is over 80 and she has great difficulty coming to grips with all these changes'. One can imagine the difficulties that this lady faced when the bank asked for documents such as a birth certificate and other things so that she could score 100 points, simply to open a new account at the bank in which she had been a customer for probably 30 or 40 years. So there are enormous complications in the social security system.

This legislation is important because it deals with simplification of language. However, surely the basic concern ought to be with a considerable simplification of the social security system, which has grown to the point where it is almost out of control. People, particularly pensioners who have been affected so adversely by recent changes to the legislation, have great difficulty in understanding what is going on.

To return to the Bill that we are considering today, I would have thought that the modernisation of the text-that is really all we are talking about, strictly speaking-might have provided the perfect opportunity for the Government to bring the legislation in line with existing social values. I refer specifically here to sexual discrimination. I am not talking about token changes to the text of legislation to avoid genderspeak. We have seen plenty of examples of that in recent times and the approach to genderspeak has gone way over the top. We are nevertheless talking about the need for legislation to treat men and women consistently and equally as they are regarded in society today. I do not believe that that ought to be difficult to do. We need to recognise that men and women are equal under the law and they ought to be treated that way.

I do not believe that the changes that we are talking about would require a great policy adjustment on the part of the Government. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security makes quite clear in his letter to me, the Government is committed to ridding the Act of sexual discrimination.

I am sure that such a basic and commonsense adjustment could have been made in rewriting the Act. I find it incredible that this new, updated rewriting is actually perpetuating the old gender roles that clearly should not have any place in legislation today. I urge the Government to look at rectifying these problems with appropriate legislation as soon as possible.

I understand that one of the advantages of the new format is that it will be easier to make clear changes. Notwithstanding many of the criticisms that can be levelled-and I am sure will be levelled-in this debate at the social security system, we nevertheless do welcome this particular Bill, and in fact we would encourage the Government to embark on a process of rewriting other Acts in a similar fashion in order that legislation can be read and understood easily by common people-such as politicians, I suppose. We are the ones, probably the only ones--

TALK.START.PARA: —Non-lawyer politicians.

—Non-lawyer politicians, as the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories correctly says, with the greatest respect to my colleague, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), who is here at the table. Those of us who are not lawyers have the greatest difficulty in understanding what this legislation is saying on many occasions. We do find that this new Act before us is understandable and the Government is to be commended for having done that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting and important to note that the Bill has gained the support of the Department of Social Security, the Welfare Rights Union and other groups. That is indeed very heartening. The Opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the legislation before us today is a rewrite of the Social Security Act 1947 and more than 100 pieces of amending legislation that have occurred since then.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1947 Act brought into a consolidated form five welfare related Acts that were in existence at that time, they being the Invalid and Old-age Pensions Act 1908-46, the Child Endowment Act 1941-45, the Widows' Pension Act 1942-46, the Maternity Allowance Act 1912-44, and the Unemployment and Sickness Benefits Act 1944.

It might be pertinent to have a look at the nature of our social security system at the time of the consolidation of the Act in 1947. If we go back to 1908, the Invalid and Old-age Pensions Act was passed under pressure from the Labor Party by the Deakin Government. During the period 1941-1949, Federal Labor governments made significant advances in the provision of welfare services. In 1942 the widows' pension was instigated; in 1943 funeral benefits; in 1943 again there was an expansion of maternity benefits; and in 1944 there was the introduction of unemployment and sickness benefits. In 1946 the Chifley Government consolidated many of these achievements by introducing a proposal to alter section 51 of the Constitution to authorise the Federal Government to provide a wide range of social services, which was overwhelmingly supported by the Australian people. So our social security system is very much seen as a Commonwealth role.

As has been said, in revising the Social Security Act, the opportunity has been taken to put it in plain English terms. I just wish to touch on the concept of the conversion of legislation to plain English. For some time I have been interested in the report of the Law Reform Commission of Victoria entitled Plain English and the Law. In that report the question is posed: why is plain English important? I quote from that report:

Plain English in legislation is important because it helps members of the public to comply with their legal obligations and to obtain benefits to which they are entitled. Laws and documents should not be drafted on the assumption that a trained lawyer will be available to interpret them. Plain English in legislation is also important because it saves money. Poorly drafted laws impose costs on those who administer them and on those whose conduct they are intended to control. Time is wasted in trying to understand them. Lawyers have to be employed to interpret them.
That is one of the problems with much of the legislation that is considered here.

I was interested in the byplay that occurred towards the end of the speech of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). Again, with due respect to not only the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), but also the shadow Minister at the table, it should not be that only our legal colleagues in this chamber are able to understand the type of legislation that we are discussing.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't understand it.

—Yes! And that is one of the more important aspects of reviewing our legislation: to enable us as parliamentarians to have a greater opportunity for a clear understanding of what it is that we are discussing. In the context of this Social Security Bill, it is important that those at whom these pieces of legislation are aimed should also have the ability to understand what is being considered. Before entering this place I worked in the Public Service. One of the more intriguing aspects of the Public Service is the degree of specialisation that can occur. People become specialists in areas of legislation, and there is considerable compartmentalisation because of that. As people develop-through work experience-a knowledge of the relevant piece of legislation, instead of acquiring a broader knowledge of what is occurring, their knowledge becomes more defined and more focused. I think that is quite unfortunate, because in the conduct of business with members of the public it often leads to what appears to be buck-passing but what is really a matter of referral to somebody who has that expert knowledge. Perhaps if we come to terms with the way in which we couch our legislation there will not be that need, and there will not be that apparent degree of chopping and changing when people contact departments.

SPEECH.PARA: In the report of the Law Reform Commission of Victoria a study by Coopers and Lybrand is referred to. The study, into the type of language employed in forms used by the United Kingdom Department of Health and Social Security, identified a number of varieties of costs that occurred because of the lack of clarity in those forms. Firstly, there was the cost to the Department, which included staff time for interviews, telephone calls, visits, postage, telephone, stationery, travel and subsistence. Then there was the cost to respondents as a result of the additional time spent on the interviews that resulted from the forms, and there were also the costs to employers of the respondents because of the time that was taken away from work in explaining what might have been more simply put in the information given in the forms that were provided by the Department.

I know that a lot of advances have been made, especially in the Department of Social Security, in looking at the types of forms that are used. Indeed, there has been a great advance in the style of letters which are sent out by the Department. I believe that the Parliamentary Secretary still has an ongoing review of those matters. I think that that is very important, because not only should there be precision when people need to know their rights, but also when a decision is made on the basis of a claim that they put to the Department, that should be explained to them in the clearest possible terms so that they have an understanding of what is really going on.

In the Law Reform Commission's report a condemnation of the Social Security Act 1947 by the then chairperson of the Victorian Division of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, Mr Chris Loorham, is quoted. In November 1986 he had this to say:

Other Parliaments in Australia seem to be able to pass or amend legislation in a manner that is at least intelligible to well educated persons. It is unfortunate that the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia allows legislation such as the Social Security Act 1947 to remain on the statute books which is almost totally unintelligible to anyone. The fact that this Act directly touches the lives of every person belonging to this country gives the Tribunal even greater cause for concern. The current state of this most important Act can only be described as a national disgrace.

With this legislation we have an opportunity to rectify such a national disgrace. Given the bipartisan comments that have been made in this debate and the comments of relevant community groups during the period of consultation, I think we have had some success in bringing about that type of change in the style of the legislation.

As I said, much legislation appears to be shrouded in legal mystique-legal mumbo jumbo. Sometimes when there is debate about the relevance of plain English, the legal fraternity argues that because our law is based on precedent there is some danger in plain English. One of the questions that is asked is whether plain English legislation is incompatible with precision. Some relevant comments have been made about that. Often it is not the precision and clarity of the written word that is at fault; rather, it is the lack of clarity and precision of the underlying policy the legislation tries to put in place.

I think it is incumbent on us, as we try to achieve plain English legislation, to understand the need for clarity and precision in the underlying policy. I believe there is an understanding of that need for a clear underlying policy base in the legislation before us today. The problem does not relate just to language. This legislation is a clear example that the problem is not merely a matter of words. In the structure and format of the legislation there is an attempt to make it, in the technological jargon, user friendly. I think that is important.

If we had taken as a basis the 1947 Act and subsequent amending legislation and tried merely to change the words, we still would have been left with the same problems. Inevitably, it would have been a headache trying to wend one's way through the many pages of the legislation. That is another important aspect of the exercise that has culminated in the Bill presently before the House.

As I said, one of the major achievements has been to lessen the complexity of the policies that are put in place by the legislation. Examples have been cited of the changes that have been made which give some indication of the way in which the legislation attempts to explain better what is intended. For example, the old subsection 158 (1) states:
The grant or payment of a pension under Part 4 shall not be made except upon the making of a claim for that pension.
This is to be replaced by the new subclause 48 (1), which states:
A person who wants to be granted an age pension must make a proper claim for that pension.
I think that illustrates what has occurred in this exercise and gives one some hope that it will achieve the goal that has been set for this legislation.

I want to talk not only about the change in the legislation but also about the change in attitude in the social security area in the life of the Hawke Government. As a simple illustration, the general philosophy that abounded in the Public Service was that, if somebody wanted to front up to a department such as Social Security to make a claim, that person should have some knowledge of his or her entitlements; it was not the role of the department to explain the opportunities that might be open to that person. Fortunately, there has been a refreshing change in that attitude. Now departments see as one of their responsibilities a requirement to explain fully to potential clients the opportunities available to them. I think it is important that the community should have an expectation that people have a right to knowledge of what is available to them.

There have been a number of real achievements in the benefits available to the community. There have been real increases in the value of benefits and significant poverty traps have been removed. There has been better targeting of payments, and there have been moves to ensure that relevant payments are indexed. I think we can all remember how in the past welfare and social service payments were used as political footballs. In the 23 Budgets brought down between 1949 and 1972, seven preceded an election by less than six months. In those Budgets that preceded an election by less than six months, the average increase in the standard age pension was $1.04. In the other 16 Budgets, the average increase was 53c-just over half of that election Budget amount. With the indexation of benefits we have moved away from that tinkering with the system. That is another positive step because it moves important benefits away from the direct political arena.

Another illustration of the vast attitudinal change taking place concerns the linkages between and the integration across different departments and agencies. For example, there is a close integration of the social security system, the labour market system and our education system. Programs such as jobs, education and training, or JET, and Newstart have been very important. It is now seen that income support is not the only thing we should be looking at. We should not think that because we provide an adequate level of income support the job has been well done. If we are trying to move to an active society in which we are able to increase the opportunities that are available to all, we should give assistance across the board. We must realise that some assistance can be even more meaningful than mere income support.

It is a little disappointing to see that some of the policy changes contemplated by the Opposition include proposals that apparently would lead to the fragmentation of the coordination we have been able to achieve. I refer to the one-line statements the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has made about voucher systems for health care, for example, and other things. I think it was in October 1990 that the Opposition suggested that if it was elected to government it would dismantle the Department of Social Security and use non-government agencies to make payments. That caused a great degree of debate and criticism throughout the community. I do not think it would have led to what was intended; that is, some degree of efficiency and, therefore, some degree of saving in the system.

It really gives me no great pleasure to note that only three Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries-Portugal, Japan and America-outlay less money than we do on social expenditure; that is, on health education, welfare services and income support. I believe that is not something that one should trumpet. Perhaps, as a society, we need to look more closely at what expenditure we provide and perhaps the level could be greater. It irks me that when we have a debate in the community there is an apparent belief that the impost on the public purse is even greater. I find that most unfortunate. If we are going to have this type of debate let us be fair about it, let us understand what the real levels of expenditure are and let us understand that the public sector is asked to make only a modest contribution in the area of social expenditure.

In conclusion, I am pleased to join with all honourable members who have spoken so far in this debate in this place in support of this legislation. I think this is a major step forward. Hopefully, other pieces of legislation will be treated in the same manner. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) mentioned the income tax legislation and I totally agree with him that we should be looking at making it more understandable. I conclude with the remarks made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) when he circulated the pro forma legislation that `Social justice demands that it be an accessible piece of legislation'--
