SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was good to hear the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) getting his last few words in. Mr Deputy Speaker, I accept, on his behalf, the little bit of tolerance you extended to him. Although there is unanimity in the belief that a total review of the Social Security Act is long overdue, especially for the need of its rewrite in plain English, I have to disagree with some of the previous speakers on the other side and say that, even though there are a number of cornerstones in the Social Security Bill which is before us in terms of its revision and, particularly, the rewrite-and one speaker actually referred to it as a cornerstone-in many ways it is actually a roadblock. I will elaborate a little on that point during the course of my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major difficulties with any social security legislation which is in place is, of course, the enormous cost to the taxpayer, particularly when these huge benefits are being met by the taxpayer. There ought to be a lot of plain thinking as to whether so much money should be paid out or some other methods should be exercised in order to perhaps reduce the need to pay out so much money in certain areas of social security.

`Caesar's war' on poverty-and we have certainly heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talking a lot about poverty over the years, particularly with regard to child poverty-is a no-win situation. Charles Murray, writing in his book entitled Losing Ground, asserts correctly that Federal programs, and particularly many social security programs over the past, have not helped but have, indeed, by and large, compounded the welfare problems. Milton Friedman said:
If you pay people to be poor, they will be poor.

I mention this because it does not matter how much attention we pay to this or how much we talk about the fact that a great deal of work has gone into revamping and revising this Act that we are debating here today, the fact remains that while these policies exist, as I mentioned earlier and as Milton Friedman said, when one pays poor people to be poor, they will be poor. His blunt assessment may have been based on the facts which show that welfare programs:
. . . are laced with incentives which encourage long term dependency. Welfare often offers more useable income than many jobs available.

In my own electorate, people have told me more often than I care to remember that they do not go out and look for work. Of course, some people do go out and look for work, because the newer provisions for receiving unemployment benefits have made it a requirement that people do make a greater effort to find work and they have to certify that in their fortnightly or weekly forms before they get their payment. Some people do take jobs, but they stay in them for only a matter of days because they find that being on welfare payments and receiving unemployment benefits is better for them and they do not have to work. A lot of plain thinking is needed on the part of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and the Government in this regard in order to overcome these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Newstart is about.
—We are looking at that in other areas of the legislation which is before the Parliament. As we are talking about plain English, it is really plain stupidity to allow this kind of thing to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other areas which I think need attention in order to save funding. Office efficiency is one such area. I note that the Strat plan has been introduced into social security offices Australia-wide and this has certainly been a very good thing; some very good savings have been made. The plan is a good example of plain efficiency-if I can commend positively the Department of Social Security in that regard. In my own electorate, even though the efficiency of the officers and of the people who work there has been good-I cannot complain about the courtesy of the officers in my local offices-over the years there have been some very serious problems with regard to the general office management. I put on record the fact that I have had great concerns about my local offices and I have taken action-which, sadly, has not received the most expeditious attention-with regard to sorting out the difficulties and problems experienced in them.

The Department needs to issue in the offices some plain English rules on good conduct for employees which are effective and which are not rendered ineffective by the fact that the unions operating in those offices have an enormous amount of influence. That influence affects the welfare and well-being of the employees in those offices. I do not want to refer to any office in particular, but I have drawn the attention of the Minister to offices in my own electorate which have very serious problems in this regard. So we do need some plain, straight-out, good, strong actions from the Minister and from the hierarchy in the State in order to come to grips with those problems. I believe, and I hope, that the current action which is being taken will overcome those problems, although we have a great deal of inertia on the part of the local union body.

I also want to highlight the fact that the Social Security Bill, however good it may be now in terms of its having been rewritten and smoothed out in lots of areas, particularly with regard to its terminology, still involves huge payouts. Almost a third of the national budget is devoted to social security payouts. We hear a lot about this Parliament House costing the taxpayer so much money, a billion dollars or a little over, and yet relentlessly we are paying out the equivalent of 25 fully-furnished new Parliament Houses each year just on welfare payments.

I refer to just one aspect of payments. As a result of marriage breakdown, every year we are relentlessly paying out the equivalent of two fully-furnished new Parliament Houses just to prop up families following marriage failure. It can be argued that that is a good thing, and some people might ask what is wrong with that. The criticism is that whilst that payment is equivalent to around $500 per Australian family, paid out relentlessly every year in support of these families that have had marriage failures or similar problems, until recently we have been paying only around 30c or 40c per family per year to stop these problems occurring.

It always worries me that the Government continuously pays out these huge sums of money in these welfare areas and yet is paying scant attention to allocating funds to stop these tremendous drains on our revenue. For example, why do we not pay $50m towards marriage counselling and marriage education programs? I know there have been increases in the last Budget in this area, and I commend the Government for that, but it is not nearly enough. If we allocated those funds, we would have savings of maybe $300m or $400m. Research shows us that 65 per cent of marriages fail because of benign neglect, not because of malicious intent. We really ought to stop and think about that.

When we look at our communities to see what sort of education programs the Department of Social Security, for example, or other government bodies may be undertaking to stop this marriage breakdown from happening, we find that they are very scant. As I said, until recent years we spent only 25c per family on marriage education. That, to me, was plain stupidity. We ought to stop and think about these areas and, rather than spend a lot of time talking about how good the Act is, we ought to come to grips with doing something to make sure that we stop the horses from bolting in the first place.

We ought to have marriage education programs in our schools for the senior years, for example, so that the pitfalls and difficulties and problems that we have to cope with in marriage, which lead to tremendous social security payouts, are dramatically reduced. That is something the Minister ought to take on for consideration. Whilst he espouses the efficacy of this new Bill because of its plain English and the way it smoothes off some of the edges and so on, he ought to take on board the need for the Government generally to get involved in programs that will encourage more plain lifestyles, that are going to encourage families to stay together rather than find it more attractive to have members leave the household, and so on. I issue that plain and obvious challenge to the Government.

With regard to the issue of plain living, I want to quote a few points from an article concerning a document produced by the International Consultation on Simple Lifestyle, following a conference in 1980. It issued An Evangelical Commitment to Simple Lifestyle, of nine paragraphs, which I think deserves careful study by anybody. Paragraph 5 is entitled `Personal Lifestyle'. In talking about this simplicity and this call for plainer living it includes a general resolve to `renounce waste and oppose extravagance in personal living, clothing and housing, travel and church buildings'.

But this betrays no negative asceticism-and when honourable members read it they will find that out. On the contrary, it picks up from Dr Donald Sider's paper Living More Simply for Evangelism and Justice a number of important distinctions. The article states:

We also accept the distinction between necessities and luxuries, creative hobbies and empty status symbols, modesty and vanity, occasional celebrations and normal routine and between the service of God and slavery to fashion.

The point is that simple or plain living is not incompatible with carefree enjoyment. I make this point on the basis that it is something that we can all consider, apart from being something that I am commending that the Government might promote in our community. The article continues:
The principle of generosity is clear too.
Mr Speaker prayed this morning seeking guidance. It is probably appropriate to mention that the article says that in 1 John 3.17 we find:
If anyone has material possessions, and sees his brother in need, but has no pity on him, how can the love of God be in him?

That is a pretty good text for us and our Australian communities to take on board bearing in mind the tremendous problems being confronted by the rural industries. We need to take a harder look at all those people around us who are having great difficulty and wherever we possibly can, through our own generosity and practical help, come to grips with their problems and help them in their great difficulties. This article-and this is also relevant to the Speaker's prayer-states:
Our God is a generous God. If his love indwells us, we shall relate what we `have' (possessions) to what we `see' (need) and take action.

May God help us to simplify our lifestyle, grow in generosity, and live in contentment so that the demands that are put upon the Government in terms of social security payouts and the huge debt to society, to the taxpayer, may be dramatically reduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Bill does not broach new policy initiatives or new spending outcomes. It basically involves a process of rewriting a number of pieces of legislation to put them into language that people can easily understand and can follow when seeking further information. As such, it is a milestone in the legislative history of the parliaments of Australia, including this Parliament, because at last we have a Bill that ordinary Australians can read and understand, and actually find information in. I am only new to this Parliament so the process of formulating legislation is a reasonably new skill that I am trying to come to grips with, and I have found it increasingly difficult, because I am not a lawyer, to understand a lot of the legalese within which the legislation is written.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to say that this Social Security Bill is for me the end of a conspiracy that has dominated this nation for 90 years, a conspiracy run and dominated by lawyers-I see my friend the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) smiling at me, because he is a lawyer-to keep legislation as confusing as possible. In that way lawyers can maintain full employment within the legal profession, because none of the ordinary citizens in the community-and I include myself in that, because by profession I am a teacher and not a lawyer-has any chance of understanding legislation. I think that is the way the lawyers want it to be, because it makes sure that they keep their jobs.

But at last we have broken that conspiracy. This process was initiated by the former Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), and was continued by the current Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson). We have a system under which the legislation is written in such a way that a person can find the relevant information without having to seek a whole series of advisers or advocates to put that information into a form that that person can understand. I think that is very important.

I echo the sentiments that were expressed by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and other speakers in this chamber today who have indicated that this process should not stop with social security but should be adopted by a number of other departments and Ministers. The honourable member for Dawson has already mentioned the tax laws, and I wholeheartedly agree with him. They comprise an incredibly complex series of Acts and regulations and most people have no chance of trying to understand them. I suppose that adds to the conspiracy theory-a conspiracy is being engaged in by accountants to keep them in full employment.

I would add a number of other departments which could pick up this practice that has been adopted by the past and present Ministers for Social Security. I would recommend to my colleagues such as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) that the process that has been adopted by the Department of Social Security in reviewing its legislation be adopted in reviewing the Austudy requirements. I have been involved in a parliamentary committee of inquiry into Austudy and, although the report of that committee has not been brought down yet, I know that one of the clear impressions that all members from both sides of the House have about the Austudy regulations is that they are extremely confusing, complex and difficult. I am sure all honourable members have had innumerable constituents coming into their offices seeking some clarification of their entitlements and of what the 94 questions on the Austudy form really mean. That is another department that could adopt this strategy.

Other departments that I think could pick up this process include the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. My office received the immigration regulations a couple of months ago; we almost had to have a moving van to bring them into the office because they were so huge, so complex and so difficult to understand. I think it would help if that Department adopted a rewrite of its legislation to bring together a consolidation of all the amendments that have been passed over the years and to rewrite the legislation into easily understood language that ordinary human beings, not just lawyers, can understand.

The rewriting of this Bill is very important for a lot of Australians, because the Department of Social Security provides services and support to over one million Australians. Therefore, over one million Australians are reliant on an understanding of the Bill-what it means; what their entitlements are; whether they are eligible for certain things; whether they have breached the guidelines; or whether, when they increase their income in some way or change their financial arrangements, they will be breaching the laws. A lot of people are affected by this legislation, and that is why it is a very important Bill. I think it is probably good that it was the Department of Social Security which adopted it first.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four million.

—Four million Australians? The honourable member for Bowman has corrected me; over four million Australians are affected by social security-which probably makes the Bill even more important. It is important that those people do not inadvertently breach regulations or provisions of Acts because they just do not understand them. This Bill has done a lot to ensure that that does not occur.

SPEECH.PARA: The structure of the Bill is very important. When the Department decided to undertake this redrafting of all its legislation, it had two main aims. The first was to make each provision as simple and as easy to read as possible and the second was to make the arrangement of the provisions in the Act logical and easy to follow. As a result, certain drafting principles were followed so that people could easily turn to the front of the Bill, find out what section they were interested in, what part they needed information on, and find the relevant information very quickly without having to delve right through the whole Bill before they found the section that they were interested in. That has been a very important part of this process. People can now have access to the relevant information without having to spend hours reading through the whole Bill.

There are a number of other improvements and innovations in the Bill that I think should be repeated by other departments. First of all, method statements have been used to itemise the steps involved in rate calculations or in determining whether someone is entitled to a social security provision. Tables have been used instead of writing out the formulae and provisions in detail in words. Some provisions are there to set the scene by explaining very broadly how provisions work and examples are listed to demonstrate the complexity of some provisions. And cross-references have been used throughout the legislation to ensure people can find all the relevant bits that might affect them in determining whether they are eligible for social security benefits and what regulations will affect them in the implementation of those social security benefits.

The language is also very important-not just in the structure of the Bill but also in the removal by the drafters of a lot of very complex words and the insertion of simple words in their place. There are still a few obscure words-I suppose the lawyers could not have them totally removed-but most of the obscure legalese has been removed and replaced with words which are in common usage. That is also very important.

Most of the complex and complicated series of laws that exist in this country make the following of the law very difficult for ordinary citizens. The Department of Social Security has set the way in removing those things by improving the whole structure of the Bill.

Another important feature that the honourable member for Dawson mentioned, and which has also been drawn to my attention, is the fact that the vast majority of community groups and lobby groups involved in the social security industry are very supportive of this rewrite. They believe it has gone a long way towards making their job easier, and hopefully it will reduce the growth industry that we have within the social welfare area of that advocacy industry which has been built up because ordinary people could not follow what the terms of the legislation were and what conditions applied. Perhaps that will mean that that growth industry will suffer some form of decline in future years.

This Bill also represents a continuing part of the process of improved efficiency in the operation of the Department of Social Security. I think that is an important issue for us to raise, because, over the last eight years of this Government, there has been an ongoing process of introducing much improved efficiency in the management and operation of the Department of Social Security.

The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) raised a couple of points with regard to his local offices of the Department of Social Security. In his view, some of the offices do not necessarily work as efficiently or courteously as they might. All of us as members of parliament have constituents come in to see us from time to time with complaints-some of them quite legitimate-about the treatment they have received in their Department of Social Security office. The fact that occasionally problems do occur is a reflection of the fact that a large volume of people go through that office. However, when I as a member of parliament have a complaint to raise about an office of the Department of Social Security, I contact the manager of that particular office and outline my concern. I have found that that complaint or problem is acted on promptly and efficiently; I get a very good response back. If the Department finds that that particular office is at fault and that something it has done has resulted in some problem for a constituent, it is very quick to rectify the matter, apologise and try to make sure that it fixes the matter up. I have nothing but praise for the Department of Social Security officers in my electorate because I think they do a wonderful job.

As we have already indicated, there are millions of people involved in the receipt of social security benefits, so of course problems will arise from time to time. The people in that office are busy; they all have a lot of people and issues to deal with; they also have to grapple with a range of language difficulties and literacy problems among the people with whom they are dealing; and, of course, often misunderstandings or misinterpretations by constituents or by clerical staff occur within the Department. But it is important that within the Department of Social Security there is a process in place whereby, if a problem arises where obviously a mistake has been made, officers act quickly and compassionately to fix it, and they do not attempt to stonewall or to try to justify their own inaction in some way which frustrates the needs of the constituent. I think that is very important. As a Federal member of parliament who has a large social security clientele in my electorate, it is extremely important that I am able to have that access and that quick response. So I am pleased to report that my officers do work very well in that regard.

The other point that I raise is that some of the complaints or comments that have been made by honourable members, particularly those opposite, about the Department of Social Security are based more on an ideological position rather than a factual analysis of the situation. The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) raised the reported suggestions of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) about what he would do to the Department of Social Security should he ever become the Prime Minister of this country. These suggestions were made late last year. The Leader of the Opposition indicated that it would be his policy that the Department of Social Security would be abolished and that much of its services would be privatised or farmed out to the private sector. He based his suggestion that this should occur on some alleged inefficiencies in the delivery of services by the Department of Social Security.

But if one looks objectively at the facts relating to the Department, one finds that there are very few inefficiencies. In fact, the Department of Social Security is one of the most efficient departments in the whole Public Service. I draw attention to the fact that the Department's administrative costs represent only 3.5 per cent of all outlays, and that is an outstanding achievement. That is an indication of very good efficiency, particularly when more than four million people are in receipt of benefits every fortnight.

The other important thing is that out of 140 million payments that the Department processes each year, 99.9 per cent arrive on time at the correct address. That is a very good measure of the efficiency and productivity of officers in the Department. So, when one hears talk about breaking up this monolith called the Department of Social Security and introducing great efficiencies by privatising, one should really look at what is behind those suggestions and understand that it is a purely ideological position-not one based on any fair and objective assessment of the current services that are provided by that Department.

I now raise briefly one other issue that has been to the forefront of the attention of the public in the last few months with relevance to social security-although also it is not exactly covered in this Bill-and that is the question of deeming provisions for pensioners, which were introduced in the last Budget and which come into force from 1 March this year. There has been a lot of concern expressed throughout the country about the provisions of deeming, and most of those concerns have been based on a lack of understanding of what the impact will be and of who will be affected. A number of people have utilised this issue to pursue personal political viewpoints rather than an objective analysis of what the effect of deeming provisions will be.

I have been concerned about that because many comments that have been made, particularly in the Brisbane media, have caused a lot of concern and misunderstandings amongst my constituents. They have rightfully been very upset because they view the deeming provisions as having a much worse impact than they will in reality.

I think it is important that when we talk about provisions such as social security or the changes that may be occurring in that area, we understand who we are dealing with and what impact rumours and shock tactics will have on those people. Most of the people we are talking about are aged pensioners or ill and infirm people. They react very quickly when they think that some major change that will adversely affect them is coming into place. It causes them great fear, hardship and distress, because they have their affairs arranged in a certain way and they fear that if there is a change made it will have some dreadful adverse effect of them. They find it difficult to understand the complexities of a lot of the changes that are introduced.

Unfortunately, some people in the Brisbane media have played on those fears and have spread a whole series of rumours and innuendos about the impact of deeming, which has caused a lot of concern amongst constituents in my electorate. The electorate of Moreton has a significant aged population. It is one of the oldest electorates by age profile in Australia. Therefore, the interests of pensioners are very much paramount to me.

Since the introduction of the Budget and the announcement of the deeming provisions, I have spent many months discussing these issues with the Minister for Social Security and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security to raise my concerns and the concerns of my constituents and to make sure that their concerns have been looked at and have been addressed. A lot of the concerns of my constituents, in fact 99.9 per cent of them, have been picked up and recognised. In fact, most of them are unfounded because the provisions of the deeming legislation will not affect them in the way that they think.

The vast majority of pensioners in the electorate of Moreton will not be affected by deeming. In fact they will be financially better off by deeming because they will be earning more money by putting their money in accounts that earn 10 per cent or more rather than leaving it in bank accounts that earn very little money.

The one issue that has been affecting us in Brisbane is the rates situation. Some people, if they earn more than the income limits, will have some of their pension cut and then may face a loss of rates discounts by the Brisbane City Council or other local government authorities in Queensland. That issue has been taken up by the Government with those local government authorities on innumerable occasions. We have attempted to negotiate a better deal, and the ball is very much in the court of the local government authorities themselves. They have the responsibility to look at their provisions for the introduction of rates discounts for pensioners and to try to pick up those concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is up to Sallyanne.

—That is right. I think the Leader of the Brisbane City Council, Alderman Sallyanne Atkinson, has a responsibility to respond to those needs, to change the rates discounts provided to pensioners in the Brisbane city area to bring them into line with the rest of the country, which provides rates discounts provided that one has a health benefits card, not just on the basis of whether one is a full pensioner or not.

SPEECH.PARA: To sum up, I think this Bill is a milestone. I congratulate both the past and the present Ministers for Social Security on proceeding with it, and I urge other Ministers and departments to take up this initiative and to introduce similar improved legislation in their departments so that people in this country have a much better understanding of the provisions of the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Social Security Bill. As was made quite clear by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) earlier today, it is important that whatever Act it may be-the Social Security Act or any other Act-it is made as simple as possible so far as is necessary for the people to be able to interpret it.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dawson referred to the Income Tax Assessment Act, which is a typical example of an Act that we would like to see simplified. I trust that the Government will proceed to update through simplification many of the Acts that we pass in this House and that have existed for a long time.

Of course, we had better be realistic about this whole matter. We do not accept that the average Australian will be able to interpret the Social Security Bill now before this House. I am just a humble farmer, and at times I am pleased that I am, rather than being a teacher or solicitor, as mentioned by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). I find that members with this background become confused at times too. I think one must be logical in looking at the interpretation of an Act.

I do not believe that any more people are going to read this Act, simple as it may be. People generally feel that an Act is difficult to interpret. So they go to their local member, solicitor, accountant or minister of religion and say, `What does all this mean?'. We are supposed to know and to pass it on, and that is reasonable when we come to think about it.

I rose to speak today for one principal reason, and that is my concern about the confusion this Act creates in the mind of the average aged person, as has been very well outlined by the honourable member for Moreton. There is confusion in people's minds about an Act that changes twice a year because it is catching up with the consumer price index. Every time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brings in a Budget there are changes to the Act and there are changes by way of regulation that people have difficulty in interpreting.

I worry about the effect that changes to social security and other legislation may have upon the health of aged people and the confusion created in their minds. Average Australians work for a lifetime and they pay their taxes. They believe that when they retire they will have the satisfaction of knowing that they have a superannuation or social security scheme that they will be able to depend upon. When people are young and working, and in middle life too, they tend not to worry about their health, but when they are older they are concerned that their health will stand by them, and in most cases it does.

When people get to their sixties and seventies little things begin to happen. They get rheumatism, heart problems and other more serious complaints. So it is that the older people get the more they worry about their future. They wonder how they are going to be cared for-by their family, if they are lucky enough to have one, or by the Acts that are passed in this Parliament and in the various State parliaments.

I reiterate that I am very concerned. No matter what we say about our electorate offices, basically they are social security offices. In my area Taree is the centre of a growing population of aged people and every day there would be five, six, seven, eight, maybe more, people coming into my office and saying, `I am in trouble with my social security; how does this deeming provision or this other provision affect me?'.

I have put out a simple booklet, and even the social security people agree with it, setting out what all types of pensioners are entitled to. Thousands of people in the community, including members of senior citizens groups and the Returned Services League, come to my office and ask for assistance. We send out thousands of these booklets; people read them and ring up and say, `Thank you'. They come to us and ask a direct question about a particular part of the Act and the way it affects them, and we then have to ring up the manager of the social security office.

I have four offices in my electorate, and I may say that I receive the utmost cooperation from all of the officers concerned. So we can get an answer from them, but if we have the booklet we can say, `This is a simple interpretation of the Act as it applies at this time'. I say that because amending this Act and making it simple is not curing the problems in the minds of the recipients of social security.

As I have said earlier, the great majority of these people are not going to read the Act, but it will be much simpler for Australian Council of Social Service officials, members of the legal fraternity, accountants, ministers of religion and others who read these things and are supposed to know. It will be in plain English and we hope it will be able to be interpreted.

From time to time throughout the year the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) has to change some form of social security legislation as a result of pressure being brought to bear by either a community group or honourable members as representatives of the people. These changes are confusing to many people. For example, the social security provisions in the last Budget must have been framed in a terrible hurry. Glaring mistakes were later pointed out by both members of the Opposition and the Government. Even after various Acts have been passed by Parliament, the regulations and certain policies are often changed, especially those affecting the aged.

I am deeply worried and concerned for the aged who, at that time in their lives, look to play their sport, enjoy a bit of peace and harmony at home and settle back and reminisce. The aged can have problems with their health. We do not want to create any further problems that will magnify this type of change occurring in social security.

I represent a rural electorate and, as such, I am greatly concerned about the assets test. Personally, I would give every Australian over a certain age an age pension. It would be simple to do it; one would not need today's bureaucracy. We would not need to simplify everything, because if someone had an income above the threshold that person would have to pay the money back to the Government anyway. I heard a couple of years ago that it would cost only another $300m to $400m to actually do this.

An assets test, once applied, not only creates confusion but is also unfair. I invite anyone to visit country areas, particularly while we are in a recession, and observe the hours that are worked for income, the results of the investment of people living and working on their properties and how those people are affected. These people have spent their lifetimes working and they feel that they are entitled to receive some kind of social security in their latter days.

I refer specifically to a small farming community in my electorate where there are 11 retired people over the age of 65 to 70 years who before the assets test received the age pension. When the assets test was introduced nine of those people lost the age pension. All of those people own small closed down dairy farms, and that is where they wanted to live. They did not want to go to town, as suggested by the Government, and buy a three or four bedroom home, which would use up their money and where the mother would have to spend her entire day cleaning, even though she might not be able physically to do it. These people wanted to remain on their farms, but in many cases their neighbours had sold out for a fair price and so the valuation of their property precluded them from receiving the age pension. These people were told they could sell their properties and move to town. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) told them at that time, `We will pay you and we will count that as a debt against your assets'. No genuine farmer would entertain doing such a thing with his property. I doubt whether any of these farmers have availed themselves of that opportunity. I believe the assets test is wrong.

There are many other examples which illustrate that the assets test is wrong. When constituents come to see me and tell me they are entitled to unemployment benefit or some other form of assistance, I sometimes say to these people-and one must be frank-`Let me go out in the street and bring the fellow driving the grader, cleaning the street or driving the local taxi in here and tell him about your situation, you being an able-bodied person, and ask him whether he is prepared to pay you'.

This is the test of social security. People believe that governments pluck money out of the air; they do not. Somebody has to pay. Those working today, the productive community of Australia, are paying this money to allow the disadvantaged and those in need of help in the country to draw a payment of some kind. I am not against paying or helping anybody who deserves help. I will fight and battle, as I do every hour of the day within my electorate, to try to get these people assistance. This is the truth of the matter.

I have people who come to me and say, `Bruce, I will give you an instance of somebody to whom I offered a job and he wouldn't accept it. Would you put him in?'. I have never put a person in in my life. I have said to those people, `You can go to Social Security'. The Department even accepts anonymous letters and we can name a particular person if we wish. I certainly will not put people in; I am not a telltale-tit. But that is the way it is.

We had better have a look at ourselves because we are in a bad recession. We are very close to a depression, if not there already. We have entered the door of a depression. There are people who come to our offices to see us. Somebody said to me the other day, `It doesn't pay for me to work. I have a wife and so many children'. In other words, that person has no incentive to work because of the income that he is receiving from various forms of social security-the family allowance, unemployment benefit and rent assistance. He says that it does not pay him to work. I warn the Government that if that is going to be its policy it should look at this very closely. It will not bring employment back in this country. If it goes too far with its social security system it will want an army of bureaucrats to be able to control and supervise it.

The Social Security Act is similar to our Family Law Act. One-third of married Australian families today are separating. What is happening with some of the children and the lady who is left behind? They apply for taxpayers' money to live on. If it is a genuine case we do not object to that. Our Family Law Act is another Act that needs simplifying. It needs more than simplifying; it needs fixing up to make it a little harder for people to marry and then say, `We can walk out next year' and leave their wife with a baby to look after. Is this fair? There is more than just a Social Security Act to simplify and look at. The Family Law Act also has to be looked at to see that it is fair.

These breakdowns are actually being accepted today. We had better look at the reason why they are happening. We had better toughen up a little because there are problems emerging. Let us look at the child support scheme. We supported it. I thought it was a great idea, whereby the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office were going to cooperate and the father of the child was going to be brought to bear. He was going to be the one who had to accept the responsibility to keep his family, his wife, and particularly the children. But there is something wrong with the administration of our child support scheme. Also in our offices almost daily we have wives coming in who do not have support. They say, `I have written to the Child Support Agency and told them the address of my husband, where he is working, where he can be found, where certain documents can be given to him, but nothing happens'.

Is the problem that the Department is understaffed? The Minister had better have a look at it because I do not think that system is operating properly. I cannot condemn any particular part of it except that it is not operating. When we ring the Department we get cooperation. Once I read in the newspaper that somebody, perhaps from that Department, said, `Unless a member for Parliament makes representations on an issue concerning a wife or family we are unable to do much about it'.

The child support scheme generally is a problem. One problem cropped up the other day that was not directly associated with this Bill-it was about aged care and the decision of the Minister to stop paying, on an assets test basis, a subsidy for people who reside in a hostel or nursing home. That decision affected hundreds of thousands of Australians. A pensioner who sold a house two years prior to coming to live within a hostel would be assets tested.

I am sure I am correct in what I am saying. We never realised when the legislation came before the House that it had such implications. Fair enough; the legislation is there. Nursing home and hostel committees have approached me and said, `Would you take this up with the Minister and point out the deficiencies, because we are concerned about it.' Every resident of hostels now have to be investigated. This results in more confusion in the minds of those poor aged people who have finally found a place in a hostel and are being cared for within that hostel. These are the problems with assets testing.

Austudy has been talked about here today. This Bill might not be directly concerned with it, but it is wide-ranging legislation. If a farmer owns a property and his income from the property is small-it is small today, as the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) has said time and time again; it has predicted farmers' incomes-the value of the assets he owns are counted in the test for eligibility. His real estate, stock and plant are used for assessment, not the return that he has. This is grossly unfair, but it is predictable because of the assets test on these things.

The further the Government takes social security, the further it subsidises A,B,C and D, the bigger the mess that it is going to get into. It is not that I am saying there are not deserving cases; there are. But governments have to think about legislation and know the direction that they are going in so that they can legislate properly to account for those people.

I appeal to the Government once again. I say to it, `For goodness' sake, in fairness look at the assets test; see the decent Australians who have worked to produce, to export and to keep the economy of this country going. See that these people are not penalised under Acts of the Parliament where they should not be penalised.' I believe that is very important.

In concluding, I think that Social Security should extend its public relations. It is not easy for its officers, but they should get around the countryside and have meetings with the recipients. They should make themselves available to answer the recipients' questions when the senior citizens' committees get together. I have received cooperation in my electorate from the Australian Taxation Office and I would suggest to officers of the Social Security Department that they ought to do these things to provide this growing number of people with this opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested to hear what the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) had to say, in particular, about assets tests-he did not get on to income tests, but that is the other side of the test on social security provisions within Australia. Certainly the suggestion that the honourable member mentioned that Australia should really give everyone the pension, as they do in England and in a number of other countries, has been put to me. But, of course, the experience in those countries is that the pension, because it is being given to everybody, is usually so small that supplementary pensions, which are assets and income tested, are needed. All a government is doing in cases like that is taking taxes off everybody-higher taxes than are needed, because obviously it has to give everybody the pension-and giving them back to every person in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Government's move of encouraging private superannuation and the private sector to take over the management and investment of those funds so that in the future people retiring will have an adequate income is a much more constructive way of going about it and helps the aim of national savings as well.

My purpose in rising today is to talk about a group of aged pensioners who, I think, are being forced by circumstance into paying full cost for operations in hospitals. I have here an advertisement from the West Australian newspaper of last Saturday headed, `Why wait 2 more painful years for a joint replacement?'. It shows an aged pensioner on a frame, obviously in distress, and it says:
Now there is no need to suffer because of long waiting lists at public hospitals.

We have heard about these long waiting lists for a long time, especially at election time, so I thought I would investigate this a little bit further. I called the number that was on the advertisement and received a brochure. I would like to read to the House the conditions that apply to the people who might be eligible under what they call the `priority-op' plan. The first condition reads:
You must be an aged pensioner on the maximum rate.
We are not talking about somebody with a lot of money-we are talking about an aged pensioner, obviously one without a lot of assets. The second condition reads:
Your financial circumstances should be such that you are unable to pay for the treatment from your private means.
This effectively rules out people with private health insurance. The third condition reads:
You must own, or be paying off a home.

When pressed on this, the organisation responsible said a pensioner would have to substantially own the home, so effectively, a pensioner would have to own his own home and be a maximum-rate pensioner.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would recognise that the target group of the priority-op plan is, indeed, Medicare patients. The literature that is put out shows that the plan is targeting Medicare patients who, according to the literature, cannot be accommodated in a public hospital. When I went into this a little bit further, I found that the cost is $11,000. There is no up-front fee, because obviously the organisation concerned is going to take out a lien on the house and take it out of the estate later on. I draw a parallel between that situation and what the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) said about the farm situation, where the farmer was asset rich but income poor, yet because of the assets test, the Department of Social Security said that if he were paid a pension it would come out of the farm. This is a very similar situation.

But $11,000 plus 10 per cent per annum after 10 years is $25,900, and after 15 years is $41,700-so it rises quite dramatically. I point out that, by contrast, a Medicare patient would pay nothing. We are talking about $11,000-stretching to $41,000 after 15 years-compared to nothing for pensioners who take up their rightful entitlement of getting that operation done under Medicare.

It is obvious that the scheme itself is diametrically opposed to the principles of Medicare, which include access to this sort of treatment. Obviously, the advertisement plays on the fears of the elderly and there is a perception in the community that there are long waiting lists for hospitals, that the public hospitals are full and that somehow Medicare is to blame.

The facts are that when we look at the hospitalisation rate in Australia, we see that 21.8 per cent of our population goes through our hospitals every year, that is 3 1/2 million, and that is the highest in the world. So our hospitals are doing a great job. In fact, they are very efficient at putting people through them. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average is 15.3 per cent. If we achieved that rate we would have one million fewer Australians going through our hospitals every year. We would not have these schemes being promoted because obviously there would be no waiting lists if we were to achieve the OECD average. Those figures are from the OECD publication Financing and Delivering Health Care. So Australian hospitals are efficient.

The other thing to remember is that of all the people treated in public hospitals, half are privately insured. The thing that, I think, is not widely understood-certainly by the promoters of this plan and State Governments, although they should-is that the Medicare agreement does allow public patients to be treated in private hospitals. I have a copy of the agreement. Clause 4.4 of the Medicare agreement between the States and the Commonwealth says:

The State may enter into arrangements with private hospitals, other States, the Northern Territory or recognised hospitals in the Australian Capital Territory for the provision of care and treatment, which is unavailable or cannot be provided within the recognised hospital system. Where such arrangements exist eligible persons will be charged in accordance with clause 9. The State Minister shall supply to the Commonwealth Minister particulars of any such arrangements.

Clause 9 states that Medicare patients cannot be charged above the schedule fee. In actual fact, the treatment must be free to the patient. That being the case, if there are, as we are led to believe, empty hospital beds and there is a demand, as indicated by the advertisement in the West Australian newspaper for age pensioners last Saturday, the question is: why are the States not making full use of the Medicare agreement?

In South Australia that is done. In South Australia public patients are treated in private hospitals, but this does not occur in any other State. Obviously, the State governments have that option open to them. You would agree, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the private sector can make these beds available at lesser cost than can the public sector. That is obviously because the private sector hospitals undertake no training-there are no training costs for private hospitals-there is no research done in private hospitals, and there are no standby or emergency facilities in private hospitals. All of those facilities are very expensive and they are all carried by the public hospitals, but not by the private hospitals. Also, if we believe the rhetoric, private hospitals should be cheaper because they are run more efficiently. There is nothing wrong with State governments contracting out to get private hospital beds for public patients, for Medicare patients, for the age pensioners who are the target of the advertisement that I mentioned.

The other reason why, obviously, this is not done is that medical specialists will not treat public patients in private hospitals. There is a medical embargo against that treatment, and that is for two reasons. Firstly, more people will drop their private health cover if they can get treatment straight away. The reason why a lot of people have private health cover now is the fear that they will have to wait a long time for operations. But if that fear was removed, the numbers with private health cover would go down. That really means that the medical specialists and the surgeons cannot bill public patients directly. Therefore, the pool of people to whom they can send bills diminishes. So those are the two reasons why the private sector is not involved in treating public patients. The age pensioner in the advertisement which I mentioned is a glaring example of that.

Obviously, as I say, this is being used to force a lot more people than would otherwise be the case into private health insurance, because private health insurance actually works in reverse to normal insurance. A person takes out more insurance and ends up paying more. In every other class of insurance, if a person takes out more insurance he ends up paying less, should he need to claim.

The family hospitals proposals really are a natural extension of what I call an evil scaremongering campaign. People on this side of the House are getting sick of Medicare being blamed for waiting lists, when that agreement specifically allows the State governments to expand the number of beds available to all Australians.

I am not criticising the family hospitals in this advertisement for their treatment or their care. The Western Australian Government should move to end these schemes by ensuring that beds are available. I put it to the House that that would be a better investment of Western Australian taxpayers' money than some of the investments that the Western Australian Government has entered into. It seems to me that this Federal Government has been upholding Labor traditions very strongly. Certainly, Medicare is one of them, but we are not receiving the support that we could from some of our State Labor counterparts. If this is to be overcome, then obviously State governments have got to have a good look at themselves. They are the only ones who can overcome this by entering into the agreement-clause 4.4 of the Medicare agreement between the Commonwealth and the States-to make those beds available in the private sector. That will not overcome the ban by specialists, but that is something this Government will have to address.

In conclusion, I think that the senior citizens and the age pensioners of this country in particular, and Australians generally, deserve better from State governments. They should be supporting the Federal Government in its attempts to make sure that access to medical treatment is made available to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that could well be asked in providing for those less well-off in this country is what we can do to make their job easier, and what can be done to enable more of our resources to be used in the direct provision of needs and less in administration. The answers to these questions lie in the Bill before us today, the Social Security Bill, and I want to make sure that I refer to that aspect of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Through this legislation, the Government has provided that our basic social security framework, which allows us to provide for our friends and neighbours in need of government assistance, has been overhauled to facilitate easier use of the Social Security Act to solve the complex problems posed by today's social structure. In an increasingly complex society, plain English is what people want, and that is precisely what people will get with this legislation.

This step builds on other important social initiatives of the Hawke Government in the retirement incomes policy, the social justice strategy, the introduction of family allowance supplements, and the indexation of social security payments, to name just a few. Against the background of social reform, however, it is disappointing to see the track record of honourable members opposite in regard to how they would provide for those in need of government assistance. It is ironic that, while the rewrite of the Social Security Act makes a great step forward in social reform, the Opposition would take the provision of assistance right back to the Dark Ages, with all and sundry being able to act as agents when handing out benefits, and no doubt taking their slice of the pie along the way.

While it may not be the aim of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to walk and talk with the animals, his ownership of an animal wishing to go in separate directions at the same time shows that he clearly shares at least one trait with the famous Doctor Dolittle.

In contrast, it is the Government's intention to remove any conflict in direction in the social reform area, and since 1983 we have proceeded down that track. Our aim of introducing greater equity in the provision of social security is unsurpassed in Australia's history.

When speaking in the House last week in the debate on one of the taxation Bills, I referred to the tirade we have heard from the Opposition in recent months about the Government's package of taxation measures and how the Opposition would vary it if it had the chance. I said then that if anything was ever clearer, it was that the average Australian is very lucky that those opposite do not have that chance. That reference applies just as strongly to the changes to the provision of social security mooted by the Opposition. I use the word `mooted' because, as with all the ideas to come from the Opposition recently, this idea was one announced by the Leader of the Opposition at a doorstop interview.

I ask the Opposition a question that has been asked many times before: is the idea to contract out provision of social security benefits Liberal Party policy? It may be Liberal Party policy to use this contracting out of social services as a means of subsidising its planned revamp of the tax system, but a quick analysis of wage scales and related benefits shows that most people currently receiving benefits will be the losers and not the winners under this type of social security system. It would be a system designed to fill the pockets of the rich rather than the poor. If it is not Liberal policy, then just what is?

While members of the Opposition try to work out their real social security policy, Australia's social security recipients need to know where they stand, and that is an important point that seems to have escaped the Opposition. Australia's age pensioners, our struggling families, and all those in need of government assistance, need to be able to plan their future. Similarly, just because somebody is no longer working, whether it be through redundancy or retirement, it does not mean that his or her independence should be removed. This Government recognises that and has acted accordingly through some of the measures I have already alluded to.

Let me first address the issue of retirement, and the associated needs of independence and dignity. To unite these linking themes, the Government has introduced the most comprehensive package of measures for retirement. This was a necessary step for Australia to prepare for the new challenges that face us into the next century as our population ages. For although Australia still has a relatively young population, between now and the end of the century the proportion of the population aged 75 and over will increase dramatically. This will mean a rapid rise in the demand for age pensions and high growth in the need for services to support the aged.

To be able to meet this rise in demand and to ensure that an acceptable standard of living can be maintained for those people in retirement, it is vital that every opportunity is provided to encourage and reward people for planning now for their retirement. Through the statement Better Incomes: Retirement Income Policy into the Next Century, Australia will be well placed to face these challenges ahead.
One of the centrepieces in the statement's drive towards greater independence in retirement is the emphasis on superannuation. I quote from that document:

It will be possible to meet the needs of an ageing population better by increasing the level of saving and by expanding labour market opportunities. However, future generations will probably expect higher levels of income and services. Consequently, a flexible and sustainable retirement income policy which delivers fair and adequate incomes needs to build on the twin pillars of the age pension system and private savings such as superannuation.
This statement clearly outlines the Government's strategy on the question of retirement incomes.

Changes announced in the Budget improve superannuation arrangements which will mean that more Australians can save for their retirement, with assistance from the Government. Particular attention has been given to providing better employment and retirement savings opportunities for women. These changes build on the 3 per cent superannuation benefit that was awarded to Australian workers as part of the Government's accord with the trade union movement. We have now seen the availability of superannuation extend to far more workers than was ever the case previously.

Historically, superannuation was seen as a sole privilege of the wealthy and some white collar workers only. Today, with the expansion of the industry-based schemes and the improvements to the portability of superannuation, the number of workers who now belong to a scheme has escalated quite dramatically.

The Government has also recognised the difficulties faced by women due to their high level of participation in part-time work. Award-based superannuation has been identified as an important method of providing superannuation coverage to the majority of women. The Government will continue to support extensive occupational superannuation to all employees and for improvements in the schemes in conjunction with the union movement through future wage rounds. Several other modifications have been announced to make superannuation more available and attractive to women.

In addressing the part-time situation, people employed for as little as 10 hours a week will now be able to contribute to personal superannuation schemes and receive tax deductions for contributions. This has been reduced from 25 hours a week, which was the previous minimum requirement to be able to contribute to superannuation.

Other initiatives aimed at giving these people further independence in retirement have been the decision to allow people to continue contributing to personal superannuation schemes for up to two years while outside the paid work force.

There are many other advances made by this Government in the superannuation area. Those advances have had one aim in mind: to make superannuation no longer the domain of the rich but to make it accessible to all Australians, thus reducing our social security bill for the aged in particular.

When we talk about social security and the objectives of the legislation before us today, we talk about social equity and providing some assistance to those who are ill able to provide for themselves.

The Government also recognises that the problems of those in need of social security assistance cannot be solved by money alone. It takes the right mix of policies. This was precisely the thrust behind the introduction of the family allowance supplement (FAS).

Under eight years of Liberal-National Party rule, there had been created a mindset whereby people had no incentive to join the work force and could gain greater government assistance by staying in receipt of social security benefits and the associated concessions for medications and the like. Through the family allowance supplement, the Government has turned this around.

As at 29 January 1990, 183,622 Australian families were in receipt of the family allowance supplement, ensuring that 445,236 eligible children of FAS families were provided for while a regular income was being earned to add substantially to the family structure. I might add that the amount of assistance these thousands of families receive through FAS is quite substantial. For instance, a family with one child under the age of 13 would still be eligible for some FAS while the combined taxable family income remained under $20,756, with the maximum rate being $53 a fortnight. A family with two children under the age of 13 and another between 13 and 15 would still be eligible for FAS while the combined taxable family income remained under $28,780, the maximum rate being $183.30 a fortnight.

Such families would of course be eligible for family allowance of $20 a fortnight in the first instance and $60 a fortnight in the latter. The only other condition applied to families when determining eligibility for FAS is a flat assets test of $347,500. Families that meet the income test criteria and fall below that assets test limit will receive the full benefit.

I am proud to say that, as at 19 December 1990, there were 2,728 families in receipt of family allowance supplement in areas serviced by the two Social Security offices in my electorate of Oxley. Put another way, that is just under 3,000 families who are being encouraged to remain in the work force.

If I may digress just a little, Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to use this opportunity to put on record my appreciation of the work done by the management and staff of the Social Security offices at Ipswich and Goodna in my electorate and their understanding of the complex array of cases they deal with on a daily basis. That is another face of social security.

Honourable members opposite seem to forget that there is more to social security than just finding a suitable person to dish out the money. Given that we have not heard any more from the Leader of the Opposition since the good doctor gave his last doorstop interview, we will have to assume he still has in mind to go about providing social security in the same way as one sells newspapers. For the Opposition's benefit I will repeat what I said earlier in regard to the provision of social security: there comes with the responsibility to provide for people financially the need to recognise the different aspects of social security, and that is something that neither the milkman, the newsagent nor any other agent would be able to do.

Evidence of the Government's recognition of this can be seen in the commitment made to maintain the benchmarks of adequacy in family payments. Specifically, these are to maintain the total value of family payments, that is, the first child rate of family allowance plus FAS, equivalent to the married rate of pension for children under 13, and 20 per cent for children aged 13, 14 and 15 years. These benchmarks were achieved in July 1989 and the Government accordingly increases the rates of FAS each January by the amounts necessary to ensure that the 15 and 20 per cent benchmarks are maintained.

Put simply, the rule of thumb when initiating and revising social security policy is to keep in touch with the targeted group. This is precisely what the Government has done through the changing of FIS, formerly the family income supplement, to FAS, the family allowance supplement, in December 1987. This step has resulted in a more than fourfold increase in the number of families in receipt of FAS from 46,000 at the introduction of FAS in December 1987 to 183,000 in December 1990, an increase of which the Government can be justly proud. The Government has also made a continuous effort to increase the awareness of the FAS program and results from a FAS evaluation show that 79 per cent of potentially eligible families were aware of the program.

The Government has undertaken a range of measures to ensure the policies implemented are those best suited for the intended beneficiaries and that those people have every opportunity to take advantage of those benefits. Some of these activities include: extensive publicity used in a wide range of outlets from television to milk carton advertisements; Social Security regional offices developing an extensive range of publicity and information material for schools, hospitals, employers and other community organisations; and market research to improve the quality of information products and publicity strategies.

Because of the anticipated turnover of the FAS client group, a great deal of importance has been placed on continual and regular outreach programs. As proof of the benefits of the constant feedback that comes to the Government through our ongoing analysis of the state of play in social security to make the task easier for families in need of help, since 1988 the separate family allowance and FAS claim forms were combined into a single document.

I ask the question: how would one derive such information under a system where assistance was not being provided by one central agency? How many butchers, bakers and candlestick makers, for instance, would need to get together to determine the effectiveness of a particular benefit? As honourable members opposite are left trying to work out the answers, I regret to give them some more bad news.

Through the united effort of a national social security system, the Government has been able to maximise the take-up of benefits by pensioners and beneficiaries who make the transition into the work force. Terminating beneficiaries and pensioners are advised of possible eligibility for FAS as a matter of course. In the case of an ex-beneficiary or ex-pensioner who is eligible for FAS and who claims within six weeks of being cancelled for pension or benefit, FAS is backdated to the payday following the last receipt of pension or benefit.

I have not heard at any point those on the other side of this place saying that we could sustain a position where expenditure continued to grow at twice the level of production. This Government had to take the decision to slow it down.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the decisions we have taken in this last year, with successive reductions in interest rates, with the move that will take place to build up stocks in this country, and with the flowthrough into the pockets of those in employment of the benefits of the tax cuts from 1 January, by the end of this year Australia will come out of its recession. But it will come out of its recession because this Government, as distinct from those opposite, has been prepared both to take the necessarily tough economic decisions to put this country in a better place to face the challenges of the future, and, as well, to do that with a compassionate face and ensured that for those who are out of work firstly there is a range of training and retraining programs, which the Opposition would abolish, and secondly there is the commitment to continue unemployment benefits indefinitely, as distinct from what the Opposition would do-that is, abolish them after nine months.

So I ask the honourable member to please tell his constituent that we have not just a verbal compassion for him but a commitment to ensure that he will get back into work and that, for as long as he is out of work, under this Government he will be paid an unemployment benefit. Just tell him what the Opposition is committed to-that is, it will throw him on the street after nine months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer whether he is aware of comments by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Bernie Fraser, about Australia's economy. What are the prospects for Australia's economic recovery in the light of these comments, and what are the Government's intentions in regard to other economic prescriptions proposed to assist the economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Governor had this to say in an address on the economy and the likelihood of a pick-up:

ANSWER.PARA: But it is achievable and activity should begin to pick up during the second half of 1991, aided by the substantial reductions in interest rates that have occurred in 1990, the countercyclical workings of fiscal policy, the eventual turnaround of the stock and housing cycle, and the improvement in inflationary expectations.

I most heartily concur with those sentiments in the way they have been expressed. As you will recall, Mr Speaker, I did answer yesterday part of the question put to me today in relation to the impact of a $3 billion reduction in spending on the economy, saying that the Government was not going to counter that cycle within fiscal policy by seeking to cut outlays further.

The fact is that the Opposition's policies which have been proposed to the Government as prescriptions for a recovery would not produce a recovery. We have now gleaned from the Leader of the Opposition that this, to date, is his manifesto: the double taxation, with State and Federal income tax, of individuals; a consumption tax on all goods; vouchers for health and education; and no wages policy to keep costs and inflation under control.

That means there would be two brand new taxes: State income tax and a consumption tax levied on all goods. This is the Liberal Party at its taxing best. Education responsibilities would be transferred from government to individuals, as my colleague has just demonstrated. In health there would be an income blow-out for doctors, letting them charge what they could get away with through a voucher system.

These are all the notions of the visiting professor, the fellow who visits issues. He wafts in and out of the issues, never fleshing the proposals out. We know he is a professor, but what we have learnt lately is that he is just a visiting professor-visiting issues without saying what he stands for, and all on the pretence that he is not really a politician but some sort of commentator putting views for public debate rather than having clear responsibilities to articulate a policy, to explain how vouchers will work for doctors or for education, to explain how the double taxation of income will produce lower tax or to explain what rates there will be under a consumption tax.

The Leader of the Opposition is a one-dimensional person. He says his expertise is on the economy, yet his sole contributions are on consumption tax and double taxation. On everything else-on foreign policy, education and health-he has simply blundered around. There was his soup kitchen proposal for pensioners to send them down to the Matthew Talbot Hostel to get their pension cheque and a bowl of soup. These are the blunders of this one-dimensional visitor to the political landscape.

—What has this got to do with the plasterer?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the response of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to allegations levelled at the Department of Defence by Senator Newman that it has increased its spending on external consultancy work by over 800 per cent over the last three years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are few people in this House who pay as much attention to the important issue of defence as the honourable member for Oxley. Senator Newman's claim that we have increased consultancy expenditure in the Department of Defence over the last four years reminds me of the old adage: there are lies, damned lies and statistics. Her calculations are based on a false figure for the base year that she uses, which is the financial year 1986-87, and she quotes a figure for external consultancies of that year of $2.559m.

ANSWER.PARA: She has been told twice, on 19 December 1989 and 19 July 1990, that that figure is false. It excludes major items such as consultancies performed for computing, for capital procurement-which in the Department of Defence runs at over $2 billion a year-and for the old Office of Defence Production, which has since been abolished. After the authority to commission consultancy work was devolved in 1985 the detailed figures were not held centrally, so the figure that she is using for that year is simply not comparable with subsequent years. She knows that, and still she persists in distorting the facts.

The reliable figures, which are available, are those from 1987-88 through to 1989-90, and in that period consultancy expenditure rose by 83 per cent. That is a tenth of what Senator Newman says is the case. That 83 per cent figure is not small, but honourable members will appreciate that Defence over those years, like the public sector generally, did take its share of reductions in personnel and has sought, very wisely in my view, not to retain expertise in-house simply for the sake of it.

In line with modern management practice and in a drive to get the most value for the budgetary dollar, Defence does commission outside experts to perform specialist tasks. Many of those are related to the new capabilities with which we are equipping the Australian armed forces. Many of them are related to our emphasis on environmental responsibility, which I am sure members would want to see pursued rigorously.

It is particularly deplorable that the items which Senator Newman singles out in her press release to criticise relate to the area of training and staff development. That work is aimed at improving skills and productivity and it yields very substantial benefits to the nation.

I conclude by saying that one of the things that she does single out is a consultancy of $19,000 to develop a survey questionnaire on attitudes to ethics amongst defence staff. Were she herself to undergo that questionnaire I suspect she would fail it.
