—My question is directed to the Prime Minister, who claims he never gets a question from me. During my recent discussions with the Brotherhood of St Laurence I was told that those Australians living in the most abject poverty were some 6,000 homeless children under the age of 16. With the Government spending nearly $30 billion a year on welfare assistance, why has the Prime Minister failed to ensure that some of this money goes to those in greatest need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hypocrisy of this question is mind-boggling. In case the Leader of the Opposition has any doubt about this, I point out that yesterday I had the opportunity of speaking with representatives of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Association. They left me in no doubt whatsoever as to the horror they entertain at the possibility of the Leader of the Opposition ever being given the responsibility of government. They are the people-not us here-who analyse closely the alternatives between this Government's policies and the Opposition's policies in the area of social welfare and security. These people are appalled, as they properly should be, by the prospect of having to live under the policies that have been espoused by the Leader of the Opposition. And well they should be, because what the Leader of the Opposition is saying now is that he would cut $3 billion off Commonwealth expenditure.
—He is asking you what you would do.
—Order! The honourable member for Isaacs!

—There is no doubt who would suffer in this community if that $3 billion expenditure cut was undertaken; it would be the poor and the underprivileged. We have seen the philosophy which underlies the Opposition's approach. My colleague Ministers in the areas of education and health have pointed out what the philosophy of the Opposition is. The philosophy is stark. At least we can give Opposition members credit for this: they do very little to disguise where their sympathies lie. They do not lie with the poor and underprivileged; they lie with the already privileged in this community.

ANSWER.PARA: In the area of health, the Opposition's policies are calculated to enhance the position of the private health funds and the doctors. In the area of education their policies are aimed at looking after those who are already relatively well attended for and best able to look after themselves. If the Opposition were to implement its vicious reduction of $3 billion in Commonwealth expenditure, it would be the poor, including children in poor families, who would suffer. That is why I say that the hypocrisy of the Leader of the Opposition in asking this question is mind-boggling.

I remind the Leader of the Opposition of what has been done in the area of payments to those most in need. Three years ago, we introduced the family allowance supplement which provides tax-free cash assistance to low income families. I will give an indication of what that means. At present, more than half a million families, including 1.2 million children, are being helped by family allowance supplement benefits or payments or their equivalent in extra pensions and benefits, including family allowances. This involves over $2 billion of Commonwealth funding for children in low income families. We have indexed family allowance supplements and other family payments to the consumer price index and last month they rose again. They rose to $26.50 a week for each child under 13 and $38.65 a week for teenagers between the ages of 13 and 15.

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the question.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—The measure of what we have done is highlighted by the fact that this brings the real increase in payments for children under 13 to 45 per cent. That is a 45 per cent real increase since 1983 and over 110 per cent real increase for children between the ages of 13 and 15.

ANSWER.PARA: Work by the Social Policy Research Centre has estimated that over the period 1982-83 to 1989-90, the real income of families with children in the bottom 10 per cent of the income range has increased by 17.6 per cent. That is as a result of carefully calculated, directed, targeted assistance to the sort of people whom the Leader of the Opposition is talking about-not airy, waffly, off-the-top-of-the-head concepts, but hard slogging work done in conjunction with the organisations.

When we were fixing the benchmarks for assistance in family allowance supplement payments, we talked with the Brotherhood of St Laurence. We asked its members, `What sort of proportion of the basic pension rate should be fixed as a percentage for family allowance supplement payments?'. It was with the specific assistance of the Brotherhood of St Laurence and other organisations that we set these figures. We have brought in these massive real increases in payments totalling over $2 billion, which have led these same organisations to say publicly that these are the most historic moves that have ever been made by any Federal Government in the history of this country to deal with these problems.

These organisations, including the Brotherhood of St Laurence, are on the public record as saying that about this Government's projects and policies. Against that achievement, we have this hypocritical Leader of the Opposition coming up and asking this question when, at the same time, he is saying he would cut $3 billion off these very programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you answer the question?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has Australia's approach to the future of sanctions in South Africa been reflected in the outcome of the recent meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers Committee on South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. As we would all agree, this is an important issue on which this Government feels, quite properly, a high degree of responsibility because Australia, as is well known, led the way in securing the imposition of sanctions, and Australia will take the lead in removing them as it is appropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to President de Klerk's speech of 2 February, we developed a proposal for the phased lifting of sanctions as the South African Government implements its proposed reforms. We called for a meeting last weekend of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers Committee to discuss it. Before that meeting in London last weekend, there was a preceding meeting of the front line states in Harare, which indicated-I may say, unfortunately-no willingness to consider any lifting of sanctions at all for the foreseeable future.

Senator Evans, therefore, went to London last weekend with a fairly stiff job-to bring some of his Commonwealth colleagues around to the Australian way of thinking on this point. I am glad to say that in the event the meeting clearly accepted the principle of phased relaxation of sanctions in response to further developments as they occur. The meeting specified the point at which that process of relaxation should begin-a point which is widely expected to be reached in May or June of this year.

Finally, the meeting accepted the Australian proposal that sporting contact should be resumed in those sports that had achieved non-racial unity, in consultation with the non-racial sports bodies in South Africa.

Mr Speaker, I have noticed that the Opposition issued press releases a couple of days ago suggesting that this outcome is a defeat for Australian policy. Let me put it this way: the train that was bound for a democratic, non-racial South Africa pulled out of the station a long, long time ago, and that train is fast approaching its destination. It is fast approaching its destination because there were men and women of courage and vision, both inside and outside South Africa. May I say that no-one from this Opposition was ever aboard that train: at every point when the world, with Australia playing a leading role in it, imposed those sanctions to bring South Africa to its senses, we met with opposition from those on the other side of this House.

Let me point out that in his press release the Opposition spokesman on sport claims that there will be no early resumption of any sporting links because the African National Congress (ANC) `opposes sporting links, even with integrated codes'. Let me say simply that he is wrong on this. The ANC has made it specifically clear to us that that is not its position. Its position is that it is in favour of sporting contact once the internal condition of integration within South Africa is satisfied.

In another press release the Opposition foreign affairs spokesman said that we had failed to offer President de Klerk any encouragement. That is what he said-that we had failed to offer any encouragement. Interestingly, that is not what President de Klerk says. In the Age yesterday, the President himself-the one to whom the Opposition says we have not given any encouragement-said this:
there is no doubt who he is talking about-
have taken it upon them to take a stance that also from the Commonwealth there must emanate a new approach towards South Africa.'
`And I think that the debate has started there and I am confident that we can look forward to continued improvements of our international relationships.'
We are the country that started that debate in the Commonwealth. Mr de Klerk says that he is encouraged by it.

As the Opposition has been wrong at every other point over all the years, it is wrong again. It is wrong in not associating with the rest of the world in applying sanctions to bring South Africa to its senses. As a result of our actions, together with those of like minded people around the world, that train is pulling into the station of a free, democratic, non-racial South Africa. The Opposition has no credibility. It has never been aboard. When it utters any statements now, it will be treated as it has been over the last two years-as totally irrelevant. That is precisely as it should be treated on this foundationally important issue, on which it has been useless from the beginning and on which it is irrelevant now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy whether, in view of the suffering that the Government's high interest rates and rural policies are causing in the bush, over and beyond the effects of the downturn in commodity prices, with honest working people forced off the land, despite years of sacrifice and hardship, he can wholeheartedly endorse the current economic strategy espoused by the Treasurer.
—Yes or no.
—Yes.

—My question to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services concerns the provision of education facilities in the west of Melbourne. Is the Minister aware of speculation about future structures for tertiary institutions in Victoria? What is the role of the Federal Government in this process? Can the Minister assure me that, whatever the outcome of these negotiations, the Federal Government will maintain its commitment to expanding higher education opportunity in the west of Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that the honourable member for Burke is referring to speculation in the last few days about the future of the Victorian University of Technology.
—You wrote the question.
—I insist that it is not a dorothy dixer. The honourable member for Burke has a long-standing and legitimate concern with higher education provision in the west of Melbourne.

ANSWER.PARA: To go back to the honourable member's question, there has been some suggestion that the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology may be considering pulling out of the Victorian University of Technology which, as honourable members would be aware, is an amalgamation of the RMIT, the Footscray Institute of Technology and the Western Institute. Quite frankly, were that to occur I think we would regard it as a very serious setback for educational provision in Victoria. The Victorian University of Technology, as a concept, is certainly one that has the potential to provide significant improvements in higher education in that State, particularly servicing the western suburbs of Melbourne.

We have put a lot of funds into that. In capital terms, we are proposing to spend something like one-third of the Victorian capital program that was to go into the Victorian University of Technology. We have been prepared to fund substantial growth for that institution at high rates. Frankly, I think that is an indication of our commitment to that institution.

There is a more general problem in Victoria in that a number of institutional arrangements in the higher education area have yet to be finalised. That has created a particular difficulty for the Commonwealth in terms of making funding decisions. Last year we attempted to reform the process of funding higher education institutions in such a way as to place them on a more equitable footing and to do it in a way that more accurately reflects what each higher education institution does-the nature of the courses it teaches and the cost of providing those courses-rather than on some historical accident.

In the last set of announcements of the funding for the 1991-93 triennium it was not possible for us to finalise the funding decisions for the great bulk of institutions in Victoria, simply because negotiations regarding amalgamations were still proceeding. The Victorian Government was interested in pursuing some amalgamation proposals and negotiating them with the institutions themselves.

The honourable member asked what the Commonwealth's role was in all of this. Of course, the primary legislative responsibility lies with the State and the responsibility for finalising institutional arrangements, in the first instance, lies with the State and the institutions themselves. However, as the funding authority involved, we clearly have a legitimate interest and concern about that. In our annual profile negotiations with the institutions we negotiate as to what each institution will teach and the nature of the courses it is providing, in a broad sense, and we provide funding on that basis.

As I have said, it is a matter of real concern if the VUT looks like it will fall apart and we are very anxious to see institutional arrangements in Victoria tied up. The Victorian Government has taken some fairly decisive steps recently in order to bring about that result. We are very supportive of those steps and very supportive of the Victoria University of Technology.

The final part of the honourable member's question seeks a commitment from the Federal Government that it will maintain its commitment to expanding higher education opportunities in the west of Melbourne. I can give that commitment unequivocally, but if the VUT does not go ahead in its proposed form that task will be made that much more difficult. A range of funding decisions which have already been made will clearly have to be reviewed as a consequence.

The conservative misfits opposite blow in from no political organisation and happen to skulk into public office on the back of the fact that there might be enough conservative people out there to support them and give them a majority-and on no other basis. —People will not even be able to afford their kid's education because they will be priced out of schools on the notion of this voucher system that the Opposition has running.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the kind of care the Opposition has for the public; the kind of care it has for the community. As the Prime Minister said very eloquently a moment or so ago, when one refers to what the Government has done for child poverty, income support and generally looking after those who are disadvantaged, how dare those opposite put themselves in the class of the rest of us who care about Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Community Services and Health completed his assessment of proposals that support services for pensioners and the disadvantaged should be exclusively delivered by voluntary agencies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The examination of alternatives, particularly alternatives that come from those opposite, takes us beyond the proposal with respect to the privatisation of social security and welfare, as the Prime Minister suggested at the time of the last election. One has to remember that the Opposition has been speaking recently about the need for $3 billion worth of cuts, and of course advocated alternative policies at the last election. Essentially, the Opposition argued that not only should there be reductions in expenditure of that order, but also that half of that money should come out of social security-half of it should be taken from those who are most disadvantaged-and something like $800m ought to be saved from those people who are unemployed.

ANSWER.PARA: So it is no surprise that the Opposition should put forward, as the honourable member for Corio suggested, a proposition that at a time in which there are economic difficulties, at a time in which there is increasing unemployment, the responsibility for that should be shifted from the public sector to the non-government sector; that responsibility should be privatised so voluntary agencies bear that responsibility rather than its being borne by the taxpayer-in other words, we ought to take that expenditure out of taxation, out of the Government's hands, and move it out into the private sector with the result that one would not be able to achieve a degree of efficiency or a degree of fairness, and one would not be able to see any degree of care. Of course that proposition, as were other propositions from the Leader of the Opposition, was a throwaway. It was poorly thought through, and it was careless in terms of those whom it would affect most.

That, again, is characteristic of the Opposition's proposals. Just last Friday we had another proposal, in a so-called Cowper lecture, to privatise health insurance, and move to a kind of voucher system. Again that was a proposal that was immediately dumped by the Opposition spokesperson, the honourable member for Lowe. There is no sense of loyalty in the Opposition; no sense of any recognition of its Leader. In fact, the honourable member for Lowe stated that it was only one of a number of options. However, rather revealingly in terms of his predecessor, he said that if this option shacks up better than other options, it is the one Opposition members will go for. If it does not, they will go for one of the others.

We can understand that attitude. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The pain and tragedy being suffered by average Australians caused by the economic recession, the Treasurer said we had to have.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important matter to bring before the House and one that certainly has not been answered in any way by today's Question Time. It is not always recognised or understood that when Paul Keating assumed the role of Treasurer here in Canberra he brought as riding instructions one foolscap page of economic policy and a raft of social policies-people policies, if you like.

SPEECH.PARA: These people policies and the consequent institutions required for their implementation blew his first Budget into deficit by approximately $7 billion and the three subsequent Budgets into deficit by an additional $19 billion. The Treasurer chose to justify this massive injection of unearned income into the economy by blaming the deficit on the previous Fraser Government. The tragic fact is that he has battled with the economic consequences of that decision ever since.

Combined with his correct but unresearched decision to deregulate the Australian financial system, the Treasurer called up a maelstrom that, although reasonably slow in its gestation, has now unleashed upon the Australian community in unparalleled fashion a full blown recession, if not depression.

Treasurer Keating has been unique in Australian history not only for his arrogance, but also for almost constantly having the Australian economy performing in the opposite direction from that of the rest of the developed world. Throughout his stewardship, developed world economies have been buoyant and yet have experienced low interest rates and low inflation. However, having overinflated the Australian economy, the Treasurer felt obliged to hose it down. But again he did so with no understanding and little knowledge. Defying established economic theory and more particularly historic experience, he applied the single blunt instrument of high interest rates. In other words, having built an economy on debt, he made that debt so expensive that the economy has collapsed.

Before this debate is over-in fact it has happened half a dozen times through Question Time-a Government speaker will claim that the Government's economic policies have created some 1.5 million jobs. Yet, in support of my argument, a simple division of the number of those jobs into the foreign debt of this nation will show that the debt is equivalent to approximately four years wages per individual per job. We have had a debt led recovery and an interest rate led recession, hardly an example of economic expertise.

That is a brief and dispassionate history of the Australian economy under the world's best Treasurer. We have heard it many times. The purpose of my matter of public importance (MPI) today is to try to get the Government, and more particularly the Treasurer, to understand the human consequences and tragedy that have resulted from this incompetence.

The figures on unemployment are more dispassionate statistics. They tell us that in the last 18 months the number of unemployed in this country have grown from 483,400 to 767,700-an increase of 284,300 people, or 58.8 per cent. The Treasurer comes into the Parliament every day to rationalise those figures and to explain, `They're really not too bad'. We can put any interpretation we like on 700,000 people being unemployed, but for the individual who becomes unemployed it is an absolute tragedy. As politicians, even collectively, we do not meet the 700,000, but we do come into contact with large numbers.

Whilst the debate of the past has centred upon the intractable long term unemployed, the individuals I am meeting today are the long term employed who have just lost their jobs. What strikes me most in interviewing these people is the absolute confusion and despair that is so evident in their faces. Many have become ill; most have dropped their bundle completely because they cannot visualise the future; many are angry that their unemployment is the result of the actions of a government whose words they trusted and for which many of them voted.

This Government, which is so intent on defending itself and telling us that it is not really happening, spends no time defining the future-and today was no different. The last speech on this subject, which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seemed so proud of, had nothing to say about the future. It gave these people no vision; it gave them no encouragement. They talked about handouts, yes, but not the future direction.

No doubt some would seek to lay the blame with heartless employers. Let me tell honourable members the true story related to me by a State parliamentarian colleague of a discussion with a businessman in his electorate who wept as he described the dismantling of his work force, forced upon him by the recession. The employer did not weep for his business; he wept because he had to dismiss a long-serving and loyal work force which in fact he saw as his life's work. This is just one example that I know of personally. It is happening in thousands of small businesses around the nation. Human resources, well trained and coordinated as a team, are being ripped apart by the recession we had to have, or the Treasurer's earlier inflationary policies that we certainly did not need. The Government has a debt for jobs policy-and that is what it is: borrow the money anywhere we can get it; create the jobs. That debt for jobs policy is falling apart, and it is a national and human tragedy.

The wording of this matter of public importance is on the desk of every honourable member. Its meaning is clear. It is an attempt to get those on the Government benches to understand how their ill-directed and ill-conceived economic policies are hurting individual Australians. It is to tell them that the thousands of empty shops and small factories that we see for the first time in 50 years are evidence not only of bankrupt businesses but also of lost jobs right through the chain that has supplied those businesses with goods and services. It is to tell them that when builders go broke they go broke because people can no longer afford to buy a badly needed home and are therefore living in sub-standard accommodation or paying excessive rent. It is to tell them that when farmers' incomes are reduced to the negative by high interest rates it is their kids who lose the opportunity for higher education. The purpose of the matter of public importance is to try to tell the Government those sorts of things.

I would like to tell the Government that people experience ill health, marriage breakdown and many other undesirable social consequences as a result of the Government's induced economic pressures that now exist in our community. I would like to call upon the Government backbenchers to stop serving up their Ministers dorothy dix questions aimed at covering up this disaster and, as coalition backbenchers certainly did during the Fraser Government, ask those Ministers the searching questions that identify the extent of the economic problems of their constituents.

I ask honourable members opposite to demand that their Ministers put responsible government ahead of political rhetoric and tell Australians the truth and provide policies for the future of Australian families. Government members were put on notice of this matter of public importance but, sadly, they show the arrogant disregard of their Treasurer by their absence from the chamber today. For the record, there are four Government members in the Parliament at this moment and not one an official Minister. They might be excused for avoiding some speeches of a more political nature, but they have a total responsibility to participate in a debate that deals directly with the difficulties of their own constituents, that deals directly with the human tragedy of the Government's deliberate recession-the one we had to have. My colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) is to expand considerably on individual cases of personal tragedy and I trust that some Government members who may be listening at this moment might consider those examples worthy of their attention and return to the chamber.

The final plea I make on behalf of individual Australians in regard to this Government-induced recession is that the Government recognises not only the existence of the recession but also its magnitude-not only the outdated statistics but also the personal effects and fears that now exist in our community-and that its policies have created this situation and its solutions, if it has any, are not working. Hand-outs are a temporary solution. Most Australians want the pride of employment and the security of an affordable home.

Yesterday, during Question Time, Government Ministers demonstrated just how out of touch they are with the community. In search of political advantage, the Government delivered an orchestrated attack on remarks made last week by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) which were aimed at focusing the debate on solutions to the Government's failure. The remarks by our Leader could be best summarised by saying that the coalition puts the value and individual needs of people ahead of institutions and that we believe that if financial relief is directed to the individual they will spend it more wisely to the general economic good.

Minister after Minister stood to defend the institutions of their departments. Even the matter of public importance was structured to this end. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) put an impassioned case for disadvantaged schools but did not say one word about disadvantaged students or their parents, and today he has rambled on again trying to back up and protect his ridiculous position, ignoring completely that governments traditionally do not hand out dollars in round figures but target, in all these policies of individual help, those most in need-a basic plank of coalition philosophy. But then, of course, his ignorance is such that he still subscribes to the socialistic belief that all the poor live in the same suburb-a not surprising misconception when one remembers his patrician upbringing.

Yesterday, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) defended Medicare and attacked the Opposition but provided not one word of advice-as he failed again to do today-on how he will overcome the personal sufferings of individuals on hospital waiting lists, which he now admits exist. The only certainty is that he will not let them occupy those empty beds in those hated private hospitals, any more than the Minister for Employment, Education and Training was prepared to simply pay Austudy to those who chose to attend a private university-perhaps for the reason that they could not get into a public one because there were not enough places.

Last night, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) showed some integrity in admitting that his policies had contributed to the disastrous financial situation in the wool industry. But when will the Treasurer wind down the tinted windows of his Commonwealth car and recognise that winning the argument is no solution to saving the economy and reinstating the hopes and aspirations of typical Australians?

When will the Treasurer recognise that the Australian people are entitled to know they have a future? When will he get up here and talk about how he is going to fix things, not just stand up here and deliver his usual insults and refuse to answer questions? When will he recognise that institutionalised labour markets, like other institutionalised marketing systems, have developed to the benefit of the institution, not to the benefit of the people? Put succinctly, when will the Treasurer and this Government give the people a go? When will they stop putting their political survival ahead of the survival of the people? When will they provide Australians with practical policies for the future? If they do not do it soon there will be a complete and utter degradation of the confidence of ordinary Australian people.

Already in my farming electorate I am being told by travellers and others, `I go to places and people are doing nothing. They don't know where to turn. They've dropped their bundle; they're in a vacuum'. If that is to be Australia's way under the Government then we have a real disaster on our hands. Only the people of Australia will fix it and the Government has to give them the encouragement and the assistance to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to contribute this afternoon initially by suggesting that what we have heard from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is a slightly different method of presentation of what is a substantially similar theme. We have seen the quiet approach, the heart-rending, not a dry eye in the House, type of approach in relation to the problems of rural Australia and so on as if there is no recognition on behalf of anyone on the Government side that the recession which Australia presently is in is not causing difficulties.

I would like to cover those specific issues that he has raised in the same quiet, gentle manner in which he approached this matter today, without getting hysterical and without trying to gloss over some of the facts that might otherwise cloud an issue so significant as this.

The first thing I want to do is suggest to him that I, representing an area of the Illawarra region, am pretty well suited to talk about problems of unemployment, to talk about problems created by governments and to talk about issues of great moment with ordinary working class folk in this country. I can remember that youth unemployment was of the order of 30 per cent, directly caused by the policies espoused by those opposite and, incidentally, directed by the present Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) when he was an economic adviser to the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard).

I can also remember that since 1982-83, when structural changes have occurred in the Illawarra, we have seen an improvement in the position only because of what this Government has done. We have seen, for example, the unemployment rate go down to 8.4 per cent-still higher than the national average-but a lot better than it was during the structural devastation that was imposed on the industrial heartland of Australia by those sorts of policies.

We have also heard concern about interest rates and about the problems associated with the person trying to borrow to buy a better quality home. I remind the honourable member for O'Connor-I am sure he recognises that this is the case-that since February of last year, 13 months ago, the Government has released the economic brakes, in terms of interest rate policy, by six percentage points-the big six. What has that been reflected in in terms of what the banks have passed on in terms of mortgage rates? Interest rates have decreased by 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 per cent-2 per cent at best if we are prepared to take a five-year fixed mortgage and then go to something else in the market place.

It is interesting that as late as today, Mr Will Bailey from the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd was talking about the fact that there is still room for a further 1.5 percentage point fall and that that will come by the middle of this year. I ask people like the honourable member for O'Connor, and obviously the honourable member who is going to follow in this debate: if people have been impeded from borrowing money because of interest rates where do they stand now in terms of housing? Where do they stand now in terms of borrowing money to invest in productive capacity in this country? Where do these people stand when it might well be demonstrated that the banks are running a secondary monetary policy in this country, trying to second guess the Government and its advisers? Because of decisions taken by the banks in the past, they have seen themselves burned and burdened with massive debts because people borrow massive amounts of money not to put into productive capacity, unfortunately, but simply to jump on the assets bandwagon.

I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to perhaps give some consideration to how governments-whether it be this Government or even a government of the conservatives-would approach that same position. Would a conservative government try to stop people borrowing? Would it try to stop credit being made available and, if so, what does it say now when employment is down and we are trying to create jobs by hopefully seeing banks being prepared to lend for creative enterprises-job generating creative enterprises-in this country? The other fundamental point which needs to be made right at the outset is the question about policies and the future and what this Government stands for and has stood for in the past. In terms of wages policy-and I know the honourable member for O'Connor and others will probably say that this is repetitious and that they have heard it before, but it is a fact and they cannot escape it-this Government has a wages policy. It has an accord with the trade union movement. If we turn our attention back to the 1983-87 period, we recall that every time there was a national wage case in this country, who opposed it? There are no prizes for guessing the answer-those who are now on the opposition benches of this place. If there was one thing that those on the opposite side of the House were consistent with, it was their opposition to wages, to wage increases and to the national wage cases. But when they come in here and when questions are directed at various spokespeople about wages policy and employment policy, what are we met with-waffle and nothing more. We got a glib press release put out on a Sunday night-a trick probably learned from a former Premier of New South Wales, one suspects-in which they say that we have got to work 40 hours. TALK.START.PARA: —And smarter.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Canning says, Australians have got to work smarter. That is not necessarily to say that we should go back to working 40 or 45 or 50 hours a week. SPEECH.PARA: While wages policy is so fundamental-and we cannot get any idea from members on the other side what they are on about-the other questions concern employment, employment generation and policies there. Due to increasing interest rates, we have been unable to realise our aspirations, despite my return to work part-time between the births of my children, making most of our children's clothes myself, plus forgoing holidays, plus careful purchasing of everyday essentials'.
In yet another case a mother told me, `I wanted to stay home with my child, but this is no longer an option. We will have to look at night shifts and split shifts to have more family time'.

Two days ago the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) detailed the statistics exposing how this recession is affecting small business. Let me tell the House about just one of the thousands in my electorate. Three and a half years ago a family purchased a small business that was a going concern. They upgraded the business with new capital equipment. This business is in a growing area within commuting distance of Melbourne, and was regarded as an exciting and viable venture. Interest rates have forced this enterprise to re-finance. The downturn in the economy has resulted in a loss of trade. Currently it is for sale because the debt burden is just too heavy.

This business, along with others in the town which are all in the same position, have tried innovative means to stimulate business. For example, they have started market days with pony rides and bands in the street, trying to create a carnival atmosphere. As the owners of this and many other small businesses like it have said, `If someone would come along, look at our books and provide us with a formula to further cut overheads and increase trade, we would use it willingly'. But they have already cut overheads to the bone, and they have done everything possible to create more business. There simply is not the money around because people's disposable income has been reduced. They are consumed by a feeling of helplessness and hopelessness.

The rural industry has been particularly devastated. Take, for example, the young couple who began farming 12 years ago with an initial capital of $10,000. They gradually built up a successful property through sheer hard work. However, high interest rates, high tax and increasing costs have eroded this farming enterprise. In order to try to hang on to the property the husband has taken on a small contracting business, and has been forced to work as a barman two nights a week at a local hotel. Again, he has little time to spend with his family and is exhausted when he is at home. As he says, `There is nothing more I can do. I have prided myself on my skills, and yet I know I am going under'.

Another couple, with two children, lived on a 100-acre property purchased some years ago when the off-farm income of the wife was used to help with mortgage payments. The family ran this in conjunction with a larger property. Again, interest rates took their toll, and then the business where the wife was working closed down after 43 years of trading. As a result of the loss of the wife's income, falling commodity prices, increased costs and high interest rates, the farm income was not sufficient to support ongoing living costs and mortgage payments. That family has now separated as a result of living with these financial pressures.

The tragedy of cases like these is that the rural industry stands to lose hundreds of these young farmers. It stands to lose their skills and expertise, which the industry must have in the future in order to survive. Honourable members should remember that the average age of an Australian farmer today is 57.

Many counsellors believe that the hidden damage that is being done to family relationships will be more significant in the long term than the forced sales and evictions. There are numerous examples of personal crises ranging from loss of dignity and self-esteem, lack of self-confidence, increased anxiety states, to increased domestic violence.

Many farmers wives are being left to manage both farm and family while the husband finds off-farm work to sustain the family. The alternative to this is that the wife, especially if she has nursing or teaching qualifications, travels long distances to find employment, while the husband manages at home. In most cases it is the woman who will seek financial counselling, as often the male partner cannot bring himself to do so.

There are also hundreds of examples in my electorate alone of the family allowance being used to buy the family's groceries. The situation has become so tough and there has been such a groundswell of concern that women have been calling public crisis meetings all over the country. The mushrooming of these groups, formed and attended by women who in the main have never spoken out in public before, demonstrates that they know the only way to draw attention to the extent of their problems is by holding public meetings-to put aside their pride and dignity and to bare their souls.

The common thread running through all these cases is that all of these people are trying to improve themselves, trying to make a better life for their families and contribute to the economy. On behalf of the thousands of people like those I have mentioned, I ask the Prime Minister and his Treasurer: when are they going to listen? When are they going to try to understand the depth of the problems facing these people? When are they going to pull their weight and do something to alleviate the suffering? As the owner of one business said to me, `All we want is a decent life. It shouldn't have to be this hard'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to implement and give effect in Australian law to the provisions of the Hague convention on the law applicable to trusts and on their recognition. The Bill will provide machinery for identifying which country's law is to govern a particular trust; and will provide guidelines for the recognition of that trust in accordance with that law.
Background

The convention was adopted at the fifteenth session of the Hague Conference on Private International Law in 1984 as part of its work in promoting the unification of private international law. As a member of the conference, Australia participated actively in its work on the convention. The convention will enter into force after three countries have ratified it (article 30). Although a number of both common law countries, the United States, United Kingdom and Canada, and civil law countries, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, have signed the convention, only the UK and Italy have yet ratified it.

As its name suggests, the Bill deals with the law applicable to trusts and the recognition of trusts. Trusts are essentially an equitable institution which has developed in legal systems based on the English common law-the concept of a trust is generally not used in civil law systems based on the roman law model. A trust may be described as an equitable obligation which binds a person, called a trustee, to deal with some specific property, the trust property, for the benefit of persons, called the beneficiaries, or for the advancement of some specific purpose. In the common law world trusts have been developed to serve a variety of functions, ranging from charitable purposes and estate planning to vehicles of commerce.

The convention is intended to overcome potential conflicts of laws problems which may arise where aspects of a trust-such as its assets, beneficiaries or trustees-have connections with more than one jurisdiction. If the trust concept is not recognised in one of those jurisdictions, as is the case in civil law jurisdictions, the very existence and validity of the trust may be in doubt. Even among common law jurisdictions which recognise trusts, there may sometimes be different rules for ascertaining the law to govern the trust and its incidents. The convention provides a common regime of rules governing both the recognition of trusts and the determination of which law is applicable to the trust.

The convention is largely for the benefit of common law countries such as Australia, in that it requires civil law countries to recognise a purely common law institution while conferring benefits on common law countries or their citizens who are likely to be beneficiaries of a trust. There will be no incentive for civil law countries to be party to the convention if common law countries are seen to lack interest in it. For this reason, early implementation of the convention in Australia is desirable, to enable accession in the near future.
Provisions of the Convention

The schedule to the Bill reproduces the convention, which is divided into chapters and articles. Chapter I outlines the scope of the convention and defines whether something is a trust covered by the convention.

Chapter II identifies the national law applicable to any particular trust. Prima facie the governing law is the law chosen expressly or impliedly by the settlor, that is, the person creating the trust. Where no choice is made, the governing law is the law of the country with which the trust is most closely connected. These rules will serve to clarify existing choice of law rules, which are far from clear.

Chapter III deals with the extent to which a trust is to be recognised in accordance with the applicable law by states that become parties to the convention. Such recognition involves, as a minimum, that the trust property exists as a separate holding and that the trustee may bring and defend proceedings in his or her capacity as trustee. As a separate holding, the trust property will have a legal existence separate from other property in general and from the trustee's own property in particular. Thus, the trustee's personal creditors will not have any recourse to the trust property, though that property may be held in the name of the trustee.

Chapter IV contains a number of general articles, several of which limit the effect of the convention in particular circumstances, where there are good reasons either for a trust not being recognised at all or for the governing law determined in accordance with the convention being ignored in favour of some other law.
Chapter V contains final articles dealing with signature, ratification, accession, reservations and entry into force of the convention.
Advantages of Implementation for Australia

The Bill will enable Australia to ratify the convention and, once the convention enters into force, to bring its provisions into force for Australia. The major advantage of the convention arises when property subject to a trust is located within the jurisdiction of a civil law contracting state to the convention. The practical effect of Australia acceding to the convention would be that the true ownership of Australian trust property in the territory of a civil law party would be recognised and respected.

At present, the law governing a trust with aspects extending over more than one jurisdiction is determined in Australia by common law rules of conflicts of laws. The convention is largely consistent with the Australian common law rules of conflicts of laws. Adoption of the convention would not require amendment of existing Australian statute law and would not cause substantial changes to existing Australian law.

In particular, the convention would not impose new obligations on Australian courts to give effect to fraudulent or otherwise `undesirable' trusts. The convention provides merely for the determination of which law applies to a trust. Moreover, the convention allows precedence to be given to a contracting state's public policy (Article 18), mandatory laws relating to insolvency, succession, transfer of property, exchange controls, protection of cultural property, et cetera (Articles 15 and 16) and exercises of a contracting state's fiscal powers (Article 19).
Scope of Application of Commonwealth Legislation

The Commonwealth legislation will apply the convention only to `international' trusts, where the law of a foreign country is potentially applicable, and not extend it to solely domestic or `interstate' trusts to which the law of another Australian State or Territory is potentially applicable. The convention specifically allows a federal state to refrain from applying the convention to conflicts of laws between its territorial units (Article 24). The Commonwealth legislation would not prevent States and Territories from themselves legislating, as some have indicated an interest in doing, to apply the rules of the convention to `interstate' trusts. The Commonwealth legislation is quite simple, merely adopting in Australia the terms of the convention subject to the reservation regarding non-applicability as between Australian States and Territories.
Commonwealth-State Implications

Within Australia trusts are generally a matter of State/Territory law and the convention could be implemented in Australia either by uniform State/Territory legislation or by Commonwealth legislation. As the convention has no effect on statute law, has the minimal possible effect on common law conflict of laws rules and is essentially concerned with international trusts, the Government has decided that it would be most simply and conveniently implemented by Commonwealth legislation.

The convention was considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in 1987 and the States and Territories have accepted this course of action. It is understood that the States and Territories, or some of them, might later enact legislation to apply the rules of the convention to `interstate' trusts.
Conclusion

The choice of law rules in the convention are very similar to the existing common law choice of law rules. The qualifications on recognition contained in the convention may appear to detract from the value of the convention to common law countries, but they were essential in order for the civil law countries to agree to the draft convention and their existence will be of prime importance in persuading such countries to ratify the convention. The convention's value is that it establishes a framework and scheme for recognition of trusts and perhaps also an expectation of their recognition. Its adoption will result in a substantial improvement over the present situation.
Financial Impact Statement
The Trust (Hague Convention) Bill will have no impact on Commonwealth revenue or expenditure. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and I commend the Bill to the House.

The Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees, commonly referred to as Comcare, was established in July 1988 to effectively manage the Commonwealth public sector workers' compensation function. Comcare operates under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. This legislation introduced income related benefits and emphasised Comcare's role in the prevention of workplace injury and disease through improved occupational health and safety practices and the rehabilitation of injured workers.

The legislation also introduced Comcare's premium system, which commenced on 1 July 1989. The premium system is a key element in Comcare's strategy to control the cost of workers compensation in the Commonwealth sector by making agencies financially accountable for compensation costs as well as providing them with incentives to develop effective accident prevention and rehabilitation strategies. The scheme is fully funded. That is, the premiums received by Comcare in a particular year are calculated so that they cover the full cost of injuries sustained during that year over the life of those claims. The premiums are also responsive to changes in an agency's performance from year to year. Managers are financially accountable for the full cost of injuries occurring in any year.
The Bill proposes new provisions dealing with the calculation, approval and payment of premiums to improve and streamline these procedures.
Broadly, the new premium system is similar in structure to the existing provisions of the Act dealing with the calculation, approval and payment of contributions.

Currently, however, the Act is too restrictive and inflexible to accommodate the financial concerns of both Comcare and departments and authorities. The proposed amendments expand and clarify the existing features of this system and set out the procedures involved in the calculation, approval, review and payment of premiums in a more logical and complete way.

Under the proposed new provisions Comcare is to reduce a premium if payment is made early or increase a premium if payment is deferred or made by instalment. This will maintain a fully funded scheme and will also enable departments and authorities to nominate methods of payment which are best suited to their needs, whilst providing an incentive for early payment and compensating Comcare for deferred payment or payment by instalment.

In addition to the changes to the provisions relating to premiums, which I am confident will benefit all participants, the Bill makes a number of amendments of a technical nature. Currently Comcare may only invest temporarily surplus funds in excess of $100,000 with the approval of the Minister. This is an unnecessarily inconvenient situation. The proposed amendments will remedy this problem and operate retrospectively to the date of commencement of the Act to ensure that past transactions cannot be called into doubt.

Other amendments included in the Bill are intended to improve the operation of the Act by clarifying certain transitional provisions and correcting some errors and omissions. The need for the amendments has become apparent since the commencement of the Act on 1 December 1988.

For example, an amendment is included which will ensure that employees who were entitled to compensation under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 will remain entitled to compensation under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 without having to satisfy the liability tests in that Act.

A further amendment will ensure that employees who were parties to proceedings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the day on which the Act commenced, or who incur costs as a result of an appeal by the Commonwealth against a decision of the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees, will be entitled to recover their costs.
The amendments relating to premiums have no financial implications. The remaining amendments will not have a significant financial impact.
Amendments to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973
The Bill also proposes a number of amendments to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 and consequential amendments to other Acts. These are contained in parts 3 and 4 of the Bill.

The principal function of the Remuneration Tribunal is to inquire into and recommend or determine the salaries of specified categories of office holders, including Ministers of State, senior public sector office holders and the Federal judiciary. The Tribunal comprises three part time members appointed by the Governor-General for periods not exceeding five years. It is particularly important that there is flexibility to appoint Tribunal members with appropriate knowledge and experience, including an appreciation of current industrial relations issues and government administration. Currently, however, a person who has been a member of parliament, a public servant, a holder of a public office or a holder of Federal judicial office is precluded from appointment to the Tribunal for a period of seven years.

The existing seven-year disqualification period has created difficulties in finding replacement members of the Tribunal with the necessary skills and experience to enable them to operate effectively. Members of the tribunal are required to have regard to the wage fixing principles of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and therefore need to be cognisant of the principles of contemporary wage fixing arrangements. Accordingly, a more flexible provision is required. An amendment is therefore proposed to the Act to reduce the disqualification period from seven years to one year.

The independence and impartiality of the Remuneration Tribunal must, however, be preserved. It is, therefore, proposed that the reduction in the disqualification period be balanced by the insertion of a new disclosure of conflict of interest provision. The provision will require a member of the Tribunal to disclose any pecuniary or other interests which could conflict with the proper performance of the member's functions in relation to Tribunal proceedings. The provision will reflect the position which, I am sure, would quite properly be taken by a Tribunal member if he or she was in such a position. In view of the changes proposed to the disqualification provision it is desirable to make explicit what might formerly be considered to have been implicit. Such provisions are commonly found in Commonwealth legislation relating to other Federal tribunals.

Under the amendment the privacy of Tribunal members is, however, preserved. The disclosure is to be made in writing to either the Chairman of the Tribunal or to the Minister, depending on which member is concerned, and not to the parties to any relevant matter.

The Bill also includes amendments to extend the jurisdiction of the Tribunal to determine the recreation leave entitlements of full time holders of certain senior public offices, on the same basis as that of fixed term senior public servants. The amendments follow a recommendation in a special report of the Remuneration Tribunal. Currently, holders of these offices are granted recreation leave but do not accrue an entitlement to a specific quantum. This has the consequence that an office holder who ceases to hold an office is not entitled to be compensated for accrued leave not taken on the basis applicable to Government employees generally. Longstanding practice is to make ex gratia payments on this basis.

The amendment will facilitate payments to office holders in respect of recreation leave accrued but unused on cessation of office. It may therefore result in some minor cost to the Commonwealth. This cannot be readily calculated, because it is wholly dependent on leave actually taken by office-holders.

These amendments are cast so that the new provisions will operate only where consequential amendments are made to the Acts establishing the relevant offices. The schedule to the Bill makes appropriate consequential amendments to a large number of those Acts. An amendment to the Remuneration Tribunal Act is also proposed to enable the remuneration of the Vice Chief of the Defence Force to be determined by the Tribunal, complementing the provisions of section 9B of the Defence Act 1903.

Further amendments will clarify the jurisdiction of the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to certain offices in higher education institutions. The Tribunal was given this jurisdiction when the Academic Salaries Tribunal was abolished on the commencement of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. As a consequence of the transfer of part of the jurisdiction of the Academic Salaries Tribunal to the Remuneration Tribunal, some ambiguities have arisen in the relevant provisions of the Remuneration Tribunal Act. Clarifying amendments are proposed to ensure that the original intention behind the legislation is reflected in the Act.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988. Among other things, that Act provides for the Higher Education Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training to report to Parliament on the operation of educational profiles and the impact of the higher education contribution scheme. Educational profiles are a mechanism designed to balance the freedom of institutions to manage their own affairs with the need for public accountability. They represent agreements negotiated annually between the Commonwealth and higher education institutions, defining an institution's broad mission together with its teaching and research responsibilities, and establishing its particular areas of activity and specified goals as the basis on which institutions receive Commonwealth funding.

The Higher Education Contribution Scheme, which came into operation in 1989, requires students and graduates to make a contribution towards some of the costs of the provision of their studies. At the time of the scheme's inception, a provision was inserted in the Employment, Education and Training Act requiring the Higher Education Council, in February and August of each year, to report to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, and thence to the Minister and Parliament, on the operation of the scheme and its effects on access to higher education and the level and quality of post-graduate research.

This Bill amends that provision by requiring the Council to report only once each year, in March. The need for this amendment is straightforward. Late in 1990 the Board reported that the Council had experienced practical difficulties in reporting in a substantive way in August. At that time of the year, no firm data relating to higher education student enrolments in the current year is available, and the educational profiles discussions with institutions are not undertaken until later in the calendar year.

Accordingly, the Board proposed that the Council need report only once in each year, both on profiles processes and the impact of the higher education contribution scheme. March was recommended as the most appropriate month. By that time final student enrolment data can be comprehensively analysed and the Council is in a position to comment substantively on the recently concluded profiles negotiations. The Employment, Education and Training Act also provides for the Minister to appoint acting members of the Board and its constituent councils for a period of up to 12 months in the event of a temporary vacancy.

The intent of the Act was to provide for the circumstances where it is necessary for the Minister to appoint an acting member of a constituent council who is also a member of the Board. Under the legislation as it currently stands, this option is not available to the Minister in all circumstances. The amendments are designed to remedy this deficiency and have no substantive policy or other implications. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
