TALK.START.PARA: —I referred earlier to the Opposition's failure to recognise the complete social security picture, and yet another example of that was its failure to support the introduction of an assets test on the family allowance. The coalition's move to overturn the introduction of an assets test on the family allowance has led to a loss of savings of some $57m in 1991-92. This fiscally irresponsible decision stems from pressure brought to bear by assets-rich interest groups. It is a blatant attempt by the Opposition and others to gain political favour with self-interested farmers and businessmen.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, it is the disadvantaged members of our society, not the privileged, who will suffer most from this action. I ask this question of the Opposition: if it is going to persist in directing social security payments to millionaires, where is it going to find the reported $1 billion it claims it could save from social security? Will it cut age pensions or force the unemployed to beg on the streets?

The family allowance is already income tested. Income alone, however, is not the only measure of a family's ability to support itself, particularly families who have substantial assets and are able to minimise their taxable incomes. Introducing an assets test on the family allowance would have brought it into line with other Commonwealth transfer payments. Pensions, benefits, family allowance supplement and Austudy are all subject to assets tests. The assets test proposed by this Government was generous by community standards. An asset level of $500,000 would not have disadvantaged families in genuine need, particularly as assets would have been assessed net of debt and would have excluded the family home.

In refusing to support the introduction of an assets test on the family allowance late last year, the Opposition missed a golden opportunity to put real support behind the stand it is taking today down the road of genuine social security reform. In contrast, the Government by its stand at that time demonstrated that it has the courage to take tough decisions while protecting disadvantaged groups in our society. Through its stand, the Opposition clearly reveals its priorities in the social welfare area.

Then, of course, there are the gross social inequities which would exist under the Opposition's proposed consumption tax. We need only look at the figures to see the enormous gap that would develop between the rich and the poor under the tax regime proposed by honourable members opposite, the centrepiece of which is a consumption tax. Such a tax and its accompanying impact on inflation would have particularly dire effects for low income earners.

So there we have it: the Liberal rhetoric through its support for the rewrite of the social security framework proposed in this legislation alongside its record in elements affecting the people who make up that framework. One certain thing for Australia's social security beneficiaries from this conflict, though, is that they will all be left a little confused-and well they might be. But they are not the only ones. In a radio interview on 18 October 1990 between Pru Goward and Dr Peter Saunders, Director of the Social Policy Research Centre at the University of New South Wales, Dr Saunders said of the plans of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to lease out social security services:

Well I found Dr Hewson's remarks somewhat strange because he talked on one hand about duplication and yet then made comments about the Department of Social Security. And the first thing I think we have to recognise is that the Department of Social Security is not in the business, by and large, in providing social welfare services; it's in the business of paying pension and benefit cheques and therefore the issue of duplication is . . . not in the social security area.
The President of the Australian Council of Social Service, Merle Mitchell, also had something to say about the proposal in an article in the Australian of 18 October 1990:
Dr Hewson cannot have it both ways. He cannot advocate greater targeting and time limits on payment of unemployment benefits.

It would appear that it is not only the Government's view that the Leader of the Opposition is quite a distance from the coalface he referred to so often when expanding on his proposal in interviews at that time. I suggest that if the Leader of the Opposition were to have a closer look at the coalface, he would then see the real benefits of a united and coordinated national social security system.

The specialists do not like the idea of privatising the provision of social security benefits, the peak social services body does not like it and, given the Pandora's box it would open for the privacy of social security beneficiaries, I do not think they would like it too much either. So while the Opposition continues to advocate that all and sundry should determine eligibility and distribute social welfare, it is hard to see how honourable members opposite can claim to have any genuine conviction about the better provision of services for those most in need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Bill 1990 is a major codification of social security legislation. For that reason, it is particularly significant. The Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, in his second reading speech also made some interesting observations when he said that since 1947 the Act had been subjected to over 100 amending Bills. He omitted to point out that between 1987 and 1988 and up to the present time under the administration of his own Government, and principally under his own administration as Minister for Social Security, there have been, in effect, over 200 administrative and legislative changes to the Social Security Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it any wonder that many people have great difficulty understanding legislation that is often seen to be out of date and for which it is very difficult to get the most accurate version? Having got that version, one often cannot understand it. Consequently, the Opposition supports the intention of the Government to introduce a piece of legislation that is both easy to read and easy to follow. Using the vernacular, it is said to be simple English legislation. There are a number of points I wish to make about the construction of this document, and I then want to go on to a wider discussion of some of the principles of the Government's policies in relation to social security in particular.

The review of social security legislation and its incorporation in one Bill of three volumes, while being a considerable reform in that administrative context, will hopefully be of some benefit to officers in the Department operating at the coalface. It should assist some beneficiaries and, hopefully, it will help welfare agencies involved in providing advice. The question I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), who is at the table, is this: are we to conclude that the Government intends to provide free copies to welfare agencies? On the charging policy of the Australian Government Publishing Service at the present time-in March 1990 the old Act would have cost $43.80-this vast document we are now talking about on the basis of weight alone, which seems to be the basic principle of the AGPS in its pricing policy, will cost at least $100.

It is not unreasonable to ask the Minister: how can poor, unemployed people who are not the normal beneficiaries of the welfare system-and do not forget we are talking about in excess of four million people who are receiving benefits through the Department of Social Security at present-benefit from this `easy English' version of this vast document which is bigger than a Sydney telephone book?

Not only should the Social Security Act be reviewed but the entire system of social welfare payments in Australia should also be reviewed with the intention of trying to simplify the mechanisms of delivery to ensure they are more effective. In his second reading speech, the Minister referred to the original 1947 Act. He said:

. . . the Act depicted a passive payment mechanism, providing benefits in the form of direct cash payments to clients. It has now become more attuned, because of the many recent amendments, to the changing social and economic environment through its development into a more active piece of legislation that targets individuals and families in genuine need while positively encouraging them toward independence of the welfare system.

Honourable members should remember those words: `targets individuals and families in genuine need' and `independence of the welfare system'. Yet during Question Time earlier today the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a very straightforward question. He asked the Prime Minister whether in his discussions with the Brotherhood of St Laurence-which is notable across Australia, especially in Victoria, as being the quintessential organisation involved in welfare at the non-government level-he had asked that organisation which people were in the most abject poverty in Australia. The answer was the 6,000 homeless children under the age of 16 years.

The Leader of the Opposition went on to ask a very pertinent question of the Prime Minister: `Since you have an annual Budget of about $30 billion, why is it so difficult for you to accurately target 6,000 homeless kids? Is it because they are on the streets with no fixed address?'. The Prime Minister said, `Yes, that could possibly be the answer'. But it is obviously more than that. It simply demonstrates that this vast administrative system, with this telephone book policy document, plus two vast documents, which every office of the Department has to administer and interpret as to whether individual payments should be made, is clearly incapable of identifying and helping 6,000 homeless children, most of whom probably are in Melbourne.

I therefore enter the debate with a little degree of cynicism as to precisely what the Government means when it talks about better targeting and achieving greater independence of the welfare system. We have been using words like `greater independence of the welfare system' but, unlike the Australian Labor Party, that is precisely what we mean. We want to keep people out of welfare and from regarding welfare as a crutch to be used forever-or, more precisely, that once one gets into the welfare net it is so difficult to get out.

In the last two days we have heard Ministers during Question Time talk about poverty traps. Earlier today we heard the Prime Minister suggest-when he was asked questions by members of the Opposition on how he would refer to individual cases of hardship caused by the failure of the Government's economic and social policies and what he would say to those people-`Under the Opposition's social policy you will get unemployment benefits for nine months and then you are thrown to the wolves. Under our policy you can have unemployment benefits more or less forever'.

If the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security cares to study the statistics, as I certainly have, he will see that there is a not inconsiderable number of beneficiaries who have been on unemployment benefits for 10 years or longer. Why is that? Why has the system been so loose that people have been able to remain there? Why are they still getting benefits from the system when they have fallen through the net in the sense that there is a pro-active capacity to assist those people to get back into the work force?

Perhaps the most damming statistics of all are the current figures of unemployment in Australia today. In December 1989 there were 366,666 beneficiaries of unemployment benefits. In December 1990-2 years later-the figure had risen to 506,004. The latest figures of January 1991 reveal that the number has risen to 542,148. So in that short period the number of people on unemployment benefits had risen 7.1 per cent-and we all know that the rate currently is well over 8 per cent.

Most observers and commentators on this unfortunate situation would add that we have probably not yet seen the worst and that the rate of unemployment may well reach 10 per cent. There is a tendency in certain parts of the community, and certainly in the Australian Labor Party, to simply take the view, `I am all right Jack, I am one of the 90 per cent who has a job, so I do not need to worry about the 10 per cent who do not'. In the present situation of a rolling recession-and that is how it has been rightly described by the Leader of the Opposition-nobody can be sure of their future employment continuity. For that reason, it is absolutely vital that we do not talk only in terms of what we do to help people who are unemployed today, important though that may be, but also have the courage of our convictions to examine precisely why those half a million people are out of work-people who two years ago had some optimism about the future.

I refer to a press release issued by the Australian Council of Social Service, another organisation which Government members claim supports the Government's social welfare policies-their great concept of compassion and concern. In its release on 23 January this year under the headline `Unemployed Young People: Tough Times, Less Help', Mel Mitchell said:

There are now 130,000 young people without jobs and not in full-time education. Despite the increased numbers staying on at school, the total number of unemployed young people is almost as high as the worst of the 1982/83 recession and the situation is likely to deteriorate further.
The release went on to say:
The amount of spending on job training for unemployed young people has plunged by more than two-thirds over the last six years.
The release goes on to say that the programs that have been of the greatest help to young job-seekers are no longer in place.

The important thing is that the Government's employment policies are fundamentally flawed because it has tried to use, with considerable incompetence, the mechanism of welfare as a substitute for industrial relations policies directed at fundamental reform of the Australian labour market. Together with that, one also has to raise the question of the incompetence of the Government and its inability over eight years to introduce the range of structural reforms which are so fundamentally important.

I learned only yesterday a most interesting story-that it is cheaper to take wheat from Turkey to New Zealand than it is to take wheat from Australia to New Zealand. It is extraordinary that our nearest neighbour cannot purchase a commodity like wheat from Australia because the costs of our shipping, the costs of getting wheat through the docks and the costs of transportation preclude us from markets with our closest neighbours-and that is just one small example. Transportation and communication are all the same. The years have been going by us and so little, if anything, has been done.

Because of these structural inefficiencies, today men and women by their thousands are paying the inevitable price. They could well say, `Why me? I had a job; I worked hard; I did what I could and all of a sudden my company has gone bust'. Why is it that a company such as Black &Decker (Australia) Pty Ltd, which on international terms was an efficient operation, has had to announce in the last month that it will close its production in Australia? It is because it can no longer compete. Interestingly enough, the company did not pick industrial relations or wage issues as its principal concern. It said it was transportation. It was those structural problems within the economy which made it impossible for it to be able to compete on world markets.

This Government tends to fail to realise so often that many of these larger conglomerate companies have subsidiaries all over the world. Often they are competing with each other in markets that should be Australian markets. Every time we lose an Australian market we are losing jobs. If it is the intention of this Government to export our jobs to Taiwan, Korea, Singapore or to any other country, let it be prepared to say to the Australian people that that is its policy. Its failure to address these fundamental issues means that that can be the only final outcome of what it is doing.

The situation is now critical and the time for change has to be with us. When we look at social policy in the main I ask the Government to consider precisely what it means in terms of delivery of programs as distinct from mere words. There are millions of them in these documents here today.

The Opposition believes that there are three fundamental principles which must be at the base of any viable social security policy. Those principles are, firstly, that assistance must be provided in a manner which maintains self-respect in the recipients and encourages and supports their quest for personal independence. The second principle encourages self-reliance by targeting programs carefully and minimising poverty traps. The third principle ensures that all Australians in need receive adequate, timely and appropriate assistance.

On all of those three counts one can say that the record over the last eight years leaves the Government with much to explain. The realities simply are that the welfare system in Australia, consuming, as I said, over $30 billion provided by the taxpayers of Australia, is no longer capable of delivering the quality of services necessary, especially to those most in need.

A number of years ago a Committee composed of members of this Parliament, chaired by a member of the Government, tabled a report in this House entitled Fairness, courtesy and efficiency in the quality of service provided by the Department of Social Security. I was on that inquiry, as was the Parliamentary Secretary at the table. It was interesting to go to the coalface and hear from the non-government agencies and people who had to deal with the Government what it was like to be on the other side of the picture.

Out of that inquiry we made a range of recommendations which, sadly, ran into all sorts of troubles within the Department and excuses for non-observance. The statement tabled in this House by the Minister on that occasion will stand as an example of how to miss the point. Among the recommendations we made was the need to improve the skills of departmental staff and to insist that all clients of the Department be treated with courtesy and respect, because so often they said that was not the case.

We emphasised the need to simplify the system and to enhance service delivery. We talked about requiring more accurate assessment of client needs and entitlements before benefits were granted. We talked about improving access for those with special difficulties, such as Aboriginal people, non-English speaking people, the illiterate, the young, the physically and mentally handicapped and those living in remote areas.

As I said earlier in my speech, the fact that we cannot accurately identify 6,000 homeless kids living in Melbourne-having been identified by the Brotherhood of St Laurence as being those most in need-would seriously bring into question the capacity of the Department to carry out that fundamental responsibility. We also talked about the need to establish regional community consultative committees which should meet regularly so there is an interchange between the welfare agencies in the communities, the departments and the Commonwealth Employment Service working with the people who were in need within those specific communities.

We talked about the need to examine the development of a single application form which would initially screen clients and assist in determining the appropriate category of payments. I hope I am mistaken but when I looked into this matter last year I was told that that question about a common form was all too difficult. I would sincerely like to know why that cannot be achieved.

In addition, the question of aged people, who are a major component of the delivery cycle of the Department, needs to be considered. I think there is a very strong argument that pensioners should get more sympathetic service. They should be assured of receiving correct information and they should be given the opportunity to deal with their peer group. In this House on previous occasions I have strongly suggested that the Department should appoint mature part-time specialist staff, including retirees, who could assist pensioners, in particular, at regional offices of the Department so that they would feel that they were dealing with people who had some empathy with their problems. Time and time again we are told that when dealing with a young person of 19 or 20 there is a gulf between a pensioner or an older person which simply cannot be bridged in so many cases. These are merely a range of the sorts of issues which have yet to be addressed and which cannot be adequately solved simply by the production of a vast tome of the type being debated in the House at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, we have before the House the Family Law Amendment Bill 1990. I understand the Government will be moving some 13 amendments to this Bill. The Bill has had a somewhat chequered history, having been introduced in May last year, brought on for debate in December with a string of Government amendments, and then withdrawn at the last minute. The comments that I make on the Bill take into account the changes that have been made by the Government amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons for the on again, off again approach that the Government has adopted in relation to this Bill is that it has now engaged in rather extensive consultations with various groups who have an interest in family law, and who will be affected by the changes to be brought about by the Bill. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and his Department, by carrying out lengthy consultations, have endeavoured to produce a workable solution to the dilemmas that arise from that most sensitive and controversial subject-namely, child sexual abuse.

For the sake of the record, I should point out that I have had some limited involvement in the process of consultation. By a letter dated 3 August last year, I advised the Attorney of a number of concerns I had with the way the Bill, as introduced, was drafted. Those concerns focused on proposed section 70BB, a provision which I will discuss in more detail shortly. I was pleased with the positive response I received from the Attorney-General, in that many of my concerns are being addressed in the amendments that the Government will be moving today.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good bloke.
—A good bloke, yes. A mug punter, but a good fellow-and in that I am only agreeing with the honourable member's leader! He is also a great judge of footballers!

SPEECH.PARA: The consultation that the Attorney-General has undertaken in relation to the Bill is to be commended. Having buttered him up, I now point out that this stands in stark contrast to the position that he took in relation to the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Bill, which we debated last week, where it appeared that the Attorney neglected to consult even Federal law enforcement agencies about the changes contained within that legislation. But that was not the case on this occasion, and he and the Department are to be commended. It was one of those rare occasions where a Bill came in, a series of amendments were moved and the Bill was then withdrawn-for the distinct purpose of consultation. I want to place on record my appreciation that that consultation occurred.

The Bill under present consideration attempts to address a number of complex and sensitive problems in the family law area. However, I have a very real concern that in doing so it could well be-notwithstanding the consultations-that in some instances the Bill creates more anomalies than it seeks to overcome.

Before discussing those parts of the Bill which are a cause of concern, I will give a brief outline of its major elements which can be divided, broadly speaking, into four areas. First, the Bill contains a number of provisions to be inserted into the Family Law Act, which aim to improve the handling of custody and access disputes in which allegations of child abuse are made by one party against another. The genesis of these provisions can be found in the report of the Family Law Council entitled Child Sexual Abuse. The relevant clauses are clause 12, which sets up a procedure for reporting cases of child abuse to State and Territory child welfare authorities; clause 14, which provides that child welfare authorities and other interested persons may intervene in cases involving allegations of child abuse; clause 17, which will limit the number of medical and psychological examinations of children which can be obtained by parents involved in custody and access disputes; and clause 15, which will give statutory force to the Family Court's practice of admitting hearsay evidence of statements made by children to adults about abuse they have allegedly suffered.

Secondly, by reason of clauses 5, 6 and 7, the Bill will provide that a step-parent adoption does not put an end to existing custody, guardianship or access rights under the Act, unless the Family Court decides that the step-parent adoption is in the child's best interests. Thirdly, by virtue of clauses 8, 10 and 11, Family Court consent orders or registered child agreements will have no effect in so far as they purport to transfer custody or guardianship to non-parents. Finally, there are a number of miscellaneous amendments, one example of which includes clause 19, which will empower the police, when authorised to arrest a person, to enter and search premises for the wanted person.

The provisions that are of concern to us in the Opposition are clause 12, especially in so far as it puts forward a proposal for the mandatory reporting of suspected child abuse; clause 14, which relates to intervention by third parties in certain proceedings; and clause 15, dealing with the admission of hearsay evidence.

I shall deal first with the proposal contained in the Bill for the mandatory reporting of suspecting child abuse cases. If we look at the Bill in the light of the amendments the Government will be moving, we see that the reporting procedure essentially is divided into three parts. First, under proposed new section 70ba, where a party to proceedings alleges that a child has been abused or is at risk of abuse that party must file a prescribed notice with the Court. Upon the filing of the prescribed notice, the Registrar of the Court must, as soon as practicable, notify State or Territory child welfare authorities.

Secondly, under proposed new subsection 70bb (1), where court personnel, who under the amendments are defined to include court counsellors, welfare officers and registrars of the Court, have reasonable grounds for suspecting that a child has been abused or is at risk of being abused, they must-I emphasise must-as soon as practicable notify the relevant child welfare authorities of both the suspicion and the basis for that suspicion. The obligation to report in that situation is confined to abuse of the type defined in clause 4 which, as amended, means an assault, including a sexual assault or sexual activity defined with reference to the unequal relationship between the assailant and the alleged victim.

Thirdly, under proposed new subsection 70bb (2), where court personnel have reasonable grounds for suspecting that abuse of a type involving either the ill-treatment of a child or exposure of the child to behaviour which psychologically harms the child, they may make an appropriate report to child welfare authorities.

So we see that under proposed new section 70bb there is a distinction between mandatory reporting and discretionary reporting, depending on the type of abuse that is suspected to have occurred. In support of a proposal to introduce mandatory reporting, one could say that as a matter of policy it reinforces the law's commitment to the protection of children. Furthermore, it can be argued that a system of mandatory reporting encourages community awareness of the issue and transforms a moral obligation into a legal obligation. Finally, it is sometimes said that a system of mandatory reporting may serve a general deterrent function.

On the other hand, critics of mandatory reporting point out that legislating for such a procedure avoids the real issue of the need to provide adequate follow-up resources and procedures. The approach in Victoria of universal voluntary reporting has been applauded by many for increasing community awareness and responsibility whereas the system proposed in this Bill, in my view, places undue emphasis upon court personnel.

Furthermore, experience in jurisdictions that have mandatory reporting has undoubtedly shown that quite often baseless reports can be made. I know that the Attorney-General has agonised over this and that is why I try to put arguments both for and against. Both of us have practised in this field, and I know that others in the House have shared what the Attorney and I have encountered, clients who make allegations or against whom people make allegations-allegations which, frankly, after investigation have been found to be utterly baseless. It is a very sensitive and very personal area which is difficult to follow up and even more difficult to prove.

There is the well publicised example of the Butler-Sloss inquiry into the Cleveland cases in England, which recommended that the relevant mandatory reporting system be abolished. In the case of M v. M, a report of which can be found in volume 12 of the Family Law Reports at page 606, the High Court of Australia acknowledged this very problem. At page 610, in a unanimous judgment, the Court said that sexual abuse of a child is `an allegation which is very easy to make but difficult to refute'.

Finally, it is arguable that mandatory reporting may discourage parties from seeking assistance and further inhibit the amicable resolution of disputes. Now, as I have indicated, this is quite clearly a complex and sensitive issue, and it is one over which right-minded people may often disagree. However, I am clearly of the view that the arguments against mandatory reporting far outweigh those in favour. There are others who take the same view. In an article by Prue Innes in the Melbourne Age of 6 December 1990, Ms Innes, who I am led to believe is a highly regarded journalist in this area, quoted a leading family law specialist as saying that many practitioners object to mandatory reporting `because it takes away what has always been the totally sacrosanct nature of confidential counselling'.

Furthermore, I have strong reservations about the approach adopted by the Bill in so far as it attempts to split mandatory and discretionary reporting according to the type of abuse alleged to have taken place. Quite often it may be that court personnel will not be in a position to ascertain the exact nature of the suspected abuse and, therefore, there may be some doubt as to whether it falls within the mandatory or discretionary limbs of those provisions.

The Law Council of Australia has expressed a concern with another aspect of these provisions. There is little indication in the Bill as to what role the Court should take in these sorts of cases. Once a report has been made to the relevant child welfare authority there is no prescribed procedure in the Bill for the results of any investigations carried out by the welfare authority being in some way remitted to the Family Court. In this respect it is obvious that the making of such allegations and any subsequent investigations will have a very significant impact on the Family Court proceedings.

Accordingly, the Law Council has suggested that reports should, in the first instance, be made to the Court rather than directly to child welfare authorities. If that path is followed, the Law Council argues, the Family Court judge will be in a position to make appropriate directions as to the conduct of the proceedings. The Law Council points out also that such a procedure would allow for some appropriate vetting of such reports. I would appreciate hearing the Attorney's views on these matters. It seems to me that the Law Council has put forward a very plausible case in support of its proposal.

There are two aspects of the drafting of proposed new section 70bb that I find somewhat curious. If we look at proposed new subsection (3), taking into account the amendments the Government will move, we see that court personnel need not `notify a prescribed Child Welfare Authority that a child has been abused, or is at risk of being abused' where they believe that the authority has previously been notified about such abuse or risk of abuse. The subsection then goes on to say that, notwithstanding this dispensation a member `may notify the Authority of his or her suspicions'.

If we contrast that drafting with proposed subsections (1) and (2) we see that court personnel, in the relevant situations mentioned in these subsections, are obliged to notify child welfare authorities of `his or her suspicion and the basis for the suspicion'. I emphasise the words `and the basis for the suspicion'. Perhaps there is a drafting error with proposed new subsection (3) and after the word `notify' there should be the words `of his or her suspicion and the basis for the suspicion'.

The other aspect which troubles me relates to proposed new subsection (5), which provides that where a notice has been given under proposed new subsection (3) the person may disclose `other information' which the person thinks the child welfare authorities should be aware of. If the child welfare authority has already, firstly, been notified of the suspicion and, secondly, notified of the basis of that suspicion, I ask: what other information is it envisaged will be disclosed under this provision? So in the committee stage of the debate we will be moving a number of amendments to proposed new section 70bb to address the concerns I have just raised.

I now turn to clause 15, which seeks to introduce a new section 100a into the Act to expressly allow the court to admit hearsay evidence of statements made by children to adults about abuse they have suffered-or are alleged to have suffered. The proposed section is not confined to oral communications and when we look at the definition of the relevant word, `representation', we see that it includes an express or implied representation, whether oral or in writing, and a representation inferred from conduct. Making inroads into the rule against hearsay evidence is, to put it mildly, a very serious matter. The Law Council has strong reservations about this provision. In its submission on the Bill it said:

Regarding clause 15 the Law Council has concerns that this provision may create dangers in the Court making the decision on ``Evidence'' which has hitherto been regarded as unreliable. The dangers of this probably outweigh the extension of the present rules which did permit some hearsay evidence.

In its report on child sexual abuse, the Family Law Council noted that the law on whether evidence can be given of statements made outside the courtroom by children is in a very uncertain state. In some cases the courts have been prepared to admit such evidence, but the basis for doing so is unclear. The Council went on to recommend that the hearsay rule should not apply to exclude evidence of statements made by children on matters relating directly to their welfare. In making this recommendation the Council relied heavily upon the 1985 report of the Australian Law Reform Commission in which it was said that first-hand hearsay evidence should not be excluded if it is the best evidence that a party has available to it.

The expression `first-hand hearsay evidence' refers to evidence of a representation by a person who witnessed the facts referred to in the representation. The Law Reform Commission also recommended that if such an exception were to operate it would be desirable to have a provision whereby the party who intended to adduce such evidence should give appropriate notice to the other party. Furthermore, it was said in the Commission's report that the admission of such evidence should always be subject to a power of the court to exclude such evidence, if it would be unfair to admit it.

A perusal of the draft Evidence Bill contained in the Commission's report shows that proposed section 100a is drawn in very different terms and does not embody the safeguards that were built into the provisions recommended by the Commission. The recommendation of the Family Law Council implicitly adopted those safeguards and, accordingly, without those safeguards we are concerned with the change that proposed section 100a would bring about. Whilst I acknowledge that in some cases it may be desirable for hearsay evidence of this type to be admitted-particularly in light of the fact that, ordinarily, the Family Court will not grant leave for children to give evidence-it appears to me that proposed section 100a does not provide the appropriate solution. For these reasons, we will be moving an amendment in the committee stage which seeks to delete clause 15.

I now deal with clause 14, which inserts a new section 92a to provide that in any proceedings in which an allegation is made that a child has been abused or is at risk of abuse, five categories of persons are entitled to intervene, as of right, in the proceedings. Those persons are: a guardian of the child, a person entitled to custody of the child, a person responsible for the daily care and control of the child, a prescribed child welfare authority and, finally, the person who is alleged to have abused the child. Under the provision, when such persons intervene, they will have all the rights, duties and liabilities of a party to the proceedings.

There are three reasons why this provision causes me some concern. First, as the Law Institute of Victoria has pointed out, the categories of persons entitled to intervene do not include persons who have been granted access to the child. In its submission on the Bill, the Law Institute suggested that it may be desirable to have a subclause to the effect that anyone with a legitimate interest in the welfare of the child should be able to intervene in proceedings.

Secondly, the proposed section is drafted in very different terms to existing provisions in the Act which deal with the intervention of third parties in proceedings-notably, section 92. Indeed, the Law Council of Australia has argued that the proposed section may not be necessary at all because under section 92 there is already adequate provision for third parties to intervene in appropriate cases.

Thirdly-and this is related to the preceding point-unlike section 92, under the proposed section it will not be necessary for the court to grant leave for the intervention and the court is given no express power to make the intervention, subject to specific terms and conditions. So, once again, we will be moving amendments in the committee stage which are designed to address these concerns.

In conclusion, whilst we have concerns about some provisions in the Bill, overall we are supportive of the changes that will be brought about by it. We support the principles underlying the Bill and for this reason we will not be voting against it at the conclusion of the second reading debate. However, during the committee stage we will be moving a number of amendments designed to address the concerns that I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has pointed out, honourable members have had a long period of time in which to become familiar with the Family Law Amendment Bill, now before the House. More importantly, the community and those who are interested in this area have also had the opportunity to have input into it. I believe that the Bill now before the House, together with the amendments which will be moved by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), represents a step forward in a particularly difficult area of family law.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the amendments have a few purposes, their principle purpose is to define precisely the circumstances in which personnel of the Family Court of Australia must report incidents of child abuse to the State authorities. This particular point is an extremely important one and is vital both in the interests of children and the smooth operation of the court. The legislation was first presented in May last year and now, almost a year later, we are fully debating it. That is a process which, given the Government's history in relation to family law, is to be commended. We have a longstanding history of attempting to gain bipartisan support for amendments to the Family Law Act, and I certainly welcome the comments of the shadow Attorney, who has had the opportunity to consult with the Government. He still has a few particular difficulties with some of the sections of the Bill, but certainly there has been ample opportunity to improve, and I believe that it has been improved, the nature of this particular Bill.

I direct my remarks, firstly, to the question of mandatory reporting, which is very much the crux of the Bill. In the original legislation an obligation was imposed upon court personnel to report suspected incidences of child abuse to State authorities. Child abuse was defined as an assault which was an offence within that particular State or Territory, a sexual assault or ill-treatment. This obligation was to be in no way mitigated by the normal confidentiality which attaches to court officers, particularly court counsellors. The original legislation went to the extent of saying that a failure to report an incident would become a criminal offence and provided that a $6,000 fine was to be imposed on court officers who failed to report an incident of child abuse.

This mandatory reporting requirement I believe caused some concern amongst practitioners within the Family Court, particularly court counsellors, and certainly I would suspect that the idea of imposing a criminal penalty for failure to report would also have caused considerable concern. However, I believe these matters have largely been addressed, although it has to be borne in mind that the Bill in fact has to come to grips with almost a clash of two fundamental principles. The first principle is that the rights and welfare of children are to be paramount and, given our community obligations towards children, there should be a greater degree of care exercised towards the rights of children than is owed by the community generally towards adults.

This is particularly so in relation to official agencies such as courts and government and welfare agencies. Agencies of this nature generally owe a duty always to act in the best interests of children. Under the general law, the basic duty towards children is enforceable against parents, either through the criminal code of the State or through various child welfare laws. So the starting point is that parents obviously have an enforceable obligation to care for and protect their children. Also under the general law this obligation extends to other classes of people who act in the position of parents from time to time-the most obvious example being teachers. They owe a higher duty to the care of children than does maybe the rest of the community.

What we are now grappling with is the extension of those general law principles beyond parents and people in a similar position to parents to a wider class of people. This particular amendment impacts mostly on the position of court counsellors. Under the general law, people such as court counsellors, doctors or teachers may through their work become aware of potential examples of child abuse, but there is no obligation upon them to act on those suspicions. Often they will do so, but there is no legal obligation on someone to report what they suspect to be a case of child abuse.

The debate which this Bill goes directly to is whether this duty to act, to report or take some action to overcome the child abuse, should be made an enforceable legal duty. It is a debate which has been canvassed in other areas. It has been canvassed in relation to the medical profession and it has also been canvassed in relation to the teaching profession. Generally speaking, in the balance of community interest it has been held that the interest of the child and making sure that children are properly cared for impose a sufficient duty that there should be a greater obligation upon doctors and teachers or whomever to report a particular incidence of child abuse. I think that that would now be almost the standard position throughout the country; it certainly is in relation to the general law in Queensland.

The Bill attempts therefore to extend that expansion of duty towards children in the area of court personnel, and I suppose particularly court counsellors. Under the Family Law Act court counsellors will in many instances come into contact with at least allegations of child abuse, if not other direct evidence of child abuse. The Family Law Act itself is predicated on the basis of counselling and mediation being the basis of the resolution of conflict, with the court supposedly coming into play only in more difficult or intractable cases. Any dispute involving the custody of children must go through a counselling process, and in that sense court counsellors are in a unique position to make judgments as to the welfare of children, and also in a unique position in relation to becoming aware of potential incidents of child abuse.

Traditionally, officers such as court counsellors have had an obligation of confidence with their clients, and in that sense that obligation is similar to obligations owed by doctors to their patients or solicitors to their clients. This duty of confidence is the sort of second principle which is clashing with the first principle of care and protection for children. The law has often recognised the obligation of confidence; however, it has never been an absolute obligation and certainly law in various jurisdictions has pegged that back where there are greater public policy grounds or a greater community goal in order to breach that confidence so that the information can be gained in order to combat that social problem.

It is therefore important that we tread warily in this area. It is understandable that court counsellors and those involved with that profession should be wary of amendments imposing mandatory obligations upon them. As I have pointed out the Government has in fact done that but it has given ample time for consultation. Generally speaking the Act as it is now to be amended is supported by the profession and by court counsellors.

This new amended legislation maintains mandatory reporting; however, it more narrowly defines situations where that will occur. It limits it to serious examples of assault-that is, criminal assault that would be an offence under the law of the State or Territory-or cases of sexual abuse. The other category which in the first draft was known as ill treatment is now no longer a matter which must be reported.

To complement those limited areas of serious abuse which must be reported under this Bill, there is also scope for voluntary reporting and that is enhanced by the provisions of the Bill which specifically remove any impediment that may exist through the ethics of the particular profession or any other legal obligation which states that the confidence between the counsellor and the client should never be broken.

The shadow Attorney-General still expressed some reservations on mandatory reporting, but indicated that there would not be a vote forced on that particular question. However, I believe that mandatory reporting is justified and it is justified on the overriding ground that we do as a society have an obligation to children and making sure they are protected. If as a society we are to be serious about child abuse, if we are going to take action to combat it, it is essential that people who have the opportunity to gain information when they have reasonable suspicions that child abuse is taking place go that one step further and report it, and make sure that there is at least an investigation of their suspicions.

That is all the Bill does. It does not attempt to prejudge matters; all it says is that where there is a reasonable suspicion of serious abuse, it must be reported to the relevant State welfare agency so an investigation can then take place. I think, on balance, that no reasonable person could argue against that. There may be some argument about confidentiality, but on balance we would have to conclude that the care of children overrides that other consideration. It is also important that reporting be mandatory because a mandatory provision underlines our commitment to children, as does this amendment further by adding to the Act itself a clause which states that the welfare of children must be the paramount consideration in custody and access disputes.

It is important to note that the Bill as it will be amended by the Attorney-General has the support of the psychological profession. I have in front of me a letter from the Australian Psychological Society, which states in part:
The proposed legislation presents no conflict with our code of professional conduct as the rules covering confidentiality allow for exceptional circumstances-
that is, for confidence to be breached. The letter goes on to say:

Psychologists must respect the confidence of information obtained from persons in the course of their work as psychologists. They may reveal such information to others only with the consent of the person or the person's legal representative except in those unusual circumstances in which not to do so would result in clear danger to the person or to others.

That makes it quite clear that the profession itself recognises that there are cases where confidence must be breached, and it sees no conflict between this Bill and its own code of professional conduct.

Similar statements of support have been elicited from those directly involved, that is, court counsellors. The Attorney-General's office made contact with the various registries of the Family Court throughout Australia. While there are still some concerns in some of the registries about the need for this provision, the overwhelming opinion coming out of the court registries is that the new Bill as it has been amended is worth while and has the support of those practitioners who will be immediately impacted by the passing of this legislation. That is also an extremely important point to note.

The shadow Attorney-General mentioned two other points. He expressed his reservations about the clause which allows the court to accept hearsay evidence. Again, I can accept his genuine concern about this. Allegations of sexual abuse are notoriously easy to make and difficult to prove. But, by the same token, we cannot allow legal rules such as the laws of evidence to provide an overwhelming barrier to the tackling of child abuse. The issue of child abuse is just far too important to allow the rules of evidence to stand in the way, provided that there is always a discretion in the judge to make a judgment as to that particular evidence and as to the weight that should be given to that evidence. Therefore, that safeguard in terms of the position of the accused is guaranteed.

I accept that the admission of hearsay evidence is a difficult issue. It is an issue which jurisdictions other than the family law jurisdiction have had to grapple with; it has been grappled with by the various State governments in terms of their own criminal laws in relation to child abuse. Again, the decision here about the admission of hearsay evidence-which really does no more than reflect an existing court practice in any event-is consistent generally with stances taken by various State governments in the question of child abuse, so it is nothing extreme or trailblazing in that it is consistent with action taken in other jurisdictions.

The shadow Attorney-General also indicated that he would be moving an amendment in relation to parties who are able to intervene in child abuse cases. In particular, I note that his amendment will add to the classes who can intervene, as well as give a general statement that any person reasonably interested or necessarily interested in a child can intervene. I have no particular problems with that. I do not believe it takes anything away from that new section of the Act, and I will not address the matter further.

In conclusion, I believe that the law in this area is difficult. However, the Attorney-General, through this piece of legislation, has adopted a very rational approach and has allowed ample time for consultation. That has occurred, and the Bill will be amended as a result of that consultation. The end result will be a piece of legislation which tackles a difficult area and will improve the position and the rights of children. If that is the end result of this legislation, I believe it is deserving of our full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in support of the Family Law Amendment Bill 1990, because I feel, as I am sure everybody in this House does, that any legislation that is brought before this House in support of the family and in particular the protection of children should be given top priority in view of the deep concerns expressed in the past not only by me but by other members of the House on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we know of the deep concern in the community with regard to a lot of the operations pertaining to the Family Law Act. This concern is not necessarily concern about the Act itself, because many if not most of the provisions in it are very good. The Act was originally debated on the occasion of its introduction and was voted on in a bipartisan manner. But many areas associated with the Family Law Act cause a lot of concern, particularly with regard to counselling. I am very glad that the Senate has agreed to an inquiry. I hope that this may even become a joint inquiry into the matters that are concerning a lot of people in the community-indeed, many of my own constituents.

There is ample evidence to indicate that child abuse in many forms is common in our society today. It is essential to identify typical symptoms associated with any form of child victimisation and to establish the means with which to deal with them. Indeed, honourable members will recall that I have introduced into the present Parliament a Private Member's Bill to eliminate the payment of medical benefits in certain instances of abortion. The killing of the innocent unborn child for social and economic reasons and for gender engineering is in any thinking person's mind the ultimate in child abuse, and I would encourage all honourable members to think very deeply about and heed the cry of the innocent unborn. But I do not intend to say any more on that matter.

It is essential that every assistance be given to promote early detection of abuse and protection for those who are unable to adequately verbalise their experiences. These traumatic experiences rob children of their childhood. Any changes in legislation that can be of assistance to reveal instances of child abuse must be commended in view of the alarming incidence of child abuse in this country. I commend the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), who is at the table, for his efforts in this regard and for the way in which this Bill was brought into the House and let lie on the table for others to comment and deliberate on it.

I have spoken on many occasions in the House on amendments to the Family Law Act. I now return to the observations that I made on some of those occasions. This legislation is before us today because, increasingly, Australian men and women do not hesitate to tear up marital commitments, to shirk marital obligations and abuse their former spouses, and in particular their children, either by neglect or by physical abuse.

I do not think that there is any sinister conspiratorial attack on the family unit in what is being proposed in this legislation, although I do not doubt that those ideologically opposed to the traditional family will experience some satisfaction over this situation. Rather, it is the natural and necessary response of law makers acting prudently to achieve justice for the weaker parties, in particular, children.

Today we will put in place legislation that will further determine the nature of the family and bring further stability and safety into the marriage relationship, particularly with regard to children.

I find the whole situation that surrounds child abuse very disturbing. I do not think that we have reflected fully enough on the implications of the situation for the role of the family in this area. I think the Attorney-General will know what I am talking about in that regard. We certainly seem to be oblivious to the continued erosion of those intangible bases of human relationships in marriage-the family and society, which this Bill both reflects and produces. Whilst we are discussing a Bill which is tremendously important with regard to the protection of children, we still have some very glaring areas in our community where we are neglecting the causes of the problem.

In the last 16 years before I became a member of parliament I was fully involved in the area of criminology and in dealing with the younger members of our New South Wales community who found themselves in confrontation with the law. I had quite an intensive 16 years in my dealings with those younger people. That experience revealed to me that this country is now awash with pornography. There is ample evidence to show that this very fact alone is the cause of a lot of child abuse within marriage and without marriage in our society today.

For example, I remember seeing not so long ago an interview with Ted Bundy, the sexual abuser and murderer of 28 women and girls in the United States. In an interview the night before he was executed, he said that within the prison where he was, and indeed in every prison in the United States, there was not one sexual offender, including himself, against children or women who did not feast on hard core pornography.

I remember in my earlier years in this Parliament bringing to the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others over and over again the need to come to grips with this particular problem confronting our community. There have been many petitions and letters to the Prime Minister and others protesting about the fact that this country is now awash with pornography.

Every sexual offender who came into my custody had a history of involvement in hard core pornography. It is all very well for us to stand up in this House and be swollen with pride over the fact that we are coming to grips with this problem-indeed, it is absolutely necessary that we do come to grips with it-but we also have to be able to say that we have done our utmost to make sure that the causes of this problem are fully dealt with and that we have a clear conscience. We should not be running around trying to find statistics and arguments which cast some doubt on the case I am putting forward, because it is right. We only need commonsense to understand that what I am saying is a fact.

Today we are involved in the political chore of regenerating our cultural capital in possibly the most significant area of social relations, the family. Can there be any doubt that the social security blow-out and the educational, health and employment problems which arise out of marriage breakdown are a threat to good government? These things are a threat to good government.

On the one hand, if we do not have high moral values and strong stable families in our society, it does not matter how good our economic situation is; the nation will continue on the road to decay. On the other hand, if we do have strong moral fibre and a government that does everything in its power to ensure the stability of the family, to see that families stay together and that all the resources needed to keep them together are in place, it does not matter what sort of economic situation we are confronted with, what our balance of payments might be, or whether we experience great depression or recession; we will still survive as a nation. History has shown that over and over again.

I make a plea to the Government and to the Attorney-General, who is at the table and who has a portfolio of tremendous influence, that these concerns of many Australian people-indeed, many people throughout the world-are taken account of.

I do not think there can be any doubt that much of our marital breakdown, child abuse and child poverty could be prevented if we nurtured the values represented in this legislation. We need to take a great deal of notice of these very concerning problems. That is why we have this legislation before us. It is not just a reaction to irresponsible behaviour by certain citizens or an invention on behalf of the weak. It is also an attempt to set before our citizens what is right and what is wrong. I want to emphasise and acknowledge that.

It champions certain values which we all believe are crucial to the good of our community and its individual members. It is crucial that we come to grips with the problem in this area that has been hitherto inhibited by the secrecy provisions of the Act.

It is our duty to alert the Australian community to what is gradually but surely occurring in Australia. There is less compassion, self-sacrifice and self-discipline in human relationships. There is more and more bureaucratic intervention in those relationships, and this too is not helping the stability of the family. Family values can be concentrated on and children can be made secure in the family situation. It is very sad that intervention is necessary in this instance. It is not that I think that this Bill is not needed-it is needed today. But it is very sad to think that such a Bill is needed and that we have to make provisions for this kind of attention in the society in which we live.

I do not want to say too much more other than to remind the House that it is so important to take on board all the issues that are confronting families and the reasons why we are experiencing difficulties with the enormous number of marriage breakdowns. When we look at the Budget outlays we see, as I mentioned in a speech earlier today, enormous expenditure on social security payments as a result of marriage breakdown-about $2 billion-and yet very small amounts being allocated by the Government for marriage education. One can search throughout the country and one will find that there are not too many programs going on in schools that prepare young people for the problems and difficulties associated with a stable marriage.

I read a statistic once which indicated that only six couples out of every 100 seek any guidance at all prior to going into marriage. We know that the complexities of modern-day living and budgeting and all sorts of other problems are part and parcel of the reasons why we have this Bill here in front of us today. The breakdown of marriage is a result of tremendous conflict arising in families, on many occasions through ignorance. People just have not had the necessary education and understanding prior to going into marriage.

The resources for people to obtain help even after marriage are very limited, even though there has been an increase in recent years by the Government. So I commend to the Attorney-General, who is at the table, that we give a lot more attention to the reasons why, sadly, we have to bring this kind of legislation into the House. I commend to the Attorney the views I have expressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been reflecting on the statistics cited by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) on how many people seek guidance prior to marriage. I admit to seeking guidance prior to my marriage because I was to marry a Catholic. I went to a Catholic priest and, unfortunately, he wanted me to join the club and I refused. So the guidance did not extend beyond a nice cup of tea and `Thanks very much, but no thanks, I won't join the club'.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a maturity in young people which leads them to seek their own counsel in some ways and to make their own decisions. Having made a decision, when a marriage breaks down everyone has a huge expectation that the Family Court can solve the problems. What I would like to do is make some remarks about the specifics of the Family Law Amendment Bill and also make some more general statements that reflect upon the maturity of the Family Court-and I do not mean that in critical sense but to acknowledge its existence since 1975.

The most important aspect of this amendment, of course, is the mandatory reporting of child abuse. I know that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has worked hard to satisfy all of those concerned. Especially I know some court counsellors in Brisbane who are a little concerned that they may be subject to criminal liability if they refuse or fail to report child sexual abuse. The Attorney-General has persisted, quite rightly, to ensure that every reasonable effort is made to encourage people, counsellors especially, to inform the relevant authorities where they believe a child is in danger.

I believe that the means the Attorney-General used to get around the original impasse were to narrow the definition of `abuse' so that there must be a reasonable belief that an actual assault or sexual abuse has taken place. There we find that the counsellors are satisfied that they have the full protection of the law against any sort of action against them, but they are also satisfied professionally that matters of a delicate nature are kept private between them and their clients. However, if the matter is so desperately awful, as now defined here, then they are liable to tell the proper authorities what is going on.

I want to make some more general remarks about the Family Court. I had a conversation only the week before last with a woman who was my guide and interpreter in Japan; I spent 10 days there with a delegation. She told members of the delegation that she had been divorced 10 years ago in Japan. The rules in that country, as she related them-and I think she was probably accurate-are that, as a consequence of her leaving her husband, she had no rights whatsoever to a share of his or her property, if they both owned it, or to any maintenance. Fortunately for her they had no children, but she would have had no rights to maintenance from the husband had she had children.

I think sometimes we ought to sit back and give ourselves a bit of a pat on the back for how far we have extended these rights to men, women and children under the Family Law Act. Japan is a well developed and economically extremely powerful nation in which it appears to me-and I could not verify whether these rules are standard today in Japan, but they are as far as my guide and interpreter was aware-that women have very few rights to be maintained after they leave the marriage. There is a form of social and legal pressure to keep families together, but it is not one we would support at all, and it is one that I am sure has brought many women and many children in Japanese society to a desperate state.

We have gone down the right path and, having gone down that path, we are now chipping away at the important but lesser questions. Inevitably this sort of debate, however important, is burrowing away at the edges. But we should not forget that the perception of many of our constituents out there is a long way behind this. A fellow and his second wife who came to see me last week were both of the opinion that because this chap had remarried he no longer had to support his three original children, who were aged 11, nine and eight or whatever. They had a definite mindset that he could leave that first family behind; he had remarried, he was going to look after the two new kids, and that was his responsibility. I had to remind him-rather gently, because he was a big bruising sort of bloke-that he had five children to look after: three through an original choice and set of circumstances and two more through some new circumstances.

Probably one of our greatest needs-still, after 16 years-is to get more Australians to understand what the Family Court can do for them and does not even attempt to do, and to sort out, usually for the male but often for the female, that their responsibilities for children are ongoing once the marriage breaks down.

In that context, very broadly speaking, let me make some remarks about an issue that has arisen in the Family Court in connection with something called family mediation. It seems to me that the Family Court, after 16 years, has reached the level of maturity where people have settled into their roles the judges are satisfied that they have a place in society equal to that of a Federal Court judge and so on, people have a good career structure, and all is well. But sometimes I believe that when people get too settled they start to look for new ideas that are not warranted, that are basically nonsense.

There has been an almighty debate in some sections of the Family Court recently about this new and what I might call trendy notion of family mediation-as if the Family Court has not been involved in alternative dispute resolutions since 1975. Court officers, deputy registrars, counsellors and so on have been involved in mediation for 16 years, and there have been some proposals from the Court that the Government ought to spend an enormous amount of money putting in a whole new infrastructure to do with family mediation.

I do not quite know where that idea came from, but I do note that in the Family Law Council annual report of 1989-90 there is a section devoted to family mediation. I will read a section of it; perhaps this is an indication of where the idea came from-I do not know. Under the heading `Family mediation' the report states:

Mediation, particularly family mediation, is a fast developing area of alternate dispute resolution. Having examined arbitration in detail, the Council resolved at its June 1989 meeting that an examination of family mediation should be undertaken, with a view to developing policy on family mediation.
The report goes on to state:
To examine family mediation as a method of dispute resolution, with a view to developing policy on family mediation, with particular attention to-
- research and evaluation
- qualifications and training
- legislation
- desired models and practices of mediation
- funding.

People have been sent far and wide to study what the Canadians, and no doubt the west coast Americans, do when they mediate. So far as I am informed by officers of the court, they have by and large come back with a new language and a new way of interacting, touching, feeling and being at home-a holistic approach. But at the end of the day they basically do the job that counsellors and deputy registrars have been doing in the Family Court for 16 years. We do not need to spend any more money involving those officers in a new program that would simply make the language a bit more west coast American.

I obviously have a very definite and prejudiced view on this but, nevertheless, there comes a time when a court ought to be acknowledged as doing its job correctly and for those who find that it is not totally fulfilling maybe they should move on and go somewhere else. But the court does a good job. It does not need to spend a great deal more money on this business of family mediation. It already does the job of mediation. It already helps counsel people before they get to a judge. The `hit rate' is about 95 per cent. Very few cases go through the court because deputy registrars second-guess what the judge will tell a couple. The deputy registrar will say, `Listen, you will get X, Y and Z out of the judge. So either accept that or go away and make a compromise, and do not take the cost of going before the judge'.

On another level, when it comes to handling children, counsellors do an excellent job. Couples must go before the counsellor and decide for themselves how they should handle future maintenance, care and custody of their own children. So full marks to the Family Court. But to those members of the Family Court who are feeling a little run down by the whole terribly difficult business of solving family disputes: I do not think there is a great need to introduce a whole new notion of mediation. It has been a central part of the Family Court for 16 years, and I know that sensible people within the Court will start to move back now to their real work and get over this trendy fascination they have with whatever comes out of the west coast of the United States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Amendment Bill amends the Family Law Act. I support the amendments that will be moved by the Opposition. Recognising the human complexities in the legislation, I understand why the legislation has taken so long to be finally debated in Parliament. I listed myself to take part in the debate so that I could speak generally about the Family Law Act, its bureaucratic intrusion into the family structure and the subsequent effect that has had on our national morality.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been married to the same person for 33 years. I believe I am somewhat experienced in marriage, if only to defend it. I recollect driving in my car somewhere before I came to this place, and I am sure I heard on the radio the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) delivering a report of a committee that looked into the Family Law Act. I do not know why, but I remember that speech. However, I am deeply concerned that Parliament goes on finding legislative solutions to the business of marriage. I use the word `business' advisedly because, perhaps unfortunately, marriage has gone past being a tradition. In this day and age it is a form of contract, and it is a pity that there is not a third party to the contract, namely, the Government.

With the social security structures and so on that we have today, the nation as represented by the Government has an important interest in the viability of marriage. I have a greater interest: I just think that marriages should survive. I am not sure that in recent times we on both sides of politics, having taken a bipartisan approach, have done much for the survival of marriage. We have made it too easy for people to escape from marriage.

I quote my mother in this place quite frequently. She was a great advocate of women's rights. Her views were a bit limited by today's standards. She just thought she should be able to own half the family home. Indeed, she campaigned so vigorously for it that, after the family grew up and my parents shifted to a duplex which my father thought would provide both accommodation and income, he put her in half and he was sent a bill for gift duty. He was nice and angry about that. Times have changed, but that was her view. Yet in later years she viewed with great concern the way we were starting to make it too easy for people to escape from marriage.

She said, quite openly, that she could list occasions, as I certainly could for different reasons, when, for instance, in an argument a marriage seems to becomes irretrievable for a brief period because one just cannot agree; it is an issue of gigantic proportions for that period in a marriage when one argues with one's spouse. But, as my mother pointed out, in those days the woman did not leave home for anything short of a beating. I am not saying that was a good situation, but women did not leave a marriage because, unfortunately, they had nowhere to go. I do not support that position either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank God.

—I do not support that situation, but I ask the honourable member to listen because the reality was that a lot of marriages survived happily because, as many of us know, that apparently irretrievable and dreadful argument of the night before often achieved minuscule importance the following morning. There is no doubt that in those days when my mother battled to be half-owner of the family home women were not in a good position. In the circumstances I have described, the fact is that women were frequently locked into violent marriages-and that was not good.

SPEECH.PARA: In attempting to address a real problem, we simply said to the community, `If you want to escape your marriage, we will pay you. The simple act of walking away from a marriage can make you a pensioner'. Of course, women deserted their marriages in droves. We also brought down the Family Law Act, which again was done with the best possible intentions. I remember a newspaper in Western Australia that did nothing else but report on the seamier side of divorce cases. The newspaper was called the Mirror, and it was a dreadful publication. It ran headlines like, `Bert caught in Digby's diggings'. That was when one party to a marriage had to prove that his or her spouse had committed adultery. That was a ridiculous situation and should not have happened.

But we did not find some sensible common ground, because we then said, `There is a no fault situation, you can break the contract'. There was nothing wrong with that: many marriage contracts today are not covered by any religious significance. But children always came in between. The great problem is that the legislation has never properly paid attention to the children. The legislation concentrated on the breakdown of marriage because the adults could not get on.

We then come to some other peculiar conclusions-for instance, that the wife is quite clearly the best person to have the children. We have all these proceedings, including those carried out by the Child Support Agency, to make sure that the assumed breadwinner, the male spouse, will pay for the support of the children. I doubt that there is a member in this House who at some time has not had a very distraught father come to him to explain the circumstances of his wife leaving the marriage, going to live with someone else and pursuing him with a vigour and vehemence to support the children.

I am totally committed to the position that people who have children should be obliged to keep them. That is why I mentioned it. Maybe it is time parents had a contract with the Government-the only other body that can do this-saying that they will do that when they get married. Maybe honourable members would say that that would be another reason why they would not bother to get married. Basically that is the only other choice we have.

We offer that freely as a government without questioning whether the people could have stayed together and kept their contract. More importantly, we sort of say, `You go away, you take the kids, here's some money'. We employ people to go around and pick them up in a motor car.
