We have an easily discoverable number that people can call to have someone come and get them.

Once a person is taken out of the marital home a marriage is generally irretrievable. Perhaps we should be leaving them in the home to try to sort things out and do what would have been done prior to all this legislation-that is, ring up mum. It was an interesting situation in those days when the only solution other than having some bureaucrat take a person out of the family home was to go home to mother. When a person rang up mum the first thing that person got was counselling, and for free. Sometimes that counselling was a little brutal because mum said, `I told you never to marry that fellow'. But frequently the marriage survived. I think that was good. Parents had a great interest in the viability of marriage. One of the reasons was-I say this without any brutality-because they did not particularly want the children coming home to mother, because they had their own economic problems.

There are other sides to this matter. I think I have mentioned them in this place before. My mother just happened to be one of 13 children. It was not a matter of great significance that one night my mother and father talked about two of my mother's brothers- they were Irish-Catholic, sixfoot six and 18 stone-who had gone around to discuss the family situation with her sister's husband who was apparently not treating her very well. I am sure his performance would have improved after the discussion.

I am saying that the family took all those levels of interest in keeping marriages together, frequently very successfully, until we politicians came along. We had good reason; we had these examples, minimum though they might have been. The same applies to child abuse. We are going to have to be terribly careful with our administration in this area. This also applies to domestic violence. I say this for the sake of the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), who is getting all a-twitter on the other side of the House. They are the minority in our community; they are not the majority.

I feared deeply the creation of the domestic violence bureaucracy. As I said in an earlier discussion today, institutions become self-supporting. The people who have the job become more interested in finding domestic violence than preventing it. We have to be terribly careful as politicians that we do not do things that eventually destroy the initiative and the institutions of our community. I am worried in general terms that we have already done that with the Family Law Act as it is today and with the supporting parents benefit, notwithstanding the fact that I would never take it off the statute books.

Someone has to stand up every now and then and say, `This is not going as well as it should'. One of the most dramatic situations that is brought to me as a member of parliament by members of broken families relates to custody of children. It represents a huge difficulty for legislators simply because, as I said, we are the first line of defence. When a marriage contract is broken there is only the Treasury to support the children until other arrangements are made. Then we go through this legal process of tugging and pulling as to who might have custody of the children. I know that someone will stand up in a minute and quote statistics showing that there is a large percentage of those cases. That is never in dispute because the spouse, and possibly the breadwinner, has just left. Clearly in that situation I argue strongly for what happens today.

There are a lot of custody cases where both parties are clearly to be found. They are both around. Yet we have to have a legal process for the custody of the children. It appears to me that in an age when we no longer differentiate between the sexes-we no longer suggest that women or men are better than each other-it would be much simpler if the law provided that the financial responsibilities for children simply resided with that individual who had the financial resources to do it. Once neither has it that is quite a different issue anyway. If, for instance, that is the male partner, until such times as they would draw from that right they are the custodians of the children. Having stood back from that, having said, as some might, `I don't want the kids', then the process of the law should demand of them that they provide sufficient money to keep them, presumably in the hands of the other partner.

If both partners want to demonstrate the financial ability to support the children without any government involvement then I guess the courts have to decide who could do it best. I just do not see why we suddenly and always have to say that the children must go to the female and the husband must pay and we will pursue the Child Support Agency to get the money. I know that is the way we do it but I do not believe it is right. I think it is too simplistic on the one hand but creates a lot of problems for government on the other because generally the person who ends up with the children then becomes dependent on government assistance, notwithstanding the new and improved means of getting some money from someone else. Honourable members should remember that the original Family Law Act simply said that in setting maintenance the courts would take account of all the welfare one could get. In other words, `Please bludge on the community first, having broken your marriage contract, and then go off and see whether there is anything necessary to be paid from those who created the family in the first place'.

These are just comments that I wanted to make. As I said, we are trying harder in the area of child abuse. I do not think there is any doubt that there is child abuse. The Opposition has expressed concern as to when, in the hatred of a broken marriage, allegations of child abuse will be made, purely for reasons other than that there was child abuse. I think that is a matter of great concern. No-one should suggest that it will not happen and that it has not happened. Of course, it will happen. Just as children who learn to live with one parent in a broken marriage are told day after day all that is wrong about the other parent and are brainwashed to hate that parent-we know that happens-equally, a very young child could be convinced of almost anything.

I do not know how one sorts that situation out, in other words, how one differentiates between reality and fantasy. But it is the sort of thing we have taken upon ourselves by poking our legislative nose further and further into the family. We have certainly contributed to more marriage breakdowns; the statistics support that without any further comment.

Honourable members opposite should go and look at the statistics when the Act was first brought in. The then Attorney-General got to the front of the queue, but after that people came in their thousands. I am not saying that is necessarily wrong. I am saying that we as legislators sometimes have to test our acts of generosity to ensure that the end result is beneficial to the community. `Beneficial' does not just mean that we pay someone some money; it means that we should try to maintain the family unit and we should do a lot of things to make sure that other people in the community who are trying to maintain their family unit are not being taxed into a position where financial pressures break up their marriage. These are the sorts of things that can happen.

I am not here trying to say that all things should change. I am here to utter a word of caution. I am not sure that our attempts as legislators in the field of marriage-I am not blaming either side of politics, myself included-have been very productive for the survival of marriage. I think marriage was more successful under some of the old rules when it was a family responsibility, not a responsibility of the courts.

At that time, the broken marriage was a straight-out financial responsibility of the immediate family and they knew it. Families certainly put a great deal more pressure on prospective bridegrooms, as I recollect. I certainly had to explain how I could keep my future wife in the manner to which she was accustomed. Nobody took any risks with me, simply because they knew that the only other persons in the community who could support my wife and our possible offspring were her parents. All of that parental interest has been reduced purely and simply on the grounds that it does not matter much any more; the responsibility will go back to the Government. We should think very carefully when we legislate in these areas so that we do the right thing. We should realise that some of the more established principles of our community may make for a better way to handle the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before debating the Family Law Amendment Bill I must say, having listened to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), how glad I am that we in my Party are on this side of the House. I could not stress that fact too much. Just two hours ago in this House we had a debate on plain English and I think you, Mr Deputy Speaker, were in the chair when I was speaking in that debate about having legislation put into plain English. I can honestly say that the Family Law Amendment Bill before the House-particularly when we look at the legal ramifications of the wording of it-is possibly another area we could address in future regarding plain English.

SPEECH.PARA: I join the other speakers in commending Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) for bringing this Bill before the House. The Government proposes to move 13 amendments to the Bill. I noted that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), in speaking on behalf of the Opposition, trivialised the fact that there were going to be 13 amendments moved by the Government. What he did not say and what I would like to have reported in Hansard is that a number of those amendments are to substitute the word `Minister' in place of `Attorney-General', so if we are going to trivialise amendments in this important Bill, let us be honest and factual.

The honourable member for Kooyong also spoke about mandatory reporting. A number of other speakers have also spoken on mandatory reporting. As the Attorney-General would know, this is an area of concern where I too disagree-except that I believe mandatory reporting should occur in all cases of child abuse. I do not believe we should have civil action to the extent that it was first placed in the legislation when it was introduced into this House on 16 May, but I do believe we should have mandatory reporting.

I stress that because I have unfortunate statistics that the honourable member for O'Connor did not have. Even though there are no national figures available-and I am ashamed to say that-about instances of child abuse, I do have figures supplied by the New South Wales Department of Family and Community Services. Those figures show that one in 11 children born in New South Wales in 1987 will be reported and confirmed as abused children by the time they reach the age of 16. Further statistics released during the child protection week last year show that in 1989, of the 18,427 new notifications of child abuse received, 10,001 were confirmed. Of those complaints, 24 per cent were of physical abuse, 23 per cent of sexual assault, 21 per cent of emotional abuse and 3 per cent of neglect. Those statistics are harrowing. The reason I back those statistics up is that I believe that through legislation, reporting should be made mandatory.

Whether we like is or not, these statistics reinforce the fact that child abuse is widespread within our community. In gradual recognition of this, over the last 10 years, child protection authorities throughout Australia have developed and implemented a variety of intervention programs for the prevention and control of child abuse. I am pleased to say that government agencies have now established specialist police, education, health and welfare services to provide assistance to victims and their families.

Both the Commonwealth and the States have now produced reports, established committees and held inquiries into child abuse. Legal reforms have been implemented in many States and funds have been provided to self-help groups. I am pleased to say that as governments and the community became increasingly aware of the prevalence of child abuse, there was also recognition of the problems child abuse posed for our legal system, which allocates family law matters to one court and child welfare matters to another. It has become evident that there is a need to foster and maintain a cooperative approach between courts and all other agencies involved in child protection matters.

I would like to give an example of one problem which arose as a result of overlapping jurisdictions of guardianship, custody and access law and child welfare law and the lack of a cooperative approach between jurisdictions with regard to child protection. In New South Wales there is a mandatory legal requirement for doctors and teachers to notify the Department of Family and Community Services of suspected cases of child abuse. Once notified, the Department of Family and Community Services begins an investigation and gives the child or children immediate protection. If necessary, the Department begins a legal process in the New South Wales courts under New South Wales law to give the child or children necessary long term protection. For the victim, the Department procures the best available help, support and counselling.

It has been the case in the past that despite the Department of Family and Community Services having taken legal action in the State courts under State law to protect a child following notification and substantiation of abuse, the Family Court of Australia, acting under Commonwealth law, in custody proceedings before it involving that child has granted the perpetrator access to the victim. I do not mean to imply that the Family Court did not care whether the child had been abused or that the Court did not consider the welfare of the child. It was more the case that if the parties to the proceedings did not direct the Family Court's attention to action taken in the New South Wales courts, there was no legal procedure for the Department of Family and Community Services to intervene to draw the court's attention to action the Department had taken. Nor was there a mechanism whereby the Family Court could check as a matter of course whether action had been taken against one of the parties in the New South Wales courts for child abuse.

Further, allegations of child abuse made by one party against another in custody and access disputes presented difficulties for the Family Court as it had no set procedures for handling such allegations.

These issues to which I refer were canvassed in the Family Law Council's 1988 report on child sexual abuse. The report was the product of a committee established in November 1985 to examine and report on cases involving allegations of child sexual abuse. The 1988 report's recommendations included that the Family Law Act 1975 should be amended to provide more explicit recognition of children's needs for protection against abuse; the hearsay rule should not apply to children's statements; notification of abuse should be made to relevant State or Territory child welfare authorities by legal practitioners, Family Court counsellors and others; and limits should be placed on the psychological and psychiatric assessment of children for purposes of litigation.

As is evident from the amendments in the Bill before the House, the Government has been largely guided by the recommendations of the report by the Family Law Council. The amendments are designed to complement the administrative arrangements established recently by the Family Court to process cases involving allegations of child abuse, and to overcome other remaining difficulties with the handling of child abuse allegations. There is to be a legal protection for a registrar or court counsellor who notifies a child welfare authority that a child has been abused, or is at risk of being abused. The amendment also provides that the registrar or counsellor is not liable in civil or criminal proceedings, and is not to be considered to have breached professional ethics or any standard of professional conduct.

The Bill before the House also contains a section to provide for State and Territory child welfare authorities and other interested persons to intervene in cases involving alleged child abuse. I believe that this section will overcome the problems I alluded to earlier arising from that lack of cooperative approach between courts and other agencies involved in child protection matters.

I would like in passing to refer to clause 15. I do so because the Opposition has already indicated that it will move to delete that clause, even the amended one. I say shame. I repeat it-shame! Clause 15 provides that evidence of a child will be admissible-even though we are going to amend that-in proceedings in the Family Court, despite the rules regarding hearsay evidence. The court, as originally intended, would give such weight, if any, as it thinks fit to such evidence. Further, the evidence may be oral or in writing or inferred from the child's conduct.

I think that this amendment, based on the new recommendations of the Family Law Council, is very important. Evidence of a child in cases where abuse is alleged would appear to be of particular relevance. Of course, the court would give evidence such weight as it sees fit. There is a growing body of academic authority which submits that small children do make dependable witnesses, especially in cases of abuse.

Clause 17 provides that the Family Court must give leave before a child is examined by a person in order for that person to give evidence about that child in a case. This section effectively limits-and thank goodness it does-the number of unnecessary medical and psychological examinations of children obtained by parents involved in custody and access disputes. This amendment deserves support for the obvious protection it extends to children who, all too often, become pawns in bitter custody and access disputes before the courts.
I also address my comments to other aspects of this Bill which are worthy of the support of this House.

At present there is a requirement that a notice be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette whenever the Minister-in the original Bill it was the Attorney-General, but we are amending that-approves or revokes the approval of an organisation as a marriage counselling organisation, to which grants of financial assistance may be made. Clause 3 amends subsection 12(7) of the Family Law Act to require notification in an annual directory of approved marriage counselling, marriage education and family mediation organisations, rather than notification in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. The new directory will ensure that the public will have better access to information on marriage and family counselling services.

I am pleased that we have that in the Bill because, as the honourable member for O'Connor stated, we no longer have the opportunity extended to us whereby, with a marriage breakdown, one can go back to mum. I am glad that in the facts he presented when speaking to the Bill he acknowledged that not every couple has a mum. I hope that in turn easier access to information will lead to easier access to, and greater use of, the services themselves.

Under existing provisions of the Family Law Act, a person may apply to the court for an order transferring custody or guardianship of a child from parents to another person, and if the parents consent to the order being made, the order may be made without appropriate scrutiny of the suitability of that person to have custody or guardianship of the child.

Clause 8 of this Bill will require the parties now to attend a conference with a court counsellor or welfare officer who will then prepare a report for the court about the guardianship or custody arrangements proposed by the parties. The purpose of that report will be to advise the court whether the parents are making an informed decision, and whether any appropriate custody or guardianship arrangements are proposed. This amendment not only protects the interests of the child, but also reinforces the concept that the primary and continuing responsibility for a child should remain with the natural parents.

For similar reasons I also strongly support clause 10 of this Bill, which provides that an agreement registered with the Family Court has no effect to the extent that it purports to confer rights of custody or guardianship upon a person who is not the parent of the child. The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that child agreements are not used to transfer legal custody or guardianship of a child, except between the parents of a child.

Arrangements for the transfer of custody or guardianship of a child to non-parents should be subject to scrutiny by a court before they are given legal effect under the Family Law Act. It is presently the case that child agreements are registered without having been scrutineered by the court. Proper scrutiny can only be ensured by requiring the parties to apply to the court for a custody or a guardianship order, instead of registering a child agreement.

The Family Law Act confers jurisdiction on the Family Court and certain other courts to determine custody, guardianship and access questions in relation to a child. To an extent, that jurisdiction depends on the child being a child of the marriage, and by definition a child ceases to be a child of a marriage if the child is adopted by a person who is not a party to the marriage. Such an adoption takes the child out of the Family Court's jurisdiction and thus Family Court determinations regarding custody, guardianship and access rights cease to apply to that child. This situation causes obvious problems where a step-parent adopts a child, thereby terminating the custody or access rights of the child's natural parent. That is, the adoption is used as a device to exclude a parent who has, and is, exercising access rights in accordance with a Family Court access order.

The Family Law Council report of 1986 entitled Cinderella Revisited: Rights and Responsibilities of Step-Families identified such problems and made recommendations regarding the most appropriate way of establishing guardianship and custody rights and responsibilities for step-parents vis-a-vis their stepchildren. The recommendations included that, in any decision made regarding changes to the legal status and relationships of a child in a step-family, the welfare and interests of the child should be paramount and the wishes of the child, where expressed, should be taken into account; step-parents' custody and guardianship rights should not arise automatically on marriage but only on a court order.

Clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the Bill before the House clarify the effect that a step-parent adoption has on custody, guardianship and access rights under the Family Law Act. They make it clear that in the case of a step-parent adoption the Family Law Act continues to apply to the adopted child, thus continuing the access rights of natural parents, unless the Family Court has granted leave for adoption proceedings to be commenced. Clause 6 of the Bill provides for the Family Court to give leave in appropriate cases.

I would like to say, too, that this Bill makes socially desirable and much needed amendments to the Family Law Act of 1975. In commending the Bill, again I reiterate that in all States of Australia, except Victoria and Tasmania, the parliaments and the courts have provided through legislation mandatory reporting of suspected child abuse or child ill treatment. I do not believe that the people with that responsibility, whether they be doctors, teachers, lawyers or whatever, have their professional integrity impinged on in any way by being obligated to report if they see a case such as I have just described.

It is our duty as adults to protect all children, and by that I mean children from birth until the age of 18. We must make sure that this legislation before the House is built on and that it continues to be amended to meet society's needs. Most particularly, we must make sure that we do not have to come to this House time and again to report abuse cases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a sense I regret that this debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill will be interrupted within seven minutes, and the contribution I shall make may therefore be somewhat terse, unless I continue my remarks tomorrow. I have a number of simple points I want to make. My qualification for speaking in this debate is that in 1980 I chaired the one and only substantial parliamentary inquiry into the Family Law Act. I am pleased, therefore, that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in introducing this Bill commented that in the past there had been a bipartisan political approach to family law matters and that he was introducing the Bill with a view to its lying on the table and for consideration to be given to amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that since the Attorney-General did that, the Bill has been the subject of amendments proposed by the Opposition shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and by the Attorney himself in incorporating many of the proposals put forward by the shadow Attorney-General. It is a sensible outcome to a very difficult issue, which has been canvassed by other speakers.

The issue of mandatory reporting and the requirements for reporting, particularly where the Commonwealth is involved in reporting child abuse to State authorities-under our constitutional arrangements the States tend to deal with these matters-raise the very vexed question of jurisdiction, referred to earlier by the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). The question of jurisdiction is not new. When those of us on the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act looked at the matter of jurisdiction, we were anxious to see that these questions were addressed by the Commonwealth and the States. We sought referral of powers and clarification of matters through the courts. We made recommendations in relation to those matters. So far as I have been able to observe, those jurisdictional questions are still with us, even if sometimes their boundaries shift. Where those problems arise, enormous personal difficulties occur for the parties involved.

The issue I want to put clearly before the Attorney, however, does not relate to the legislation and the compromises that are involved; it relates to the very issue of the division of responsibility in relation to family law and the family law counselling service and the State responsibilities-the State courts that have jurisdiction, particularly in advance of any matrimonial cause arising. When the Joint Committee looked at these matters it made a number of recommendations in relation to the way in which counselling ought to be undertaken. I think the Committee's recommendations, which have been largely ignored, ought to be reviewed again because they were sensible in terms of addressing the question of resources and where those resources ought to be most appropriately placed.

I mentioned when the Attorney was in the House earlier, and he recalled from his own experience much the same facts, that this has been exponentially a growth area of Commonwealth expenditure. When I practised in the matrimonial causes area as a young solicitor, before the Family Law Act was put in place, there were some three judges and one acting judge who dealt with family law matters in the matrimonial causes jurisdiction in New South Wales. I have not done a recent count as to the number of Family Court judges and all the additional staff. Much of that increase may well be related to the increase in divorce. We can bring in all sorts of arguments in relation to these issues, but the fact is that enormous resources are being put into this task. The resources that were previously at the disposal of the old matrimonial causes jurisdiction and the Children's Court were rather minimal.

When the Joint Select Committee looked at these questions it found that the people who were more likely to find children at risk, the people who were more likely to be dealing with situations in which they could counsel for reconciliation rather than for divorce, were the courts of State jurisdiction. They were the old Children's Courts, the courts that might first have to deal with a child that had come to the attention of welfare authorities. They were the same Children's Courts that might first have a claim by a woman for maintenance from a husband who was not assisting.

So at the State level we had people who were more likely to become aware of difficulties in a family situation and be able to positively assist. Yet enormous resources have been placed by the Commonwealth in developing a court counselling service, a service that is jealously regarded by the Family Court as its own. It is the Family Court that gives the court counselling service its work, sits in the same building and sees it as its own creature. What we needed was a body that was much more able to relate to the other services. This is a problem of jurisdiction.

The Joint Select Committee report dealt with that matter in a very positive way, and there are recommendations in that report that have still not been positively addressed. For me, the inquiry was a case study in the way in which a parliamentary committee asked to look at these matters found that its report was later being reviewed by the professionals in the area-the advisers and family law counsellors. Anything that they did not like got swept off the agenda. I am glad that we have a new parliamentary committee about to commence inquiry in this area. I hope that the recommendations of that committee do not face the same fate that we saw in regard to many of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act in 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise the question of the standard of public debate in Australia on important issues. I will take as an example what has happened over the last few days on the matter of health policy. On 15 February, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in the Sir Norman Cowper Oration looked at the issue of the division of financial responsibilities between State and Federal governments and canvassed a number of ways of solving that problem. I remind the House that the Leader of the Opposition has supported the initiative of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in having a thorough review of these relationships. This was quite a serious speech and in the course of it the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it must be recognised that moving from a relatively centralised to a decentralised fiscal regime would impose responsibilities on all parties to co-ordinate national policy stances to a common purpose.

Just how this might be done of course requires more study and discussion. One suggestion by the Business Council is that in return for the additional taxing powers, each of the States would be required to maintain a balanced budget according to a strict accounting convention . . .
He continued:
Another alternative would be to follow the suggestion of the Institute of Public Affairs (IPA) and establish a Federation budget.
He then went on to say:

A more radical alternative which has been raised by both the Centre for Independent Studies and the IPA would be to see the Commonwealth cease paying specific grants to the States altogether in such areas as education and health.

He then canvassed the suggestions of those people regarding vouchers. That is the context within which this supposed debate has occurred. One will notice the tentative nature of those alternatives and the fact that they were identified as alternatives which were being put forward by outside bodies.

If one is going to try to have a sensible debate on these matters one has to contend with certain elements of the press. On Tuesday, 19 February, the Sydney Morning Herald carried the headline `Libs go back to the `50s with health vouchers' over an article written by Pilita Clark. It states:
The Federal Opposition is considering a radical free-market health policy which would see Medicare abolished and replaced by a voucher system administered by the Department of Social Security.
The plan is being examined in the Leader of the Opposition's office where it has attracted the strong interest of some of Dr Hewson's more influential advisers and a number of senior Liberal MPs.

One can see how that has been built up. `Libs go back to the `50s with health vouchers'-that is a very balanced report of what Dr Hewson said! There was then enormous fuss: Government Ministers created a nonsense in the House. The following day the same writer, Pilita Clark, said, `Opposition support for health vouchers wavers'. This is the support she herself had built up the previous day. The article states:
The Government moved yesterday to make maximum political capital from revelations-
revelations by whom?-
that the Opposition was considering . . . And Opposition sources confirmed that preliminary costings of the voucher system . . . showed it could add up to $3 billion to the health bill.

Where did she get that from? They do not exist. The same paper has a supposed report `From The Gallery' by Mike Seccombe entitled `Shadow health is a sickly position' which is what I can only describe as a vicious, malicious and prejudiced attack on the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods). It is a disgraceful piece which should not be there. In the same edition of the Sydney Morning Herald, there is a special piece, again by Pilita Clark, entitled `Unhealthy state in the Coalition's health policies'. It states:
Pilita Clark reports that the Coalition is still struggling to develop a workable health policy, despite its latest proposal.
The article says `its latest proposal'. I thought it was a proposal from the Centre for Independent Studies. The unbelievable bit is that she goes on to say:
The resultant headlines, which blared that the Opposition was heading back to the 1950s, provided an instant sense of deja vu for anyone . . .

Which resultant headlines? The headlines of the Sydney Morning Herald the previous day are the headlines that blared. So one can see how these things build up. A perfectly sensible and rational discussion arising out of a bipartisan attempt to look at Federal-State relations is built up by the press. Of course, one cannot expect anything better from Ministers in the House, but I do expect something better from a serious newspaper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are facing a situation today in Brisbane where, once again, the Liberal administration of the Brisbane City Council has shown its complete contempt for the people of Brisbane and their needs by its decision on 5 February to agree to the positioning of a dump at Rochedale. One might think that I should not be raising an issue such as this in Federal Parliament, but it is a very important issue to me as it will affect enormously many residents in my electorate because the dump will be located only 800 metres from very large housing sections in my electorate. Therefore, I think this is a very important issue which I need to raise on behalf of my constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many very valid reasons why this dump should not be there-none of which the Liberal administration of the Brisbane City Council took any notice. We now have a situation where one of the largest dumps in the world-a dump which will be 194 acres in size-will be located in a rural residential area, within 800 metres of the large suburban residential sections of Wishart, Mansfield and upper Mount Gravatt. This dump is simply too large. It will be the only dump servicing the whole of Brisbane. Every four minutes trucks will come past large residential areas to off-load their material at the dump and it will have enormous implications for the lives, lifestyles and health of many residents in my electorate of Moreton. The dump will be used for commercial, residential and industrial waste-and can include toxic and hazardous substances. Yet it is situated only 800 metres from densely populated suburbs. I think it is a disgrace that the Brisbane City Council Liberal administration has agreed to the location of this dump in this area.

There are many reasons why it is a totally unsuitable site, and I will list just a few of them. Firstly, there will be the problem of noise from the dump-large heavy vehicles will be working from 6.30 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. every day. Large vehicles will be driving past, as I have said, every four minutes through densely populated areas to off-load their material. So people will be disrupted by noise.

Secondly, the people of my electorate will be disrupted by odours coming from this dump. The decomposition of material in the dump will pollute both the local water table and the local air. The local water table is a very important issue because the area south of the dump is a garden farming area which produces a lot of fruit and vegetables for the markets of Brisbane. The dump site will lead to poisoning of the water table which is used by those local farmers in the Rochedale area to water their crops. That could lead to some quite adverse conditions for those farmers as well as for the people of Brisbane. The poisoning of the water table will also lead to the pollution of Bulimba Creek and, subsequently, the Brisbane River, and that also has some serious implications.

Another issue is the spreading of odours, dust and other pollutants by the wind. Surface wind analysis has indicated that for 50 per cent of the time those high density population suburbs in my electorate-the suburbs of Mansfield, upper Mount Gravatt and Wishart-will be directly exposed to smells and air pollutants emanating from this site. The pollutants will include dust, odorous substances and toxic contaminants. A massive increase in heavy truck traffic will occur in the area. The Pacific Waste Management proposal states that a large truck will enter the dump every four minutes from Monday to Friday and every 4.8 minutes on Saturday and Sunday. This will make driving more difficult, increase noise and dust and lead to a deterioration of roads in the area.

The decision of the Brisbane City Council to allow the dump to be situated in Rochedale was a scandalous decision and an abuse of its power. It ignored the massive level of complaints from local citizens that this dump was not suitable for this site. The only good thing that will come out of this decision is the fact that after the next City Council elections on 24 March Rochedale will be represented by a Labor alderman by the name of Mr Phillip Reeves, who will ensure that the needs and conditions of the people of Rochedale ward will be better looked after. Hopefully, this decision will be reversed.

All Victorian readers of the newspaper, having read the article and the headline, would have the impression that the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) had put forward definitive and costed health policy options. Nothing could be further from the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: This misleading headline has emerged from the obvious bias and lack of research by the Sun-Herald correspondent, Sue Dunleavy. The Leader of the Opposition presented a speech to the Australian Institute of Political Science on Friday, 15 February, in which he canvassed a range of policy options. It was a carefully thought out speech in which he put forward some of the more radical alternatives which could bring about a better Australia. One such idea concerned the financial arrangements between the State and Federal governments. He suggested that the Commonwealth cease paying specific grants to the States in such areas as education and health, but in specific terms he suggested:

The payments would instead be made directly to individuals, perhaps in the form of a service access card or voucher as the Americans have called it. The access card could then in turn be used by the individual to buy services from State governments or from private sector providers.

This seems a fairly sensible and thoughtful idea which has been canvassed by a number of thinking political commentators over the years. The thrust of the Leader's remarks was in the context of State and Federal relationships, and not specific health funding.

The Sun-Herald correspondent then developed a thesis based on health funding costings which have absolutely no basis in fact. The bias of the article shows through quite clearly in the suggestion that the Opposition had a costed health policy option involving voucher payments to individuals which would cost $1 billion. Sue Dunleavy was assured on two occasions that no costings had been done, and she was also assured by the Leader's office that there was no costing being commissioned.

To further compound her already erroneous statements, she intimated that the Leader had a preferred health voucher option. The Leader of the Opposition has made it quite clear, since announcing that a health seminar would be held, that he and the Party would look at all policy options to overcome the chaos that the current Medicare scheme has inflicted on all Australians. The shadow health spokesman, the honourable member for Lowe, also confirmed that there were no costings of the voucher option in existence, but that it was one of a number of health options being considered.

This initial article by Sue Dunleavy was used in the Medicare matter of public importance discussion yesterday and was quoted as authoritative evidence that a voucher system would cost $1 billion. The Government has used these incorrect reports to launch an unsubstantiated attack on the Opposition in relation to education and health funding. The whole sorry state of affairs shows the Government's own inadequacies in defending its poorly performing and costly Medicare scheme. This article reflects poorly on the SunHerald and its correspondent, Sue Dunleavy, because of the way in which the coalition's discussions on health matters have been grossly misrepresented and distorted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Wetherill Park Business Mail Delivery Centre: Public Telephones

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 May 1990 in my first speech before this House I mentioned the problem of inadequate postal facilities within my electorate of Prospect-a problem that has been a cause of concern for my constituents for quite some time. I am pleased to report that as part of the ongoing program for the development of Retail Post, Australia Post now is developing a business mail delivery centre at lot 202, Victoria Street, Wetherill Park.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a specialised facility. The Retail Post program is being developed at three levels-retail activities, such as stamp sales and normal post office transactions; business centre activities, involving the reception of volume business postings, mail pick-up and delivery for businesses, and 24 hour access private boxes; and the delivery centre function, covering the delivery of mail to all delivery points in the area. Wetherill Park is to be a combination of business centre and delivery centre, and will provide facilities for the reception of mail from surrounding businesses and for the delivery of mail within its area.

The building is being erected at an estimated cost of $1.1m, and is expected to be operational by the end of June 1991. There are currently about 22 delivery staff and five night sorters at the Smithfield post office, and all of these staff will be relocated to the Wetherill Park delivery centre. In addition, consideration is now being given to the transfer of delivery staff from Fairfield, creating much needed room in that particular facility. The counter services will remain at Fairfield and at Smithfield.

Some Smithfield post office staff will be relocated to the business centre, but it is anticipated that additional staff will also need to be employed as this is a rapidly developing industrial area. Because of the increasing need for postal facilities in the area, a retail service and private box facility will remain at Smithfield, even when the business centre is fully operational.

Although praising the action that has now been taken, it has been brought to my notice today that although the Smithfield post office originally had four telephone booths for use by the public, two were taken away some time ago and the other two were removed some four weeks ago. Upon investigating where those public telephones had been moved, I was informed that they were relocated to a shopping arcade which, I might add, is locked at night. We have no public phone facilities available in the immediate Smithfield shopping centre area following the removal of those telephones by Telecom Australia. I understand the telephones were removed at the request of Australia Post, which no longer wanted them at that location.

I believe consideration should be given to providing facilities for the people. People stranded at the Smithfield shopping centre will not have a public phone available. After inquiry I was told that there are two telephones in the immediate vicinity. When I asked where, I was told there was one at the Mobil service station and another at the Returned Services League club-half a mile away. I hope no-one breaks down and has to try to get into the club at half past two in the morning, wearing shorts and sandals.

There is another phone, I was told, 400 metres away, at the corner of Brennan and Stimson Street. Anyone who has measured that as 400 metres certainly needs to start again with his ruler. I was then informed that there was another one 800 metres away, at the intersection of Hassall Street and The Horsley Drive. That is some mile and a half away, in the old measurements, from where the original public phones were situated. How it can be said that that is 800 metres never ceases to amaze me.

I believe Telecom, in relocating services like this, must take into account the facilities that need to be provided for the public, no matter what Australia Post says. I know many homes now have phones; I know they are available. But what do people do at 2 o'clock or 3 o'clock in the morning when they need a public phone, and they go to a post office because that is where they think a phone is-and that is where the phones have been since this particular post office was built in 1972-only to find there are no phones? Then, of course, they are told not to worry because there are phones provided in the arcade for the benefit of the public-an arcade which, I stress again, is locked up every night. I cannot see how the public can benefit from a public phone which is not available to them from 6 o'clock at night until 9 o'clock in the morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise again the issue of the notorious Westpac letters. Legal action in three countries has been initiated by Westpac against the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age, the Canberra Times, Australian Broadcasting Corporation Television's 7.30 Report, ABC Radio's PM, a former Westpac foreign exchange dealer and his family, the Foreign Borrowers Association and its spokesman, Mr John McLennan. All have been restrained from publishing the letters.

SPEECH.PARA: Aggressive newspaper advertisements by Westpac have threatened the population at large for disclosure. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration inquiry into the Australian banking system was blocked from undertaking any discussion of the letters. Senator McLean was prevented from tabling the letters in the Senate. Yet, there has been no denial of the allegations contained in the letters.

This saga has raised two issues of national importance: first, the contents of the letters themselves and their allegations of malpractice on a grand scale with major implications for Westpac and the banking system; and second, and more importantly, the subversion of the national Parliament by its being prevented from fulfilling its proper function. The Constitution guarantees the freedom of parliamentary debates from question in the courts. This privilege was established by the House of Commons in 1688 by article 9 of the Bill of Rights, which states:
That the freedom of speech and debates of proceedings in Parliament ought not to be impeached or questioned in any court.
Article 9 also prevents proceedings in parliament being used in evidence in a legal action, with limited exceptions. A chief justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Harry Gibbs, has stated:
. . . a member of Parliament should be able to speak in Parliament with impunity and without any fear of the consequences.

Section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 makes it clear that while the courts might issue injunctions to prevent disclosure of documents by the public, the Parliament is immune. This immunity extends to committees and expressly extends to the presentation of documents to the House.

Notwithstanding this fundamental right, the House can restrict itself and decide that the sub judice convention could curtail debate. It is a matter of balancing the wider public interest against the need to ensure that juries are not influenced and that parties in court proceedings are not prejudiced. It is the practice of the House, in applying the sub judice rule to civil matters, to do so only if the court proceedings have been set down for trial or are on foot. In this case, there are proceedings but no jury. Former Speaker Snedden commented in 1976:
. . . judges of the courts do not regard themselves as such delicate flowers that they are likely to be prejudiced in their decisions by a debate that goes on in this House.

It might be argued that the Westpac letters ought not to be disclosed in Parliament because of legal professional privilege, but Parliament is not bound to observe any such claim. Professional privilege prevents a letter from a legal adviser being used in evidence without consent. Parliament is outside the bounds of this claim of privilege. In any case the Privileges Act 1987 prevents the letters, if they are tabled or if anything is said about them, from being used in evidence in court. There are no substantial arguments on the grounds of either the sub judice rule or legal professional privilege which would justify the House refusing the tabling of the Westpac letters. There are compelling reasons for allowing it. Parliament's integrity as an institution is at stake and there is a public interest in Parliament being free to consider the issues raised by these letters that far outweighs any public interest consideration in keeping them secret.

The Constitution, the High Court, the Parliamentary Privileges Act, the advice of the Clerk of the Senate, precedent and the overwhelming interests of the people of Australia demand that no member should be prevented from tabling the Westpac letters. To prevent their tabling would show that Westpac is being protected and this House is being subverted. I therefore seek leave to table the two Westpac letters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

—The honourable member has not gone through the normal forms of the House in providing the letters to the Minister at the table for verification, and I am not prepared to allow those letters to be tabled at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Late last year, in November, I attended with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the opening of the Melton campus of the new Victoria University of Technology (VUT) in the west of Melbourne; it was one of the most exciting days-in fact, probably the most exciting day-for the history of higher education in the west of Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with some sadness that I refer to a question that I asked the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) in the House today about the proposed development of the Victoria University, and in particular the antics of the board of the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, commonly known as RMIT.

The VUT is based essentially on a merger between RMIT and the Western Institute and the various campuses that make up those two bodies. The result of the merger, with both partners playing principal roles, has an exciting future as Victoria's fifth university. Unfortunately-and it was well covered in an article in the Australian Financial Review yesterday on page 25-there has been a breakdown in the negotiations about the formation of the campus, which seems to be based mainly around the views of the board of RMIT, which seems to think that in some way the status and the profile of RMIT will be jeopardised by continuing with the plan to be part of the VUT.

I want to take a couple of minutes of the time of the Parliament to make very clear a couple of things. First of all, I thank the Minister for his unequivocal commitment today, in the answer to my question, that the resources and the continuing support for the development of higher education in the west of Melbourne remain the highest priority for the Government. In fact, I think the Minister mentioned that some 40 per cent of the allocation for higher education in Victoria in the coming financial triennium is to this university. That is a message that ought not to be lost on the board of RMIT.

RMIT is desired as a partner in the VUT, but I would suggest that the board is being just a little bit too precious about itself in the negotiating position that it is adopting at the moment. The fact of the matter is that already students have flocked to the VUT; the enrolments this year have far exceeded even optimistic expectations. As I mentioned before, the opening day with the Prime Minister at the Melbourne campus was an exciting time. Some 700 or 800 people present saw something transformed from paddocks to a university. People are voting with their feet to come out of the city and join the new university.

I want to suggest to the members of the board of RMIT that they should think deeply about their position. As I said, I think they are being a little bit too precious about their status and view of themselves. The Government's very clear message is that the resources will go to the west, there will be substantial resources, and they will mean a lot. The RMIT can be part of that or it can elect to be something else.

I know there are a number of other options. For instance, I personally, being a person who grew up in the north and west of Melbourne, am greatly attracted to a merger of places such as the Phillip Institute of Technology, the Broadmeadows College of Technical and Further Education and the Western Institute as a university for the north and west of Melbourne. I see many options with the current proposed structure.

I reiterate the view that I would like to see the current proposal go ahead, but I make it very clear that, no matter what RMIT decides, the Victoria University of Technology in the west will go ahead, will succeed and will be the prime focus of higher education on that side of Melbourne. That is where the resources will be. I do not think there is much future being a loner in the central business district in Melbourne and occupying some of the best buildings that could be available for redevelopment of Melbourne's central business district. I do not think that that is the place where RMIT ought to be leaving itself as these things unfold.

I take this opportunity to urge the board of RMIT to take note of the students, who have said that they want to be part of the VUT, and suggest that the board move very quickly to finalise this merger.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I rise in response to the contributions in the adjournment debate tonight by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), specifically in relation to their claims about the standard of debate, particularly of the health debate, that has been going on in this House over the last couple of days.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar in particular berated the media for what he suggested was inaccurate reporting or interpretation of the Opposition's position on the health policy, such as it may be. He claimed that the Government was speaking nonsense on the matter and that he did not expect anything better from Ministers, although he expected better from the media. That is the quote that I wrote down at the time he was speaking-I hope that it is accurate.

Therefore I want to comment on the debate that has taken place in the House on these matters in the last couple of days. In particular I refer to the matter of public importance which was raised by the Government yesterday, notably to remarks made by the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods). He made a comment about the drug erythropoietin which seemed to be in parenthesis, therefore indicating that it was some form of statement or quote from the Government or from a Minister who was not specifically named. It would be assumed that it was said by either the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) or myself. The quote about the drug erythropoietin was as follows:
It is too expensive. Don't worry about the fact it saves lives or allows mothers to see their children grow up. It is too expensive. We will make sure that it is blocked out.

I want to make it very clear that in terms of standards of debate it is a nonsense to insinuate that a Government Minister made such a statement. This allegation should be justified and substantiated. As far as I am aware, the Minister for Community Services and Health did not say anything like that and I certainly have never said anything like it.

The issue of erythropoietin needs to be put in place if we are to talk about standards of debate. This kidney hormone is of use in the treatment of anaemia associated with chronic renal failure. It is currently available to patients on a clinical trial basis only. The sponsor company, Janssen-Cilag, is charging patients or health authorities for its use. In June 1990, after a previous rejection in February 1989, the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee-which is not made up of Ministers and bureaucrats, but of properly qualified doctors and experts, people who know their job in the field of pharmacy and pharmacology-recommended that erythropoietin be recommended for general marketing once outstanding quality control and product information issues were settled.

The product information document proposed by the company was considered unacceptable by this expert panel of Australian medical people. In order to save time that might be lost through protracted negotiations on individual points, the document was rewritten by the Department of Community Services and Health and returned to the company for comments. After extensive negotiation with the company, the final document was approved.

Although most quality control issues have been resolved, there are two outstanding problems in the sterility and toxin content areas. As the product may be given directly into the blood volume of the patient, sterility is of utmost importance, particularly for people who are suffering from the very serious condition of chronic renal failure. Similarly, ill patients should not be given excessive amounts of bacterial toxins. These are issues that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee is most concerned about.

As Minister, I take its advice and will not allow the marketing of that product in Australia until those experts are satisfied. I do that to protect Australians. The company was formally requested to provide answers to sterility issues in April 1990-10 months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. There being no other Minister rising, I will allow the Minister to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I was saying, the company was formally asked to provide answers to the sterility issues in April 1990, but there has been no reply despite numerous requests. The latest information from the company is that its manufacturing facility in Belgium has been so busy that it has not had the time to respond to the questions.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are talking about standards of debate, honesty and accuracy in this place, let us get down to some of the facts instead of the bluster. The questions that have been asked of the company are no different from those which would have been directed to any manufacturer of a drug purporting to affect sterility. Janssen-Cilag is well aware, or should have been well aware, of the issues to be addressed as they are set out in the NDF4 guidelines and the company has had much experience in this field. Again in September 1990 the company was asked to take action on this matter or to include an appropriate warning on the label, but so far there has been no response. These are major safety issues with a drug for people who are very sick. These issues must be resolved properly before marketing can be permitted.

Today in this country we face a process of which we are seeing more and more. It is being aided and abetted by the standard of debate-particularly in the health area-by those on the other side. We are seeing a process of drug evaluation by press release and, clearly, judging by comments that were recorded in Hansard yesterday, by unsubstantiated innuendo. The honourable member for Lowe should check his statements for accuracy because he is not doing his party any credit in the health policy area and he is creating a problem in drug evaluation processes in this country. It is not good enough just to get a cheap press release. He must get the details. I hope that the standard of debate in that regard will be lifted.

In drawing to a close I make this comment: it is becoming more and more a feature of drug evaluation issues in this country that programs are subverted and attempts are made to subvert evaluations by press release, media campaigns and letter writing campaigns before the drug has been properly evaluated. I make the point-and I will reiterate it in a letter to manufacturers and the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association-that if this sort of process continues, I will have to consider very seriously issues of commercial-in-confidence. If people want to persist in pushing these sorts of approaches out in the public and hide behind commercial-in-confidence issues within the subject of their applications, they have to be very much aware that the Government will not be prepared to have the proper drug evaluation processes of this country subverted in that way without being able adequately to respond and to assure the Australian population of the highest quality and safety of their pharmaceuticals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 21 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government provided $29.68 million to a machinery dealer in the People's Republic of China for the purchase of American technology and equipment, as reported in the June 1990 issue of China Foreign Trade.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is considering an application for funding under the Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) for a project which involves the supply of equipment and technology for the manufacture of environmentally friendly (non CFC) refrigerator compressors in China. The Australian exporter proposes to supply equipment based on US technology, for which it holds a manufacturing licence.

The report to which the honourable member refers is quite incorrect. The Australian content requirements applying to exports approved for DIFF assistance are that the equipment or service being exported must be wholly or mainly of Australian origin. In this particular project, 88 per cent of the total contract value would be manufactured in Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations: Micronesia and Marshall Islands

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: In which organisations of the United Nations have the (a) Federated States of Micronesia and (b) Republic of the Marshall Islands (i) sought and (ii) gained membership.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) has not yet made a formal approach to any UN organisation for membership although the FSM is in the process of deciding the organisations for which to formally seek membership. FSM is at present a member of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) and an associate member of the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP).
(b) The Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI) has not joined or applied for membership of any UN organisations because of problems concerning RMI's international status.
